first_sentence: Gatland's team lost 39-21 in Auckland on Saturday, leading after an hour before conceding 21 points unanswered.Wales face the Chiefs on Tuesday before the second Test against the world champions in Wellington next Saturday.
text: "There were a lot of positives out of today and we learn from the experience of that match," said Gatland. "I think we would have learned a heck of a lot from that and hopefully we are better for it again next week. "Wales have lost 27 consecutive games against the All Blacks, with their last win coming in 1953.However, Gatland said the performance at Eden Park was a big improvement after a disappointing defeat by England at the end of May. "We were brilliant for 60 minutes. We said we were going to come out and play. We knew we needed that game after England," he added. "It's the learning you take from playing against the best team in the world and sometimes the learning takes place out in the middle. "It doesn't matter what we do on the training field and as coaches, you've got to be out there in the middle and experience the relentlessness that the All Blacks bring. "We feel like we get better the longer we are together. Players don't have that many games at that level of intensity. "They get to experience it a lot more than us and are familiar and comfortable with that. "Taulupe Faletau and Rhys Webb scored tries for Wales, but the All Blacks hit back through two tries from wing Waisake Naholo and scores from Julian Savea, Kieran Read and Nathan Harris.The result ensured New Zealand's 22-year unbeaten run at Eden Park goes on after their 35th successive win at the ground.Wales play Steve Hansen's side again on Saturday, 18 June as they look for a first win in New Zealand. "We had to be brave and we had to be bold, and we did that," said Gatland. "I thought a couple of tries that we scored were outstanding and could have scored a couple more. "We made a couple of line-breaks where the All Blacks seemed reasonably happy to give away a penalty, rather than giving us a chance at the end of the breakdown. "They are the world's best team and they showed that at the end of the day because they just kept playing for the full 80 minutes."
sample_text: Despite a promising opening hour, during which they led 21-18, Wales were ultimately outclassed by the reigning world champions.Wales coach Warren Gatland was left to lament his team's inability to close out the match, citing a combination of fatigue and inexperience as contributing factors to the collapse. "We were in a great position at 60 minutes, but we just didn't have the energy or the composure to see it through," Gatland said in the post-match press conference.The tourists will now regroup and refocus ahead of their midweek clash with the Chiefs in Hamilton on Tuesday. The match against the Super Rugby franchise will provide an opportunity for Gatland to rotate his squad and give some of his fringe players a run-out.However, the real test will come next Saturday, when Wales face the All Blacks again in the second Test in Wellington. The Welsh will need to regroup and find a way to contain the All Blacks' attacking threats if they are to have any hope of levelling the series.Gatland has already hinted at making changes to his starting lineup for the second Test, with several players putting their hands up for selection with impressive performances off the bench. One player who is likely to come into contention is scrum-half Gareth Davies, who sparked Wales' attack with his introduction in the second half.Despite the defeat, Wales can take heart from their first-half performance, which saw them match the All Blacks blow for blow. If they can rediscover that level of intensity and cohesion, they may yet cause an upset in Wellington. But for now, the focus is on bouncing back from a disappointing defeat and preparing for the challenges that lie ahead.

While the tourists will be disappointed with the outcome, they can take solace in the fact that they pushed the world champions to the limit for large periods of the match.One of the major positives to emerge from the game was the performance of Wales' debutant, wing Josh Adams. The 22-year-old scored a try on his international debut and looked dangerous every time he touched the ball. His pace and agility caused problems for the All Blacks' defense, and he will be a key player for Wales in the remaining matches of the tour.Another player who impressed was flanker James Davies, who made his first start for Wales. The 27-year-old was a constant thorn in the side of the All Blacks, making several crucial tackles and turnovers. His work rate was exceptional, and he will be a key component of Wales' back row in the second Test.Despite the loss, Wales' captain, Alun Wyn Jones, remained upbeat about his team's chances in the series. "We're disappointed with the result, but we're not disheartened," Jones said. "We know we can improve, and we'll be working hard to do so. We'll take the positives from this game and build on them for the next match."The All Blacks, meanwhile, will be relieved to have come away with the win, but they will also be aware that they were pushed to the limit by a determined Welsh side. Coach Steve Hansen will be looking for improvements in several areas, including their set piece and defense, which were both breached by Wales on several occasions.The second Test in Wellington promises to be another intense and physical encounter, with both teams looking to make a statement. Wales will be desperate to level the series, while the All Blacks will be keen to wrap up the series with a win. One thing is certain - it will be a thrilling encounter that will have fans on the edge of their seats.

"We were in a great position at 60 minutes, but we just didn't have the energy or the composure to see it through," Gatland said in the post-match press conference.The tourists will now regroup and refocus ahead of their midweek clash with the Chiefs in Hamilton on Tuesday. The match against the Super Rugby franchise will provide an opportunity for Gatland to rotate his squad and give some of his fringe players a run-out.However, the real test will come next Saturday, when Wales face the All Blacks again in the second Test in Wellington. The Welsh will need to regroup and find a way to contain the All Blacks' attacking threats if they are to have any hope of levelling the series.Gatland has already hinted at making changes to his starting lineup for the second Test, with several players putting their hands up for selection with impressive performances off the bench. One player who is likely to come into contention is scrum-half Gareth Davies, who sparked Wales' attack with his introduction in the second half.Despite the defeat, Wales can take heart from their first-half performance, which saw them match the All Blacks blow for blow. If they can rediscover that level of intensity and cohesion, they may yet cause an upset in Wellington. But for now, the focus is on bouncing back from a disappointing defeat and preparing for the challenges that lie ahead. The defeat marks Wales' 27th consecutive loss to the All Blacks on New Zealand soil, a streak that dates back to 1953. While the tourists will be disappointed with the outcome, they can take solace in the fact that they pushed the world champions to the limit for large periods of the match.One of the major positives to emerge from the game was the performance of Wales' debutant, wing Josh Adams. The 22-year-old scored a try on his international debut and looked dangerous every time he touched the ball.

first_sentence: They are among dozens of firms worried that proposed new regulations will mean extra charges for fast internet access.The US Federal Communications Commission said its proposals were designed to protect net neutrality.Many groups taking part will display the spinning wheel, an icon for slow loading speed, but will run normally.Indicating that it would take part in the protest, Netflix posted an animation of the wheel on its US Twitter account on Monday.
text: The icon will link to a page showing readers ways to take action to defend "net neutrality", Agence France-Presse (AFP) reported.The Netflix post also urged others to join the campaign. WordPress and the American Civil Liberties Union said they were also planning to take part on Wednesday.A Twitter spokesman told the BBC: "We support the Internet Slowdown campaign and its efforts to draw public attention to a critically important issue. We're not planning to add a banner to our home page, but we'll participate in other ways." The spokesman would not elaborate on the form Twitter's protest would take.According to one of the protest organisers, Free Press, Reddit and Netflix will be joined by Mozilla, Kickstarter and Upworthy, as well as Automattic - which runs WordPress - Digg and Vimeo.Other online firms taking part will include Boing Boing, Thunderclap and Urban Dictionary, as well as Foursquare, Digg and Cheezburger. "The cause of net neutrality is important to us as a business. It's important to our visitors, and it's important for our democracy. We're proud to take part in the Internet Slowdown and encourage others to join with us," said Reddit general manager Erik Martin.Paul Sieminski, general counsel of Automattic said: "The free and open internet has been central to the economy and to global free expression. Everyone has to step up now and do everything they can to protect it," according to AFP. "We need our leaders to stand up to the cabal of cable and phone giants that have called the shots in Washington for too long," Free Press Action Fund president Craig Aaron said.The move follows the proposal from the Federal Communications Commission (FCC), which would require telecom providers to ensure that "all users have access to an internet experience that is sufficiently robust, fast and effectively usable".The proposal came after a US Court of Appeals ruling in January that found that broadband providers were not under an obligation to ensure all internet traffic was treated equally.The FCC's proposals defined users as both consumers and "content providers who do not enter into specific arrangements with broadband providers".Providers would be banned from blocking downloads of legal content but the rules would leave the door open to them to charge for "prioritised" data delivery.In response, more than 100 technology firms, including Microsoft, Google, Facebook and Twitter, wrote to the FCC claiming the rules "would enable phone and cable internet service providers to discriminate both technically and financially against internet companies and to impose new tolls on them".They wrote: "This represents a grave threat to the internet."
sample_text: The event, dubbed "Internet Slowdown," aims to demonstrate what the internet might be like if the proposed regulations are implemented.The FCC's proposals would allow internet service providers (ISPs) to charge companies for faster access to their customers, a move that critics argue would stifle innovation and limit access to certain websites and services. The regulations would also reclassify broadband internet as a public utility, giving the FCC greater authority to regulate the industry.Proponents of the regulations argue that they are necessary to ensure that ISPs do not unfairly throttle or block certain types of online content. However, opponents claim that the rules would lead to increased costs for consumers and stifle investment in broadband infrastructure.During the protest, participating websites will display a spinning wheel icon, which is typically seen when a website is loading slowly. The icon will be accompanied by a message explaining the importance of net neutrality and encouraging users to contact their elected representatives to express their opinions on the issue.The protest is being organized by a coalition of tech companies, advocacy groups, and online activists, who are urging the FCC to adopt stronger net neutrality rules. The event is seen as a key moment in the ongoing debate over the future of the internet, and is expected to generate widespread media attention and public awareness.In addition to the online protest, several advocacy groups are planning rallies and demonstrations outside FCC headquarters in Washington, D.C. to coincide with the event. The protests are expected to draw hundreds of people, including tech industry leaders, activists, and concerned citizens.The FCC is expected to vote on the proposed regulations later this year, and the outcome is far from certain. However, with the tech industry and advocacy groups mobilizing against the proposals, the agency is likely to face significant pressure to reconsider its approach.
sample_text2: As the Internet Slowdown protest gains momentum, major tech companies such as Google, Amazon, and Facebook are expected to participate, displaying the spinning wheel icon on their websites and social media platforms. Other prominent participants include online platforms like Reddit, Netflix, and Twitter, as well as advocacy groups like the Electronic Frontier Foundation and the American Civil Liberties Union.The protest is not limited to the online sphere, as several rallies and demonstrations are planned outside FCC headquarters in Washington, D.C. The events are expected to draw hundreds of people, including tech industry leaders, activists, and concerned citizens. Protesters will be holding signs and banners, and will be encouraged to share their experiences and opinions on social media using the hashtag #InternetSlowdown.The Internet Slowdown protest is seen as a crucial moment in the ongoing debate over net neutrality, as it aims to raise awareness about the potential consequences of the FCC's proposed regulations. By simulating a slow internet experience, the protest hopes to demonstrate the negative impact that the regulations could have on online innovation, free speech, and consumer choice."This is a critical moment in the fight for net neutrality," said Sarah Jones, a spokesperson for the Electronic Frontier Foundation. "We need to send a strong message to the FCC that the internet belongs to the people, not to the ISPs. We can't let them turn the internet into a toll road, where only those who can afford it get to access the fast lane."The FCC's proposed regulations have sparked intense debate, with proponents arguing that they are necessary to ensure that ISPs do not unfairly throttle or block certain types of online content. However, opponents claim that the rules would lead to increased costs for consumers and stifle investment in broadband infrastructure.As the protest gains momentum, lawmakers and regulators are taking notice. Several members of Congress have spoken out against the FCC's proposed regulations, and some have introduced legislation aimed at protecting net neutrality.The Internet Slowdown protest is expected to generate widespread media attention and public awareness, and could potentially influence the FCC's decision on the proposed regulations. With the tech industry and advocacy groups mobilizing against the proposals, the agency is likely to face significant pressure to reconsider its approach.As the protest continues, one thing is clear: the future of the internet is at stake, and the outcome of this debate will have far-reaching consequences for online innovation, free speech, and consumer choice.

first_sentence: "Celtic have brought in the higher-class player, I think," said former Celtic midfielder MacLeod.
text: "When you are bringing players from Liverpool, boys who have played at Man City - it is good quality players they have brought in. "But Rangers have brought in good quality as well. "Former Arsenal, Manchester City and Liverpool defender Kolo Toure and winger Scott Sinclair, formerly of Man City and Aston Villa, have been recruited by new Celtic manager Brendan Rodgers.Meanwhile, Rangers counterpart Mark Warburton's big-name additions are former Burnley midfielder Joey Barton and his former QPR team-mate, Niko Kranjcar. "I think Rangers fans will be going into this game hoping they all produce a good performance on the day," said MacLeod looking ahead to Saturday's first Old Firm game of the season at Celtic Park. "But Celtic fans will be looking at their team and thinking they are a strong side, quicker, better and they can win the match. "However, MacLeod pointed out that the Old Firm occasion has sometimes proved too much for some notable names to handle. "There have been a lot of players and even big-name players who have turned up for an Old Firm game and not played well," he said. "Some players in the past, you have looked at them and thought that he will be great addition to the club and they have not produced anything. "You have to wait until the game actually happens and then decide how well they have played. "MacLeod believes Leigh Griffiths could be the difference between the teams in Saturday's Old Firm derby - as long as the striker recovers from injury.The 26-year-old missed Scotland's 2018 World Cup qualifying win in Malta on Sunday with a hamstring complaint, but Celtic are confident he will recover in time to face Rangers in their first Premiership encounter of the season. "In any Old Firm game, you need people who can score goals and, when you have got Griffiths fully fit, that is so important because I think he is the one that will get goals," said MacLeod. "Griffiths is the guy you look at that is going to score, whether from outside the box or inside the box. He is a predator and he will score goals for you at all levels."
sample_text: In an exclusive interview with our publication, MacLeod, who made over 300 appearances for the Hoops between 1978 and 1987, stated that Celtic's transfer business has been more impressive than Rangers' this summer.'Celtic have brought in the higher-class player, I think,' said MacLeod. 'They've got a better squad depth and quality now. Rangers have done okay, but Celtic have done better.'MacLeod's comments are likely to rile Rangers fans, who have been buoyed by their team's impressive start to the season. The Gers have won their opening three league matches, while Celtic have stuttered with two draws and a win.However, MacLeod believes that Celtic's superior squad depth will ultimately tell as the season wears on. 'Celtic have got a stronger squad, and that will show as the season goes on,' he said. 'They've got more quality players, and that will make a difference.'MacLeod's comments have sparked a fierce reaction on social media, with fans from both sides of the Old Firm divide weighing in on the debate. While some have praised MacLeod's honesty, others have accused him of bias and ignorance.The debate is set to continue in the coming weeks, as both teams face crucial matches in the league and Europe. One thing is certain, however - the rivalry between Celtic and Rangers remains as intense as ever, and MacLeod's comments have only added fuel to the fire."
sample_text2: **OLD FIRM RIVALRY REACHES BOILING POINT AS MACLEOD WEIGHS IN ON TRANSFER BATTLE**The war of words between Celtic and Rangers fans has escalated to new heights after Hoops legend Murdo MacLeod sparked a frenzy with his comments on the two teams' summer transfer business. In an exclusive interview with our publication, MacLeod, a Celtic icon who made over 300 appearances for the club between 1978 and 1987, boldly stated that the Bhoys have outdone their arch-rivals in the transfer market.MacLeod's assertion that Celtic have assembled a stronger squad with "higher-class players" has drawn a fierce reaction from Rangers supporters, who have been quick to point out their team's impressive start to the season. The Gers have won all three of their opening league matches, while Celtic have stuttered with two draws and a solitary win.However, MacLeod remains adamant that Celtic's superior squad depth will ultimately prove decisive as the season wears on. "Celtic have got a stronger squad, and that will show as the season goes on," he insisted. "They've got more quality players, and that will make a difference."The 62-year-old's comments have sparked a heated debate on social media, with fans from both sides of the Old Firm divide weighing in on the debate. While some have praised MacLeod's honesty, others have accused him of bias and ignorance.Rangers fans have been quick to point out their team's impressive start to the season, with many arguing that their side's early momentum will be difficult for Celtic to catch up with. "MacLeod must be joking," tweeted @RangersTillIDie. "We're top of the league and Celtic are struggling to get out of second gear. Who's got the better squad now?"Meanwhile, Celtic fans have rallied behind MacLeod, hailing his comments as a dose of reality. "MacLeod's telling it like it is," wrote @CelticFC4Life. "We've got the better squad and it's only a matter of time before we catch up with Rangers."As the debate rages on, both teams face crucial matches in the coming weeks that will go a long way in shaping the destiny of the Scottish Premiership title. Celtic travel to Hibernian on Saturday, while Rangers host Aberdeen at Ibrox.One thing is certain, however - the rivalry between Celtic and Rangers remains as intense as ever, and MacLeod's comments have only added fuel to the fire. The battle for supremacy in Scottish football has never been more fierce, and fans from both sides will be eagerly awaiting the next installment of this epic struggle.

first_sentence: Keane Wallis-Bennett, 12, died in the changing rooms of Liberton High School.Sheriff Principal Mhairi Stephen found "the innocent high-spirited behaviour" of pupils could have caused the freestanding privacy wall to collapse.She recommended that new warnings should be issued about similar walls.City of Edinburgh Council said its "overriding priority" is to ensure pupils' safety.The determination said Keane died of multiple injuries following the incident on 1 April 2014.The immediate cause of the wall collapsing was found to be the application of lateral force sufficient to push it beyond its tipping point.It was "probable" the activities of other pupils who were braced between the wall and a nearby shower wall caused it to move.But the determination said: "The unstable nature of the wall was the real cause of the accident.
text: "It identified two main factors.The first was the design and construction of the wall.The second was a crack along the horizontal plane of the wall.The sheriff principal said that although the crack close to its base had been there for "a long period of time" it would not have been obvious to visual inspection.Although she said there were no reasonable precautions she could recommend which would have avoided the accident, she said a warning about freestanding walls should be reinforced.She said the Health and Safety Executive, in conjunction with the Scottish government, should ensure an assessment is made of the risk posed by these walls.This should be in conjunction with remedial measures where the walls cannot be safely and effectively removed.City of Edinburgh Council said the inquiry had backed its view that there were no "reasonable precautions" it could have taken.Executive Director of Communities and Families, Alistair Gaw, said: "Once again on behalf of the City of Edinburgh Council I want to express our deepest sympathies to Keane's family for their tragic loss. "Having now received the determination from Sheriff Principal Mhairi Stephen, we note her conclusion that there were no reasonable precautions that could have been taken to avoid the accident which resulted in Keane's death. "She further finds that the maintenance and inspection regime at Liberton High School complied with statutory requirements and that there was a comprehensive understanding of the fault-reporting system among staff. The determination also states that the council had taken all reasonably practicable measures to ensure that the wall was inspected and maintained. "The council said it had already looked at the potential hazards represented by other walls of similar design.Mr Gaw added: "Immediately after the incident in 2014, the council removed similar free-standing walls in its schools and subsequently safety advice was issued by the Scottish government advising all local authorities of the risks regarding these walls. "Our overriding priority is always the safety of pupils and staff and we want to ensure nothing like this tragic event ever happens again."
sample_text: The wall was not securely fixed to the floor and was prone to tipping over."Sheriff Principal Mhairi Stephen's determination highlighted the need for schools to review their safety protocols and ensure that similar freestanding walls are properly secured to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.The incident occurred on April 1, 2014, when Keane Wallis-Bennett, a 12-year-old pupil at Liberton High School, died after the freestanding privacy wall in the changing rooms collapsed on him. The wall, which was approximately 2.4 meters tall and 1.2 meters wide, was not fixed to the floor and was designed to provide privacy for pupils changing for physical education classes.The investigation into the incident found that the wall was not properly secured and was prone to tipping over. The determination stated that the wall's unstable nature, combined with the innocent and high-spirited behavior of the pupils, led to the tragic accident.City of Edinburgh Council, which is responsible for the school, has expressed its condolences to Keane's family and has pledged to take steps to ensure that similar incidents do not occur in the future. A spokesperson for the council said, "Our overriding priority is the safety of our pupils, and we will do everything in our power to prevent such a tragedy from happening again."The council has promised to review its safety protocols and to work with schools to ensure that all freestanding walls are properly secured and meet safety standards. The council will also provide additional training to school staff on safety procedures and emergency response protocols.Keane's family has welcomed the determination and has called for schools to take immediate action to ensure that similar walls are properly secured. In a statement, the family said, "We hope that Keane's tragic death will not be in vain and that schools will take action to prevent such incidents from happening again. We will continue to fight for justice and to ensure that schools are safe for all pupils."The incident has raised concerns about school safety and the need for schools to review their safety protocols to prevent such tragedies from occurring in the future.

first_sentence: Toyota set the target as it unveiled a concept fuel cell powered car, called the FCV, at the Tokyo Motor Show.The car can be re-fuelled within minutes and it can cover about 500km (300 miles) on a full tank, according to the firm.Earlier this week, rival Hyundai said it plans to start mass production of such cars as early as next year.By Puneet Pal SinghBusiness reporter, BBC NewsEco-friendly cars have been been the buzzword in the auto industry for some time now.
text: And within that space, fuel cell-powered vehicles are turning out to be the flavour of the season.Carmakers have been showing off the progress they have made in the area.The trick, of course, is how soon companies can take their concept cars from the motor show floors, to showrooms and subsequently to garages at homes.Toyota and Hyundai aim to do this within the next year or two. But as we have seen it with electric cars in the past, it is easier said than done. There are already concerns about a lack of hydrogen filling stations.And an equally big challenge will be producing them cheaply enough to keep them affordable for buyers.None of the carmakers has officially revealed the prices as yet, though some reports indicate that Toyota's FCV may cost between $50,000 and $100,000 (Â£31,000 to Â£62,000).The South Korean company has announced plans to start commercial sales of a fuel cell-powered version of its sports utility vehicle, the Tucson, in the US market.Honda Motor is also expected to unveil its latest concept version of a fuel cell-powered vehicle later this week.Many carmakers have been looking to develop the fuel cell technology further and bring it to mass production.One of the main reasons is that it is emission-free.The technology uses hydrogen to generate electricity to power the engine and the waste products are heat and water.At the same time, fuel cells charge much faster and travel a longer distance after being charged, compared with battery-operated electric cars.However, there are concerns over the demand for such vehicles, not least because there are not enough hydrogen filling stations.Carlos Ghosn, chief executive of Nissan, said that worries over infrastructure were the key reason for his firm to put some of their plans on hold. "Frankly, I don't know how they are going to do it, because knowing all the problems we have, to have a charging system with electricity, where is the hydrogen infrastructure?" Mr Ghosn was quoted as saying by the Reuters news agency. "That's why we have postponed, in a certain way, some of our ambitions in terms of fuel cells."
sample_text: The Japanese automaker has set an ambitious target of launching its fuel cell powered car, the FCV, by 2015. The concept car, unveiled at the Tokyo Motor Show, boasts an impressive range of 500km on a full tank, which can be refueled in just a few minutes.Toyota's announcement comes hot on the heels of Hyundai's declaration earlier this week that it plans to start mass production of fuel cell powered cars as early as next year. The South Korean automaker has been investing heavily in fuel cell technology and has already showcased its own fuel cell powered car, the ix35 FCEV.The growing interest in fuel cell technology is driven by its potential to provide a zero-emission alternative to traditional gasoline-powered cars. Fuel cells use hydrogen as a fuel source, which produces only water and heat as byproducts, making them an attractive option for environmentally conscious consumers.Toyota's FCV concept car is powered by a fuel cell stack that is more compact and efficient than previous models. The company claims that the car can be refueled in just three to five minutes, making it a viable option for daily driving.While there are still significant challenges to overcome, including the lack of hydrogen refueling infrastructure, Toyota's announcement is a significant step forward for the industry. The company has already begun testing its fuel cell technology on public roads in Japan and plans to expand its testing to the US and Europe in the coming months.As the auto industry continues to shift towards more eco-friendly options, it's clear that fuel cell technology is going to play a major role in the future of transportation. With Toyota and Hyundai leading the charge, it's likely that we'll see more and more fuel cell powered cars hitting the roads in the coming years.
sample_text2: Industry experts are hailing Toyota's announcement as a major breakthrough, citing the company's reputation for reliability and quality as a key factor in bringing fuel cell technology to the mainstream."Toyota's entry into the fuel cell market is a game-changer," said Dr. David Kim, a leading expert on alternative energy vehicles. "Their commitment to producing a fuel cell car by 2015 will help to drive down costs and increase adoption rates. It's a significant step forward for the industry as a whole."Toyota's FCV concept car is not only impressive in terms of its range and refueling time, but also in its design. The sleek and futuristic vehicle boasts a spacious interior and advanced safety features, making it an attractive option for consumers.While Toyota and Hyundai are leading the charge in fuel cell technology, other automakers are also investing heavily in the area. Honda, for example, has been testing its own fuel cell car, the FCX Clarity, on public roads in Japan and the US.The growing interest in fuel cell technology is also driving investment in hydrogen infrastructure. Governments and companies around the world are investing billions of dollars in building out a network of hydrogen refueling stations, which will be critical to supporting the widespread adoption of fuel cell cars.In California, for example, the state government has committed to building out a network of 100 hydrogen refueling stations by 2020. Similarly, in Japan, the government has set a target of building 1,000 hydrogen refueling stations by 2025.While there are still significant challenges to overcome, including the high cost of fuel cell technology and the lack of hydrogen infrastructure, it's clear that the industry is moving rapidly towards a future powered by fuel cells.As the world continues to grapple with the challenges of climate change and air pollution, the development of fuel cell technology is a welcome step forward. With Toyota and Hyundai leading the charge, it's likely that we'll see a significant shift towards fuel cell powered cars in the coming years.In the meantime, consumers can expect to see more and more fuel cell concept cars and prototypes hitting the roads, as automakers continue to test and refine their technology. With the promise of zero-emission driving and fast refueling times, it's clear that fuel cell technology is an exciting development that's here to stay.

first_sentence: The British world number two broke Berdych in the third game and saved two break points in the next before racing through the first set in 38 minutes.Murray made it nine successive games to get to 3-0 in the second set before securing a semi-final against Novak Djokovic at 13:00 BST on Saturday.
text: "I felt I dictated the whole match," the 28-year-old Scot told Sky Sports. "Against someone serving as big as him, it's not always easy to do. I didn't have too much defending to do. I served well and got a good read on his serve. "Murray was relieved the contest only lasted 78 minutes, saying: "I'm very happy with the performance and I get to conserve some energy. It's pretty late here and it takes an hour-and-a-half to get back to the hotel. "World number one Djokovic moved into the last four with a 7-6 (8-6) 6-1 win over Australian Bernard Tomic.The Serb was pushed all the way in a thrilling opening set, edging the tie-break, before Tomic capitulated in the second.Djokovic won his last match against Murray in Shanghai, in the 2012 final. "It'll be an extremely tough match," the Briton said of Saturday's encounter. "We played great tennis in the 2012 final, but I feel like we are quite different players since then. I feel both of us have progressed and play different tennis. We are now quite aggressive. "Earlier, Rafael Nadal's renaissance took a big step forward as he thrashed a flagging Stan Wawrinka for the loss of just three games.The Spaniard beat the world number four 6-2 6-1 for his first win over a top-five player in more than a year, building on his run to last week's China Open final.Nadal will meet Frenchman Jo-Wilfried Tsonga - a 7-6 (8-6) 5-7 6-4 winner over South Africa Kevin Anderson - in the last four.

first_sentence: Media playback is not supported on this deviceCathro admits he did not deal with Sunday's Scottish Cup disappointment in the best way on camera.
text: "Nobody's sent me a copy of the clip yet and I don't think I'm going to watch it," he said. "I would be cringing more than anybody else in the room. "BBC Scotland had live coverage of the fourth-round tie at Stark's Park, where Declan McManus's late, flicked header cancelled out Jamie Walker's opener, forcing a replay at Tynecastle on Wednesday.Cathro took part in an awkward interview afterwards and offered an explanation on Tuesday. "Your mind's in a different place and it shouldn't be, but sometimes it is," he said. "You're going to feel that way at times. I wasn't happy. "Whether you should try and hide that, maybe you should. You should probably do it better than I did, but that's for me to recognise as well and that will be part of this. "If there's any reason for it, it's because you take the frustration and disappointment that the fans felt in that moment, you've probably got to times that by 1000 to get to where I was. "Hearts will have a home tie against Edinburgh rivals Hibernian if they beat Raith, but Cathro insists the team's focus is on nothing beyond Wednesday.New signings Malaury Martin, Lenny Sowah, Andraz Struna and Aaron Hughes were all involved in Sunday's match and Cathro has his eye on adding a couple more before the end of the month.A striker and a centre-back top his list of priorities"Yes, we're working, we're working," Cathro said. "Every day we're making progress. "There are still a few things we'd like to do. The fact we're getting closer to the end of the month, everything does become a little bit more difficult, or complicated. "You start to see the end of the month and sometimes it changes the conditions and maybe some people's behaviours, and the whole game gets a little bit more, not murky, but more difficult. "We're in a position where more players will join us, we've just got a bit of work to do. If we bring in another couple of players then we begin to say we have the balance that we would like. "I don't want to get obsessed about a certain number of players."
sample_text: In a candid interview, the Hearts manager acknowledged that his post-match comments on Sunday were "unprofessional" and "emotional", and apologized to the fans and the media for his behavior."I was still reeling from the defeat and I didn't handle it as well as I should have," Cathro said. "I let my emotions get the better of me, and for that, I apologize. As a manager, I need to set a better example and show more composure, even in the face of adversity."Cathro's comments on Sunday had sparked controversy, with many criticizing him for being overly defensive and dismissive of the team's performance. However, in today's interview, he took full responsibility for the defeat and vowed to learn from the experience."I've had time to reflect on the game and I realize that we didn't do enough to win," he said. "We didn't create enough chances, and when we did, we didn't take them. That's on me, and I need to do better."When asked about his future at the club, Cathro remained defiant, insisting that he still has the support of the players and the board."I've spoken to the chairman and the players, and we're all on the same page," he said. "We know we've had a tough run of results, but we're working hard to turn it around. I'm committed to this club and I'm determined to get us back on track."Despite the apology, Cathro's future at Hearts remains uncertain, with many fans calling for his head on social media. However, for now, it seems that he will be given the chance to redeem himself and turn the team's fortunes around.
sample_text2: Cathro's apology and vow to learn from the experience has been met with a mixed reaction from the Hearts faithful. While some have praised the manager for taking responsibility and showing humility, others remain skeptical and are calling for more tangible results on the pitch.One fan, who wished to remain anonymous, told our reporter: "It's all well and good for Cathro to apologize, but actions speak louder than words. We need to see a marked improvement in the team's performance and results before we can start to trust him again."Another fan, John Smith, said: "I think Cathro's apology is a step in the right direction. He's shown that he's willing to listen and learn, and that's what we need right now. Let's give him a chance to turn things around before we start calling for his head."The Hearts board has also released a statement in support of Cathro, saying: "We appreciate Ian's honesty and commitment to the club. We're working hard to prepare and we're determined to come out on top. It's going to be a tough match, but we're ready for the challenge."Only time will tell if Cathro's apology and vow to learn from his mistakes will be enough to save his job. One thing is certain, however - the pressure is on, and Cathro needs to deliver results quickly to avoid becoming the latest managerial casualty in the Scottish Premiership.

first_sentence: The IMF also has strong warnings about what a Brexit would do to the economy, and the Reality Check team will look forward to evaluating those next month, when the IMF gives the full detail of its forecasts.But it is worth bearing in mind the IMF describes itself as an organisation "working to foster global monetary cooperation".
text: It is hardly surprising a potential Brexit would not be its cup of tea.It actually cited two reasons for the currency's weakness, saying between August 2015 and February 2016 "the British pound depreciated by 7%, driven by expectations of a later normalisation of monetary policy in the United Kingdom and concerns about a potential exit from the European Union".The point about the "later normalisation of monetary policy" means as a result of the general weakness of the economy, the expected date of the first rise in interest rates from the Bank of England was delayed.The IMF is presumably comparing the pound with a selection of currencies. Between the beginning of August and the end of February, the pound actually fell about 11% against the US dollar and 10% against the euro.How much of this was due to the referendum and how much was down to other factors?Well, the referendum date was not confirmed until 20 February, but it was widely expected to be announced.There was a pretty sharp fall in the value of the pound around the time of the announcement, as you can see from the graphs, although that particular dip was relatively short-lived.So, how much of the pound's fall was down to uncertainty surrounding a potential Brexit as opposed to factors such as interest rate expectations?As we have discussed before, predicting uncertainty cannot be seen as a controversial forecast, and it is generally accepted markets do not like uncertainty.So it is fair to say some of the fall in the pound has been due to the potential for Brexit - it is a factor that has been cited regularly in analysts' reports. The Office for Budget Responsibility cited some of the banks predicting weakness for the pound.But given the result of the referendum will have implications for the economy for decades to come, a bit of weakness in the pound ahead of the vote should not be seen as too worrying a factor.In particular, a weak pound is not a bad thing for everyone - it is good news for many exporters in the UK.Reality Check verdict: The referendum debate is likely to be one of the factors weakening the pound, but things like delayed interest rate rises are also responsible.Read more: The facts behind claims in the EU debate
sample_text: As such, it's no surprise that the IMF would be concerned about the potential disruption to global trade and economic stability that a Brexit could cause.The IMF's warnings come on the heels of similar cautionary statements from other major economic organizations, including the World Bank and the OECD. All of these organizations are sounding the alarm about the potential risks of a Brexit, including the possibility of a recession, a decline in trade and investment, and a decrease in economic growth.But it's not just the economic organizations that are sounding the alarm. Many business leaders and investors are also expressing concerns about the potential impact of a Brexit on the economy. They point to the uncertainty and instability that a Brexit would create, and the potential for a decline in consumer and business confidence.Despite these warnings, however, many Brexit supporters remain undeterred. They argue that the UK would be better off outside of the EU, free from the burdens of EU regulations and able to negotiate its own trade deals. They also point to the potential benefits of a Brexit, including the ability to control immigration and to make its own laws.As the debate over Brexit continues to heat up, it's clear that the economic implications of a Brexit will be a major factor in the decision. sample_text2: **Brexit Debate Intensifies as IMF Warns of Economic Risks**The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has added its voice to the growing chorus of concerns over the potential economic risks of a Brexit, warning that a UK exit from the European Union could lead to a decline in trade, investment, and economic growth.In a statement released yesterday, the IMF cautioned that a Brexit could lead to a "negative and lasting impact" on the UK economy, citing the potential disruption to trade and investment flows, as well as the uncertainty and instability that would likely follow a UK exit from the EU.The IMF's warnings come on the heels of similar cautionary statements from other major economic organizations, including the World Bank and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD). All three organizations have sounded the alarm about the potential risks of a Brexit, including the possibility of a recession, a decline in trade and investment, and a decrease in economic growth.**Business Leaders Weigh In**Many business leaders and investors are also expressing concerns about the potential impact of a Brexit on the economy. They point to the uncertainty and instability that a Brexit would create, and the potential for a decline in consumer and business confidence."The uncertainty surrounding a Brexit is already having an impact on our business," said Sarah Jones, CEO of a UK-based manufacturing firm. "We're seeing a decline in investment and a hesitation to make long-term plans. If the UK were to leave the EU, I fear it would only exacerbate these problems."**Brexit Supporters Unfazed**Despite these warnings, however, many Brexit supporters remain undeterred. They argue that the UK would be better off outside of the EU, free from the burdens of EU regulations and able to negotiate its own trade deals."The EU is holding us back," said John Smith, a leading Brexit campaigner. "We need to take back control of our laws and our borders. A Brexit would allow us to do just that, and would ultimately lead to a more prosperous and independent UK."**Economic Implications Take Center Stage**As the debate over Brexit continues to heat up, it's clear that the economic implications of a Brexit will be a major factor in the decision. The IMF's warnings are just the latest in a series of cautionary statements from major economic organizations, and they are likely to be closely scrutinized by policymakers and voters alike.In the coming weeks and months, the Reality Check team will be digging deeper into the economic implications of a Brexit, examining the claims and counter-claims of both sides and providing an in-depth analysis of the potential risks and benefits.**Stay Tuned for More**Stay tuned for more on this developing story, as we explore the potential impact of a Brexit on trade, investment, and economic growth. first_sentence: The 30-year-old Germany midfielder is believed to have told Bayern he did not want to extend his contract, which runs until 2016.United announced in a club statement on Saturday that they had reached an agreement to sign him.
text: "I hope you understand my decision," Schweinsteiger told fans on Twitter.The World-Cup winner said he was moving to United to "gain experience at a new club". "No one can take away the incredible journey we had together. The decision was very hard to make because you and Bayern have, are and will always be an extremely important part of my life," he added.The Old Trafford club hope to complete the medical to enable Schweinsteiger to be involved in their tour of the US.Louis van Gaal's men fly out to America on Monday afternoon and will be based in Seattle for their first game against Mexican team Club America on Friday.Bayern's chief executive Karl-Heinz Rummenigge said: "It's regrettable because Bastian meant a great deal to the club. "He achieved great things but he wants to do something new at the end of his career. He asked that we meet his wishes. "Schweinsteiger has made 536 appearances for Bayern since his debut in 2002 and played under Van Gaal while the Dutchman was in charge at Bayern between 2009 and 2011.He helped his country win the 2014 World Cup and has one Champions League, eight Bundesliga titles and seven domestic cup triumphs to his name while at the German club.Bayern defender and former German captain Philipp Lahm said: "We have to simply respect and accept his decision. He's  looking for a new challenge, but for me it's an absolute pity he is going. "United identified Schweinsteiger earlier this summer as a high-profile player they were interested in, along with Real Madrid defender Sergio Ramos.United have made two other signings this summer - £31m-winger Memphis Depay arrived from Dutch club PSV Eindhoven in June - and on Saturday Italian defender Matteo Darmian signed for an undisclosed fee from Torino.Find all the latest football transfers on our dedicated page.
sample_text: The transfer fee is reportedly in the region of £20 million, a significant coup for United who have been searching for a creative midfielder to bolster their squad.Schweinsteiger, a World Cup winner with Germany in 2014, has been a key player for Bayern Munich, making over 350 appearances for the club and winning numerous honors, including eight Bundesliga titles and the Champions League in 2020.The midfielder's decision to leave Bayern has come as a surprise to many, given his status as a club legend and his close relationship with manager Pep Guardiola. However, it is understood that Schweinsteiger was seeking a new challenge and was attracted to the opportunity to play in the Premier League.United manager Louis van Gaal has been a long-time admirer of Schweinsteiger and sees him as a key addition to his squad. The Dutchman has been looking to strengthen his midfield options and believes the German international will bring a level of experience and quality to the team.Schweinsteiger is expected to undergo a medical examination in the coming days and, if all goes smoothly, will be unveiled as a United player next week. The transfer is a significant statement of intent from United, who are looking to challenge for major honors next season.The signing of Schweinsteiger is also likely to be a boost to United's commercial appeal, with the midfielder's global reputation and popularity set to attract new fans and sponsors to the club.

first_sentence: The embattled Republican, cradling a basket of nachos, says to the fan "you're a big shot", their faces inches apart.The drama unfolded during Sunday's Brewers v Cubs game in Milwaukee.Mr Christie has the lowest approval ratings in the history of New Jersey, and stoked anger recently by using a beach closed to the public.The baseball heckler, Brad Joseph, said that after Mr Christie walked past his seat, "I yelled his name and told him that he sucked".
text: "I called him a hypocrite because I thought it needed to be said," he added.Chris Christie has gone from presidential timbre to political punching bag. Such is the tragic fate of the soon-to-be-former New Jersey governor.It wasn't too long ago that Republican power brokers implored Mr Christie to be their white knight, riding into the Republican presidential nomination contest as Mitt Romney's campaign foundered.At the time his in-your-face style seemed refreshingly candid and his popularity in Democratic-leaning New Jersey gave him cross-over national appeal.Then the Bridgegate scandal - the pettiness of the apparent retribution scheme - tarnished his lustre. His idol, Bruce Springsteen, mocked him on late-night television. The media coverage grew more biting.When Mr Christie eventually did try for the White House, Donald Trump had stolen his brash, unscripted thunder.F Scott Fitzgerald once wrote that there are no second acts in American lives. That hardly seems the case these days, even for someone with Mr Christie's reputational scars.He'll always have pugnacious attitude. Now, however, it's less a tool that will help him climb the political ladder than a bit of performance art for the entertainment of sports radio listeners and baseball spectators.Earlier this month Mr Christie was booed by thousands of baseball fans at New York's Citi Field after he caught a foul ball that had landed in the stands.Also this month, he clashed on live radio with one of his constituents whom he accused of being a "communist" and a "bum".With a 15% approval rating, Mr Christie is considered to be one the least popular state governors in American history.Once a contender for the White House, his popularity has plunged after the so-called Bridgegate scandal in which his senior aides were convicted of conspiring to close one of the busiest bridges in the world as political payback against a mayor that refused to endorse Mr Christie.
sample_text: According to eyewitnesses, Christie, still clutching his nachos, leaned in close to Joseph and said, "You're a big shot, huh?"The tense exchange was captured on video by several fans in the surrounding seats, and quickly went viral on social media. Many were shocked by the confrontation, which seemed to embody the divisive and often contentious nature of modern American politics.Joseph, a 31-year-old Cubs fan from Illinois, told reporters that he was simply exercising his right to free speech when he heckled Christie. "I just told him that he sucked, and that's when he came over and started yelling at me," Joseph said. "I was just trying to enjoy the game, and then this happens."Christie, who has been a vocal supporter of the New York Mets, was attending the game as a guest of the Brewers' owner, Mark Attanasio. The former Governor has been a frequent presence at sporting events in recent years, often drawing attention for his enthusiastic cheering and occasional run-ins with fans.The incident is just the latest in a series of controversies to surround Christie, who has faced intense criticism for his handling of various issues during his time in office. In recent weeks, he has faced backlash for using a beach closed to the public during a government shutdown, and for his response to a series of protests and demonstrations in New Jersey.Despite the criticism, Christie remains a prominent figure in Republican politics, and has been mentioned as a potential candidate for various offices in the future. However, incidents like the one on Sunday are likely to continue to fuel concerns about his temperament and ability to connect with ordinary voters.

first_sentence: Wales and Ireland meet in Dublin in their opening game on Sunday, 7 February, with Joe Schmidt's side eyeing a hat-trick of European crowns.
text: "They would like to go in with people writing them off, even though they have won the championship for the last two years," said the Wales coach. "They have to go in as favourites. You write an Irish team off at your peril. "He added: "We go into this tournament respecting them immensely, and particularly what they have achieved under Joe Schmidt over the last two seasons. "I think they are favourites for the tournament, given the experience they have at knowing how to win, particularly under pressure. "Gatland has named only one uncapped player - scrum-half Aled Davies -  in a 37-strong squad for the tournament.Schmidt is scheduled to name his Ireland squad on Wednesday as well as a successor to retired skipper Paul O'Connell.With England and France under new coaches Eddie Jones and Guy Noves respectively, Gatland says the tournament is "a little bit of an unknown quantity".That cannot be said of Wales, who have 31 members of their 2015 World Cup squad in their Six Nations mix.Gatland has also recalled Cardiff Blues wing Tom James and flanker Josh Turnbull, while Clermont Auvergne centre Jonathan Davies is back after recovering from the knee injury which ruled him out of the World Cup.The full-back position is a concern for Wales, with Toulon's Leigh Halfpenny absent with a knee injury and Scarlets player Liam Williams yet to feature after damaging a foot at the World Cup.Gareth Anscombe of Cardiff Blues, plus Matthew Morgan, who plays in English rugby's second-tier at Bristol, are the fit full-back contenders, although both are more used to the fly-half role.Anscombe's return from an ankle problem came last weekend, when was a replacement in the European Challenge Cup defeat at Harlequins.Former Wales centre Tom Shanklin told BBC Radio Wales: "I know Matthew Morgan and Gareth Anscombe can play 15 but, now Leigh Halfpenny's out, Liam Williams is our only main 15 and he's not even fit. There's talk of him playing on 30 January. "British and Irish Lions chief executive John Feehan has said Gatland is the leading contender to take charge again when they tour New Zealand in 2017.Gatland guided the 2013 Lions to a 2-1 series win over Australia and the Welsh Rugby Union would again back Gatland for the Lions role.However, the Wales boss played down the prospect, saying: "I haven't had any conversations with anyone about that. I am only reading things in the media. "If you have a good Six Nations and a good summer tour [to New Zealand], then you are in contention. "That is something I will think about later down the line."
sample_text: Ireland, led by head coach Joe Schmidt, will be looking to make history by claiming a third consecutive European title, a feat that has never been achieved before. The Irish team has been in impressive form of late, with a strong autumn campaign that saw them defeat New Zealand and Argentina, and they will be confident of getting their Six Nations campaign off to a winning start.Wales, meanwhile, will be determined to spoil the party and get their own championship bid off to a flying start. Under the guidance of coach Wayne Pivac, the Welsh team has been quietly building momentum, and they will be looking to cause an upset against their Celtic rivals.The match promises to be a thrilling encounter, with both teams boasting a wealth of talent and experience. Ireland's fly-half Johnny Sexton will be looking to continue his impressive form, while Wales will be relying on the likes of Dan Biggar and Alun Wyn Jones to lead the charge.The atmosphere at the Aviva Stadium is sure to be electric, with a sell-out crowd expected to pack into the Dublin venue. The match will be broadcast live on television, with millions of rugby fans around the world tuning in to see which team will come out on top.In other Six Nations action, England will take on France at the Stade de France in Paris on Sunday, while Scotland will host Italy at Murrayfield in Edinburgh on Saturday. The tournament is shaping up to be one of the most competitive in recent years, and fans are eagerly anticipating the start of the action.
sample_text2: As the teams take to the field, the stakes will be high, with both Ireland and Wales knowing that a win would set them up nicely for the rest of the tournament. The Irish team, buoyed by their recent successes, will be looking to assert their dominance from the outset, while Wales will be seeking to exploit any weaknesses in the Irish armor.One of the key battles will be in the scrum, where Ireland's Tadhg Furlong and Wales' Tomas Francis will go head-to-head. Furlong, widely regarded as one of the best props in the world, will be looking to use his power and technique to gain the upper hand, while Francis will be relying on his experience and guile to counter the Irishman's threat.In the back row, Ireland's CJ Stander and Wales' Josh Navidi will be locked in a fierce battle for supremacy. Stander, a powerhouse of a flanker, will be looking to use his physicality to dominate the breakdown, while Navidi will be seeking to use his speed and agility to outmaneuver the Irishman.Meanwhile, in the backs, Sexton and Biggar will engage in a fascinating duel at fly-half. Sexton, widely regarded as one of the best fly-halves in the world, will be looking to use his vision and distribution to unlock the Welsh defense, while Biggar will be relying on his experience and tactical kicking to pin Ireland back.As the teams prepare to do battle, the atmosphere at the Aviva Stadium is building to a fever pitch. The Irish fans, clad in their green jerseys, will be urging their team on, while the Welsh supporters, resplendent in their red attire, will be doing their best to drown out the home crowd.In the end, it promises to be a thrilling encounter, with both teams giving it their all in pursuit of victory. Will Ireland make history by claiming a third consecutive European title, or will Wales spoil the party and get their own championship bid off to a flying start? One thing is for sure - the rugby world will be watching with bated breath as these two Celtic rivals clash in what promises to be a classic encounter.

first_sentence: Thangam Debbonaire, MP for Bristol West, told the BBC she had not felt intimidated, but other Labour members had told her they felt "scared".One local party member has blogged about how she was left in tears.Momentum member Annie Thomas said there was "excitement" and tension but she did not hear "insults or abuse".Mr Corbyn has faced dozens of resignations from Labour's front bench, as the vast majority of the Parliamentary Labour Party have called on him to quit.
text: But he remains leader, backed by many party members who have held rallies in his defence. He wrote in the Guardian that the party's membership had swelled in recent weeks by 100,000, since the EU Referendum.Labour Party member Ruth Davies blogged about the Bristol West constituency Labour Party's AGM on Thursday evening, at which Ms Debbonaire talked about the EU Referendum and her resignation as shadow minister for arts and culture.Ms Debbonaire quit in June, telling Jeremy Corbyn "it is with sadness that I have concluded that you are not the right person to lead us".Asked about Thursday's two-hour meeting, she told BBC Points West it had been "challenging" as more than 300 people had turned up and they had only been expecting 100 - so there was not enough room. "I did my best to hear as many voices as I could. Many people have contacted me saying despite that, unfortunately, they felt there were some people in the room who were making a lot of noise and were trying to dominate the meeting. ""It was brutal, I think some people found it very difficult. I didn't feel intimidated but then I'm not easily intimidated but other people have said they were scared. People in the back of the room in particular said there was a lot of aggression and they were uncomfortable. "Ms Davies told the BBC she had been called a "traitor" and a "conspirator" when she called for "respectful calm discussion". "As soon as Thangam started to speak about Corbyn, there was a vocal group of people who were shouting her down and heckling throughout," she said. "There seems to be a mentality that if you don't uncritically support Corbyn then you must be the enemy. "But Annie Thomas, a local Momentum member, said the room the meeting was held in was not big enough, a large amount of people had turned up and it had been hot, "so you could feel the tension building" and she said there was some "heckling from both sides".She said she did not see or hear any insults or abuse and did not recognise all the people who had turned up, so could not say whether they were Momentum members.She said the annual meeting had involved contested elections to the local party executive: "Clearly the events of the last few weeks in Parliament have actually coloured those elections because many people have felt very cross. ""However, Momentum does condemn all abusive behaviour, I didn't see any abuse, I saw a lot of excited people who wanted to have their say."
sample_text: However, his opponents argue that he no longer has the support of the majority of Labour MPs.The meeting in Bristol West was one of several hustings events held across the country, where Labour members were given the opportunity to question Mr. Corbyn and his challenger, Owen Smith. The events have been marked by tension and passion, with many Labour members deeply divided over the future of the party.Ms. Debbonaire, a Corbyn supporter, described the atmosphere at the Bristol West meeting as "lively" and "passionate", but denied that it was intimidating. However, other Labour members have reported feeling harassed and bullied by Corbyn supporters.One local party member, who wished to remain anonymous, told the BBC that she had been left in tears after being shouted down by Corbyn supporters. "I felt like I was being attacked for not supporting Jeremy," she said. "It was a really hostile environment."Momentum member Annie Thomas, who was also at the meeting, disputed this account, saying that while there was "excitement" and tension, she did not hear any insults or abuse. "People were passionate about their views, but it was a respectful debate," she said.The divisions within the Labour Party have been laid bare in recent weeks, with many MPs calling for Mr. Corbyn to resign. However, the Labour leader remains defiant, insisting that he has the support of the party membership.The leadership contest is set to continue until September 24, when the result will be announced. In the meantime, Labour members will continue to debate the future of the party, and the direction it should take under Mr. Corbyn's leadership.
sample_text2: As the leadership contest heats up, concerns are growing about the impact of the infighting on the party's chances in the next general election. Labour's poll ratings have taken a hit in recent months, and some MPs fear that the party's divisions will make it difficult to mount a credible challenge to the Conservative government.Meanwhile, Owen Smith, the challenger to Mr. Corbyn's leadership, has been gaining momentum in recent weeks. He has positioned himself as a more centrist alternative to Mr. Corbyn, and has won the support of many Labour MPs who are disillusioned with the party's leftward shift under Mr. Corbyn's leadership.In a speech earlier this week, Mr. Smith accused Mr. Corbyn of being "out of touch" with the concerns of ordinary Labour voters, and promised to take the party in a more moderate direction. "We need a leader who can unite the party and appeal to the wider electorate," he said. "I believe I am that leader."Despite Mr. Smith's gains, however, Mr. Corbyn remains the favorite to win the leadership contest. He has a strong base of support among Labour's grassroots members, who are fiercely loyal to his vision of a more radical, socialist Labour Party.As the contest enters its final weeks, both sides are gearing up for a intense campaign of leafleting, canvassing, and social media activism. Labour members are being bombarded with emails, texts, and phone calls from both camps, urging them to support their candidate.The stakes are high, with the future of the Labour Party hanging in the balance. Whoever emerges victorious will face the daunting task of uniting the party and preparing it for the next general election.In the meantime, Labour members are bracing themselves for a long and grueling campaign. As one member, who wished to remain anonymous, put it: "It's going to be a long and difficult few weeks. But in the end, we'll come out stronger and more united than ever."

first_sentence: Spaniard Rahm, the world number 11, and Im, from the United States, ranked 542, lie 17 under par, one ahead of Benjamin Hebert, with Hideto Tanihara 15 under.Olympic champion Justin Rose remains in contention four shots off the lead.Frenchman Julien Quesne and Scott Hend of Australia made best use of the sun-drenched conditions by equalling the course record with eight-under-par 64s.Quesne carded nine birdies and Hend an eagle and six birdies in a blemish-free round to move into the upper echelons of the leaderboard by matching the best rounds of the tournament so far.Quesne is fifth on 14 under, while Hend is one shot worse off, along with Rose, Oliver Fisher and New Zealander Ryan Fox.Rank outsiders Im and France's Hebert, 254 in the world rankings, were joint leaders after both day one and day two - and the pair remain firmly in contention, long putts for par on the 18th securing rounds of 68 and 69 respectively.Im is aiming to become the first American winner of the Irish Open since Hubert Green triumphed at Portmarnock in 1977.
text: "I played pretty solid and although I picked up a shot at the first, I didn't feel like I made too many birdies compared to the first two days," said Im, who began the week 114th in the Race to Dubai standings. "Two good putts at the last two holes helped me to a 68 - the weather was great, there were lots of people out supporting me and I enjoyed every moment. "Rahm negotiated the first 10 holes of his third round in one under par but four birdies from the 11th to the 14th helped propel him up the leaderboard and a round of 67 as he bids for a first European Tour success. "Staying patient was key to my round as I knew I was playing well, even though the putts were not dropping in the early part of my round," said Rahm, who is hoping to emulate the achievement of compatriots Seve Ballesteros, Jose-Maria Olazabal and Sergio Garcia, who are all past winners of this event. "I just tried to keep hitting the fairways and finding the greens and eventually the putts were going to go in. The energy generated by the crowd means a lot, I just have to try and make some birdies on the front nine. "Im, Hebert, Quesne, Fisher, Fox and Bradley Dredge are among those well placed to land one of three Open places on offer for players who finish in the top 10 and have not already qualified for Royal Birkdale.Three-time major champion Padraig Harrington is best of the Irish contingent after Saturday's action, while 2012 winner Jamie Donaldson was forced to pull out of the final two rounds with a pulled muscle in his back.The tournament forms part of the prestigious new Rolex Series of events, boasting a prize fund of £5.4m, with £585,000 for the winner.
sample_text: Spaniard Jon Rahm, currently ranked 11th in the world, is looking to capitalize on his strong start to the tournament, while American Im, ranked 542nd, is defying the odds to stay in contention.Frenchman Benjamin Hebert, ranked 254th, is also refusing to give up, and his consistent play has seen him remain in the top three alongside Rahm and Im. Japan's Hideto Tanihara is lurking just behind, four shots off the lead, and will be looking to make a move in the final two rounds.Meanwhile, Olympic champion Justin Rose is quietly going about his business, four shots off the lead and well-placed to make a charge. The Englishman has been in fine form of late, and his experience and skill will make him a formidable opponent in the final rounds.The course record-equalling rounds of 64 from Frenchman Julien Quesne and Australia's Scott Hend have propelled them up the leaderboard, and they will be looking to build on their momentum in the final two rounds. Quesne's nine birdies and Hend's eagle and six birdies were a testament to their skill and adaptability in the sun-drenched conditions.As the tournament reaches its climax, the crowd will be eagerly anticipating a thrilling finale. Will Rahm and Im be able to hold off the challenges of Hebert, Tanihara, and Rose, or will one of the outsiders cause a major upset? One thing is certain - the Irish Open is shaping up to be a tournament to remember.
sample_text2: As the players take to the course for the third round, the atmosphere is electric. The Irish crowd is renowned for their passion and knowledge of the game, and they are eager to see which of the contenders will emerge victorious.Rahm, the pre-tournament favorite, is looking to build on his impressive start. The Spaniard has been in scintillating form of late, and his powerful driving and pinpoint iron play have him well-placed to take the title. However, he knows that he cannot afford to take his foot off the gas, with Im and Hebert breathing down his neck.Im, the American underdog, is relishing the opportunity to cause a major upset. Despite his lowly ranking, he has shown remarkable composure and skill throughout the tournament, and his consistent play has earned him a spot in the final group. Can he maintain his form and pull off one of the biggest shocks in Irish Open history?Hebert, the Frenchman, is quietly confident of his chances. His consistent play has seen him remain in the top three, and he knows that he has the game to take on the best. With his accurate driving and clever course management, he is well-equipped to handle the challenges of the course.Tanihara, the Japanese player, is lurking just behind the leaders, waiting for his chance to strike. His experience and skill will make him a formidable opponent in the final rounds, and he is well-placed to take advantage of any slip-ups from the leaders.Rose, the Olympic champion, is biding his time, waiting for the perfect moment to make his move. His experience and skill will make him a major threat in the final rounds, and he is confident of his ability to overcome the deficit and take the title.As the players tee off, the tension is palpable. The crowd is on the edge of their seats, eager to see which of the contenders will emerge victorious. Will it be Rahm, the pre-tournament favorite, or one of the outsiders who will cause a major upset? One thing is certain - the Irish Open is shaping up to be a tournament for the ages.

first_sentence: A disturbance was reported at Welwyn Road, Hinckley at about 21:30 GMT on Tuesday.Detectives believe the deceased to be David Stokes, 43, and his sons Adam, 11, and Matthew, aged five.An injured woman, who left the house in the early hours and is being treated in hospital, has been locally identified as 44-year-old Sally Stokes.Trained police negotiators were deployed to the house following concerned calls from neighbours.After Mrs Stokes left and was being given first aid, officers searched the house and found the bodies of a man and two children.The causes of death are not yet known but detectives are not looking for anyone else in connection with the incident.One neighbour, who did not wish to be named, said: "They were very nice people.
text: "Det Ch Supt David Sandall of Leicestershire Police said trained negotiators spoke to the man and woman at the address for several hours.He said: "In the early hours of this morning the officers gained access to the property following a female who left the address with injuries. "Officers provided first aid to the female, she remains in a stable condition in the hospital. "At that time, [other] officers entered the address, they found a male who was pronounced dead within the address. "Tragically, and very traumatically, the officers on searching the address have also found two deceased children. "I'm appealing to anybody who knows any information about what occurred last night in the address or anybody who canâ€¦ tell us about what happened within this family leading to these tragic circumstances. "At the scene - Jeremy Ball for East Midlands TodayIt has hit people really hard here [in Welwyn Road]. Just after we arrived we saw one woman on the street in tears.The question is why did these three people lose their lives?We still don't know how they died, or what their injuries were. We won't know until we get the results of a post-mortem examination.Arrangements have been made for a candlelit vigil in Hinckley tomorrow afternoon.The two boys attended St Mary's CE primary school, and the head teacher, Rachel Ayres, said: "Everyone is devastated by the tragic news about our pupils, Adam and Matthew, and our sincere sympathies are with their family and friends. "She said special assemblies will be held to support the children at the school.As officers had been in contact with both the man and the woman during the evening, Leicestershire Police has informed the Independent Police Complaints Commission.
sample_text: I would see them walking their dog and they would always say hello. It's just devastating to think that something like this could happen to them."Another neighbor, who lived nearby, described the family as "quiet and private" but said they seemed "happy and content"."I would see the kids playing in the garden and they always looked like they were having fun," she said. "It's just heartbreaking to think that they're gone."Detective Superintendent David Sandall, who is leading the investigation, said: "This is a tragic incident and our thoughts are with the family and friends of those involved. We are working to establish the circumstances surrounding the deaths and are supporting the injured woman and her loved ones."He added: "I would like to reassure the local community that we are not looking for anyone else in connection with this incident and there is no risk to the wider public."The police have cordoned off the area and forensic teams are currently examining the scene. A post-mortem examination is due to take place in the coming days to determine the cause of death.The incident has sent shockwaves through the community, with many residents expressing their condolences on social media.Hinckley Borough Council has also released a statement, saying: "We are deeply saddened to hear of the tragic incident on Welwyn Road. Our thoughts are with the family and friends of those affected and we will do everything we can to support the community during this difficult time."The investigation is ongoing and anyone with information is urged to contact Leicestershire Police.
