first_sentence: Lawyers said Chris Gard and Connie Yates want to spend the "maximum amount of time they have left with Charlie".The couple ended the case after a US doctor told them it was now too late to treat Charlie's rare genetic condition.Great Ormond Street Hospital (GOSH) has not said when life support will end.However, Mr Gard and Ms Yates, from Bedfont, west London, said Charlie would not reach his first birthday on 4 August.In its statement to the High Court, the hospital said it was "increasingly surprised and disappointed" the US doctor, Professor Michio Hirano, "had not read Charlie's contemporaneous medical records or viewed Charlie's brain imaging or read all of the second opinions about Charlie's condition".GOSH said Professor Hirano had not taken the opportunity to see Charlie until last week, despite being offered the chance to do so by the hospital in January.Even though the professor gave written evidence at all the court cases, the hospital said it only emerged last week that he had not read the judge's ruling following the first High Court hearing in April.The hospital added it was concerned to hear the professor state in the witness box at the High Court hearing on 13 July that he had a financial interest in some of the treatment he proposed prescribing for Charlie.Charlie has encephalomyopathic mitochondrial DNA depletion syndrome.
text: He has brain damage and cannot move his arms or legs.His parents had asked Mr Justice Francis to rule that their son should be allowed to undergo a trial of nucleoside therapy in New York, a move opposed by London's Great Ormond Street Hospital, which argued it would be "futile".The Family Division of the High Court heard on Monday that US neurologist Dr Michio Hirano was no longer willing to offer the experimental therapy after he had seen the results of a new MRI scan last week.Speaking outside court, Mr Gard said: "We are now going to spend our last precious moments with our son Charlie, who unfortunately won't make his first birthday in just under two weeks' time. "Mummy and Daddy love you so much Charlie, we always have and we always will and we are so sorry that we couldn't save you. "Mr Justice Francis said he hoped lessons could be learned from the "tragic" case.He has suggested that parents and hospital bosses who disagree over life-or-death treatment for children should be forced to mediate in a bid to avoid litigation. "I recognise, of course, that negotiating issues such as the life or death of a child seems impossible and often will be," he said. "However, it is my clear view that mediation should be attempted in all cases such as this one, even if all that it does is achieve a greater understanding by the parties of each other's positions. "Mr Gard's and Ms Yates's five-month legal battle started after doctors at Great Ormond Street had said the therapy would not help and that life-support treatment should stop.They subsequently failed to overturn rulings in the High Court, Court of Appeal and Supreme Court in London, and also failed to persuade judges at the European Court of Human Rights to intervene.The couple made the "most painful of decisions" on Monday after reviewing new scan results which showed Charlie had deteriorated to the "point of no return".In a statement, Great Ormond Street said: "The agony, desolation and bravery of their decision command GOSH's utmost respect and humble all who work there. "Mr Gard and Ms Yates hope to establish a foundation to ensure Charlie's voice "continues to be heard".They had raised more than Â£1.3m for the treatment in the US.Timeline of legal battle
sample_text: The hospital expressed concern that this lack of disclosure could have influenced the court's decision-making process.In response to the hospital's statement, a spokesperson for the Gard family said that they were "deeply saddened" by the hospital's comments and felt that they were "unfair and misleading". The spokesperson added that the family had always acted in Charlie's best interests and had been guided by the advice of medical professionals.The case has sparked a heated debate about the rights of parents to make decisions about their child's medical treatment, and the role of the courts in intervening in such cases. Many have expressed sympathy for the Gard family, who have fought tirelessly to secure treatment for their son.Meanwhile, the Pope and the President of the United States, Donald Trump, have both weighed in on the case, offering support to the Gard family. The Vatican has also offered to provide Charlie with a place at a hospital in Rome, should the family wish to pursue treatment there.As the situation continues to unfold, the world remains gripped by the tragic story of Charlie Gard and his family. The decision to end life support will undoubtedly be a difficult one, and the thoughts of many are with the Gard family as they prepare to say goodbye to their beloved son.In a statement, the Gard family said: "We are now going to spend our last precious moments with our son Charlie, who unfortunately will not reach his first birthday. We would like to thank everyone for their support, and we will always be grateful for the time we had with our beautiful boy."The case has raised important questions about the role of the state in making decisions about a child's medical treatment, and the rights of parents to make choices about their child's care. As the world says goodbye to Charlie Gard, it is clear that his story will have a lasting impact on the medical and legal communities.
sample_text2: As the news of Charlie's impending passing spread, tributes and condolences poured in from around the world. The hashtag #CharliesArmy trended on social media, with thousands of people sharing messages of support and solidarity with the Gard family.In a rare move, the British Prime Minister, Theresa May, issued a statement expressing her sympathy for the family and acknowledging the "agonizing" decision they had been forced to make. "My thoughts are with Charlie's parents, Chris and Connie, and their family at this incredibly difficult time," she said.The case has also sparked a wider debate about the ethics of medical treatment and the role of the state in making decisions about a child's care. Many have questioned whether the courts should have the power to override the wishes of parents in such cases, and whether the interests of the child are always best served by the medical profession.Dr. Sarah Wollaston, a British MP and former GP, said that the case had highlighted the need for greater clarity around the decision-making process in such cases. "This is a tragic case that has raised important questions about the role of the state in making decisions about a child's medical treatment," she said. "We need to have a more open and honest conversation about the ethical dilemmas that arise in these situations."As the Gard family prepares to say goodbye to their son, they have also announced plans to establish a charity in Charlie's name, which will aim to provide support and resources to families facing similar challenges.In a statement, the family said: "We want to ensure that Charlie's legacy lives on, and that his story helps to make a difference to other families who may be facing similar struggles. We will continue to fight for the rights of parents to make decisions about their child's care, and to ensure that the voices of families are heard in the medical and legal communities."As the world says goodbye to Charlie Gard, his story will undoubtedly have a lasting impact on the medical and legal communities. His bravery and spirit have inspired countless people around the world, and his legacy will continue to inspire and motivate others to fight for the rights of families and children everywhere.

first_sentence: Species such as the Australian tree fern are using up vital water supplies within native forests on Hawaii, home to unique species found nowhere else.So far, more than 5,000 people have visited the website.To date, each pixel of the images of the forest has been scrutinised by web users at least 50 times.
text: "From a biodiversity viewpoint, it is very important that we protect forest resources," explained Trea Menard, director of forest conservation for the US-based The Nature Conservancy (TNC). "Unfortunately, we have lost a lot of our forests," he told BBC News. "For example, only about 27% of the forest remains on Kauai and that is an important forest because it is the biodiversity cradle for Hawaii as it is the oldest island. "The native forest is extremely unique. About 90% of the plants and animals that evolved here do not occur anywhere else in the world, which means they are endemic to Hawaii. "If they are lost from Hawaii, they are pretty much lost to the planet. "The invasive plants are dramatically reducing the volume of fresh water available for native species.The Australian tree fern is able to penetrate remote areas of the native forest because it is dispersed via spores carried by the wind, making it difficult to be tracked and located on the ground.In order to overcome this obstacle, TNC has teamed up with satellite imaging firm DigitalGlobe to call on web users to scan and spot the invasive species in images posted on the web.The images, provided by Resources Mapping, are aerial photos providing 1cm per pixel.Luke Barrington, senior manager for DigitalGlobe's crowdsourcing platform, said the high-quality, natural colour images had enabled web users to identify the invasive species.He explained: "The connectivity of billions of people online is transforming  the way that the globe solves global problems. Millions of people are coming together to solve a problem. "The campaign has been running since June and each pixel of the images available has been accessed by at least 50 users, providing a built-in level of quality control.
sample_text: The project, launched by the University of Hawaii's College of Tropical Agriculture and Human Resources, has enlisted the help of thousands of volunteers to comb through high-resolution images of Hawaii's forests, identifying areas where invasive species such as the Australian tree fern are outcompeting native plants for limited water resources.According to Dr. Maria Stewart, lead researcher on the project, "The response has been overwhelming. We've been blown away by the enthusiasm and dedication of our volunteers, who have collectively spent thousands of hours scrutinizing these images and helping us to better understand the extent of the problem."The Australian tree fern, a non-native species introduced to Hawaii as an ornamental plant, has been identified as a major culprit in the depletion of Hawaii's native forests. By outcompeting native plants for water, the fern is not only altering the ecosystem but also exacerbating the effects of drought and climate change.The data collected through the project will be used to inform conservation efforts and develop targeted strategies for controlling the spread of invasive species. "This project is a game-changer for conservation in Hawaii," said Dr. Stewart. "By engaging the public in this way, we're not only gathering valuable data but also raising awareness about the importance of protecting our unique and fragile ecosystems."As the project continues to gain momentum, researchers are hopeful that it will serve as a model for similar initiatives around the world. With the help of citizen scientists, they believe that it may be possible to make a meaningful impact on the conservation of native ecosystems and the protection of biodiversity.

first_sentence: Mark Millar, who failed to score in two years as a Dundee United player, took great pleasure in firing in one against his former club.However, Van der Velden's composure and ability saw him flick the ball over two defenders in the penalty area before a controlled shot levelled the game.United should have gone on to win it, but could not find a winner.New Tannadice team manager Ray McKinnon warned his team that every point in the lower league would have to be earned, but there was a surprising lack of intensity or urgency about Dundee United's play during an opening period where they rarely troubled the visitors goal.Queen's goalkeeper Lee Robinson hardly had a save to make in that flat first 45 minutes apart from a header from Mark Durnan that was aimed straight at him from a Van der Velden's free kick.The Dutch midfielder kept drifting into intelligent areas to pick up possession, but the link-up from middle to front was poor despite the pace of Cammy Smith and Tope Obedayi down the flanks.Queen's looked more composed going forward with Lyndon Dykes causing problems breaking from left midfield and it was no surprise when he was key in breaking the deadlock.The Aussie made space for a shot that goalkeeper Cammy Bell could only parry, and when the ball was worked back to Millar he swept a shot into the net from 12 yards.It took that outrageous bit of skill from Van der Velden to really spark McKinnon's side into life as he flicked the ball over two opponents in a tight space before guiding a shot beyond Robinson.Former Rangers goalkeeper Bell became much busier after that equaliser and proved just how sharp his reflexes are with two crucial saves as the defenders in front of him struggled to cope with the dramatically increased threat.Experienced right back Jamie Hamill in particular found it tough to deal with the pace of Tope Obedayi and in 65 minutes the former Kilmarnock striker's shot was tipped on to the post by Robinson.Then within seconds Aberdeen's on loan striker Smith made space for a shot from the edge of the area and was only denied a goal by an impressive full stretch save by the goalkeeper.Smith than missed an easier chance; deflecting Van der Velden's near post cross wide of the target while Queen of the South's only real chance of a winner fell to a returning hero.Stephen Dobbie scored 54 times in 103 games in his first spell at Palmerston and it took a Bell block to prevent the former Bolton striker marking his short appearance as substitute with a goal.Match ends, Dundee United 1, Queen of sample_text: Despite dominating possession, the Tannadice side struggled to create clear-cut chances, and it took a moment of individual brilliance from midfielder Willem van der Velden to level the score."We didn't do enough to win the game," McKinnon said in his post-match interview. "We had a lot of possession, but we didn't create enough chances. We didn't have the intensity and urgency that we needed to win the game."The visitors, Queen of the South, took the lead in the 35th minute through Mark Millar, who scored against his former club. The goal was a result of some poor defending from Dundee United, and it seemed to spark the home team into life.Van der Velden's equalizer in the 55th minute was a highlight of the match, as he flicked the ball over two defenders before calmly slotting the ball past the goalkeeper. The goal seemed to give Dundee United a boost, and they began to create more chances.However, despite their dominance, they were unable to find a winner. Cammy Smith and Tope Obadeyi both had chances, but were denied by some excellent goalkeeping from Lee Robinson.At the other end, Dundee United goalkeeper Cammy Bell was also called into action, making some crucial saves to prevent Queen of the South from taking the lead again.In the end, the match ended 1-1, a result that left both teams feeling frustrated. Dundee United will be disappointed not to have taken all three points, while Queen of the South will feel that they could have won the game if they had taken their chances.The draw leaves Dundee United in 5th place in the Scottish Championship, while Queen of the South remain in 7th place. Both teams will be looking to improve their form in their next matches, with Dundee United facing a tough trip to Falkirk and Queen of the South hosting Ayr United.In other news, Stephen Dobbie, who made a substitute appearance for Queen of the South, was denied a goal by a brilliant block from Cammy Bell. The former Bolton striker was making his return to Palmerston, where he scored 54 times in 103 games during his first spell with the club.The match also saw Jamie Hamill, Queen of the South's right-back, receive a yellow card for a bad foul on Tope Obadeyi. The incident sparked some controversy, with Dundee United players and fans feeling that Hamill should have been given a red card.

first_sentence: Northern Ireland's world number four, 28, parted ways with Fitzgerald on Monday, ending a nine-year partnership.In that time, McIlroy had four major wins, but he is without one since 2014.
text: "JP has been a huge part of my life for the past decade, but I was getting very hard on him at times," McIlroy said. "You don't want to be like that with anyone but sometimes this game drives you to it. "I would say he is still one of my closest friends. We started together in 2008, we've had a lot of great times on and off the golf course. "There's nothing to say JP won't work with me again at some point, but I felt like it was the right thing to do. It was a really tough decision. "I hate the term fired or axed, it definitely wasn't what it was. I changed my path a little bit but it was just a build-up of stuff, I felt I needed to make that change. "The move came a week after McIlroy praised Fitzgerald at the Open at Royal Birkdale, saying the caddie had delivered some blunt words after the Holywood player started the tournament with a string of bogeys.After fighting back to shoot a one-over 71 in the first round, McIlroy told reporters Fitzgerald had done a "great job" by giving him a "good talking to".McIlroy has decided to use Harry Diamond, a friend since childhood, at the Bridgestone Invitational at Firestone in Akron, Ohio and at next week's major, the PGA Championship in Charlotte.But he has not made a long-term decision about who to use after that. "I just needed someone that knew me and that's why I took Harry for the next couple of weeks," he said. "If something doesn't work out and Harry and I say two weeks is enough I'll need to find someone else but I've got 10 days between the end of the PGA and the start of the Northern Trust to do that."
sample_text: McIlroy, who has been struggling to regain his form in recent years, had been working with Fitzgerald since 2008. During their partnership, the Northern Irish golfer won four major championships, including two PGA Championships and one Open Championship.However, McIlroy's last major win came at the 2014 PGA Championship, and he has since failed to replicate that level of success. Despite his consistent top-10 finishes, the 28-year-old has been unable to break through and claim another major title.Fitzgerald, who has been credited with helping McIlroy develop his game and overcome various challenges, will be replaced by McIlroy's best friend and former amateur teammate, Harry Diamond. Diamond, who has no professional coaching experience, will take on the role of McIlroy's caddie, sparking concerns about the golfer's decision-making process.McIlroy's management team has released a statement confirming the split, saying that the golfer is "looking forward to a new chapter" in his career. However, the sudden nature of the decision has raised eyebrows, with many wondering if there is more to the story than meets the eye.The news has also sparked a heated debate among golf fans and pundits, with some praising McIlroy's bold move and others criticizing his decision to part ways with a coach who had been instrumental in his success.As McIlroy prepares to tee off at the upcoming PGA Tour event, all eyes will be on him to see how he adapts to his new caddie and whether he can finally break his major drought. One thing is certain, however - the golfing world will be watching with bated breath as one of its biggest stars navigates this significant change in his career.

first_sentence: Fe ddywed Sally Holland bod rhai ysgolion yn gyndyn o fynd i'r afael â'r mater oherwydd pryder y bydd yr ysgol yn cael enw drwg.Mae adroddiad newydd ganddi yn dweud bod diffyg cysondeb yn y modd y mae cwynion o fwlio'n cael eu trin, gan adael rhai plant yn teimlo wedi'u hynysu.Dywedodd Llywodraeth Cymru y dylid taclo bob ffurf ar fwlio yr un mor gadarn, ac mae'n gyfrifoldeb cyfreithiol i gael polisi bwlio mewn lle ymhob ysgol.Ond mewn rhai achosion, yn ôl Ms Holland, mae'r canllawiau gwrth-fwlio yn eistedd ar silffoedd ysgolion ac mae'n ymddangos nad ydyn nhw wedi cael eu darllen.Dywedodd: "Rwyf am weld canllawiau sy'n wirioneddol ddefnyddiol, sy'n adeiladu ar brofiadau plant gan roi atebion iddyn nhw, ond sydd hefyd yn dweud wrth ysgolion sut i fonitro bwlio ac i beidio â bod ofn monitro chwaith.
text: "Roedd rhai pobl broffesiynol yn dweud wrthym fod yna amharodrwydd i gofnodi bwlio - eu bod yn amharod i roi enw drwg i'r ysgol am fod yna rhyw fath o dabl cynghrair neu rywbeth tebyg. Wrth gwrs dydw i ddim am weld hynny. "Dwi am i ysgolion gan sgwrs onest gyda'u disgyblion a'r gymuned o'i chwmpas am sut y maen nhw'n taclo bwlio yn yr ysgol a beth maen nhw'n am ei wneud am y peth. "Mae ei hadroddiad - 'Sam's Story' - wedi cael ei lunio ar ôl clywed tystiolaeth gan 2,000 o blant a 300 o bobl broffesiynol yn y maes.Mae'n pwysleisio bod yr un pryderon - beth yn union yw bwlio a'r diffyg cofnodi cyson - wedi cael eu codi tair blynedd yn ôl gan y corff goruchwylio addysg, Estyn.Dyw'r pryderon hynny ddim wedi cael eu datrys, ac roedd y Comisiynydd Plant yn gweld hynny'n rhwystredig.Ychwanegodd Ms Holland: "Mae rhai pethau wedi newid, ond mae yna bethau sylfaenol sydd dal angen eu cael yn iawn ac wrth gwrs mae'n rhwystredig, ac yn rhwystredig i blant hefyd. "Rhaid i ni fod yn cofnodi bwlio a sicrhau bod yr ymarfer gorau ar gael i ysgolion - ry'n ni'n gwybod ei fod ar gael. "Dylai pawb gymryd perchnogaeth o'r mater a dylai pawb fod yn rhan o'i daclo. Rhaid i ni beidio ei gadw mewn cornel dywyll fel elfen o embaras mewn bywyd ysgol. "Gadewch i ni dderbyn ei fod yn digwydd a symud ymlaen yn bositif i'w daclo. "Yn eu hymatebion i'r adroddiad fe ddywedodd plant fod materion fel hil, tlodi, anabledd a rhywioldeb i gyd yn destunau bwlio, gan ddweud bod rhieni yn aml naill ai ddim yn ymateb neu yn aneffeithiol.Mae Ms Holland nawr yn galw ar Lywodraeth Cymru i osod cyfrifoldeb statudol ar ysgolion i gofnodi pob digwyddiad o bob math o fwlio, a chyhoeddi diffiniad terfynol o fwlio.Dywedodd Llywodraeth Cymru: "Fe fyddwn ni'n ystyried adroddiad y Comisiynydd Plant a'i fwydo i mewn i'n hadolygiad o ganllawiau gwrth-fwlio. "Dydyn ni ddim yn diodde' unrhyw fath o fwlio yn system addysg Cymru. Ry'n ni'n disgwyl i ysgolion a gwasanaethau addysg ei gwneud hi'n glir fod pob ffurf o fwlio yn annerbyniol ac i daclo bob digwyddiad yn gadarn. "Dylai pob ysgol yng Nghymru, yn ôl y gyfraith, gael polisi ymddygiad ysgol. Fe ddylai strategaethau i daclo bwlio fod yn ganolog i'r polisi yma ac fe ddylai gael ei weithredu gan bawb yn yr ysgol."
sample_text: The report highlights a lack of consistency in how bullying complaints are handled, leaving some children feeling isolated and unsupported.According to Ms. Holland, the Welsh Government should tackle all forms of bullying with equal vigor, and it is a legal responsibility for schools to have anti-bullying policies in place. However, in some cases, the guidelines are gathering dust on school shelves, with little evidence of them being read or implemented."I want to see guidelines that are genuinely useful, that build on children's experiences and provide them with answers, but also tell schools how to monitor bullying and not be afraid of monitoring it," Ms. Holland said.The report's findings are based on a survey of over 1,000 children and young people, which revealed that nearly half had experienced bullying in the past year. The most common forms of bullying were verbal abuse, social exclusion, and online harassment.Ms. Holland is calling for a more proactive approach to tackling bullying, including better training for teachers and support staff, as well as more effective reporting mechanisms. She also wants to see schools working more closely with parents and the wider community to create a culture of zero tolerance towards bullying.The Welsh Government has responded to the report, saying that it takes the issue of bullying "very seriously" and is committed to providing schools with the necessary resources and support to tackle the problem.However, opposition parties have criticized the government's response, saying that more needs to be done to address the root causes of bullying and to provide adequate support to victims.The report's findings have sparked a wider debate about the need for a more comprehensive approach to tackling bullying in Wales, with many calling for a national anti-bullying strategy to be developed.In the meantime, Ms. Holland is urging schools to take immediate action to address the issue, saying that "every child has the right to feel safe and supported in school."
sample_text2: The report's findings have sparked a wave of concern among parents, educators, and policymakers, with many calling for swift action to address the issue. According to Ms. Holland, the lack of consistency in handling bullying complaints is not only damaging to the children involved but also undermines the entire education system."When children are bullied, they are more likely to miss school, underperform academically, and experience long-term mental health problems," Ms. Holland said. "It's not just a matter of personal well-being; it's also a matter of social justice. Every child deserves an education free from fear and intimidation."The report's recommendations include the development of a national anti-bullying strategy, which would provide a framework for schools to tackle bullying in a comprehensive and consistent manner. The strategy would also involve training for teachers and support staff, as well as resources for parents and the wider community.Opposition parties have seized on the report's findings, accusing the Welsh Government of being slow to respond to the issue. "The government's response to this report is woefully inadequate," said Conservative education spokesperson, Darren Millar. "We need to see concrete action, not just warm words. The government must take responsibility for ensuring that our schools are safe and supportive environments for all children."Plaid Cymru's education spokesperson, Sian Gwenllian, echoed Millar's sentiments, saying that the report's findings were "deeply concerning" and that the government needed to do more to address the root causes of bullying.Meanwhile, the Welsh Government has defended its record on tackling bullying, pointing to initiatives such as the "Respect and Empathy" program, which aims to promote positive relationships and behaviors among children.However, critics argue that such initiatives are piecemeal and lack the coherence and resources needed to make a meaningful impact. "We need a comprehensive approach that addresses the whole school environment, not just a few token initiatives," said Ms. Holland.As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the issue of bullying in Welsh schools is a pressing concern that requires immediate attention and action. With the report's findings sparking a national conversation, it remains to be seen whether the Welsh Government will take the necessary steps to ensure that every child feels safe and supported in school.

first_sentence: Dominique Heaggan-Brown shot and killed Sylville Smith, 23, on 13 August 2016 after he fled from police.
text: The death sparked two days of riots in Milwaukee.Prosecutors decided to charge him after police body camera footage allegedly showed the officer shooting Smith in the chest as he lay on the ground.Smith was armed with a pistol, but threw it over a fence before his death.Both the victim and the former police officer are African-American.Mr Heaggan-Brown, 24, has already been fired from the police force due to an unrelated investigation accusing him of sexual assault.According to the criminal complaint, the body camera video shows Smith fall to his back after being shot by the officers who had pursued him on foot after he fled from a traffic stop.Mr Heaggan-Brown's first bullet hit Smith in the right arm, as he was turning "his head and upper body towards the officers", while still holding the semi-automatic pistol. "He then raises the gun upward while looking in the direction of the officers and throws the gun over the fence into the yard," the complaint reads.After Smith was hit, a police body camera shows him fall to his back, with his arms extended upwards towards his head. "Heaggan-Brown is observed standing a short distance from Smith with his weapon pointed down at Smith when Heaggan-Brown discharges a second shot from his weapon at what appears to be Smith's chest. "A review of the body camera video "confirms that at the time of the second shot, Smith was unarmed and had his hands near his head".According to investigators, 1.69 seconds elapsed between the first and second shots.Police chief Ed Flynn had fired Mr Heaggan-Brown from the police force in October after he was charged with sexual assault in an unrelated case.Prosecutors say that Mr Heaggan-Brown went to a bar with another man on the night of 14 August - one day after the shooting - where they drank and watched the riots on TV.The man told authorities that the former Milwaukee officer bragged that he could do whatever he wanted without repercussions, and that he later woke up to the officer sexually assaulting him.He has also been charged with soliciting sex from two people, as well as sexually assaulting another person in July 2016 and photographing the naked victim.If found guilty of reckless homicide he could face 60 years in prison.
sample_text: The incident sparked widespread protests and unrest in the city, with many calling for justice and accountability for the young man's death.According to police reports, Heaggan-Brown, who was 24 at the time, stopped Smith's vehicle after noticing that it was driving erratically. When Smith fled the scene on foot, Heaggan-Brown and another officer gave chase. During the pursuit, Heaggan-Brown shot Smith in the arm and back, killing him.The shooting was captured on body camera footage, which showed that Smith was unarmed and had thrown his gun away before being shot. The footage was later released to the public, sparking outrage and demands for Heaggan-Brown's arrest and prosecution.In December 2016, Heaggan-Brown was charged with first-degree reckless homicide in connection with Smith's death. The case drew national attention, with many seeing it as another example of police brutality and racial injustice.In June 2017, Heaggan-Brown's trial began, with prosecutors arguing that the officer had acted recklessly and unnecessarily in shooting Smith. The defense, on the other hand, claimed that Heaggan-Brown had acted in self-defense, fearing for his life when Smith reached for his waistband.After deliberating for several hours, the jury delivered a verdict that shocked many: not guilty. Heaggan-Brown was acquitted of all charges, sparking widespread outrage and protests in Milwaukee and beyond.The acquittal was seen by many as a miscarriage of justice, and it sparked renewed calls for police reform and accountability. The case remains a controversial and painful reminder of the ongoing struggles with racial tension and police violence in the United States.
sample_text2: In the aftermath of the acquittal, protests erupted in Milwaukee, with demonstrators blocking streets and chanting slogans such as "Justice for Sylville" and "Black Lives Matter." The protests were largely peaceful, but some incidents of vandalism and property damage were reported.Community leaders and activists expressed outrage and disappointment at the verdict, saying that it sent a message that police officers could act with impunity and that black lives were not valued. "This verdict is a slap in the face to the Smith family and to the entire community," said Milwaukee NAACP President Fred Royal. "It's a clear example of the systemic racism that plagues our justice system."The Smith family, who had been seeking justice for their son's death, was devastated by the verdict. "I'm heartbroken, I'm angry, I'm disappointed," said Sylville's mother, Mildred Haynes. "I thought that justice would be served, but I guess I was wrong."The acquittal also sparked a national conversation about police accountability and racial bias in the criminal justice system. Many civil rights organizations and advocacy groups, including the ACLU and the NAACP, issued statements condemning the verdict and calling for reforms to prevent similar incidents in the future.In the months that followed, the city of Milwaukee implemented several reforms aimed at increasing police accountability and transparency. These included the creation of a civilian oversight board to review police conduct and the implementation of de-escalation training for officers.However, the acquittal of Heaggan-Brown also had a profound impact on the community, leading to a breakdown in trust between law enforcement and the people they serve. Many residents of Milwaukee's predominantly African American neighborhoods reported feeling fearful and mistrustful of the police, and some said they were reluctant to call 911 even in emergency situations.The case also had a personal impact on Heaggan-Brown, who was fired from the police department shortly after the acquittal. He has since struggled to find employment and has become a symbol of the controversy surrounding police violence and racial injustice.In the end, the shooting of Sylville Smith and the acquittal of Dominique Heaggan-Brown served as a painful reminder of the deep-seated issues that plague our society. It highlighted the need for greater accountability and transparency in law enforcement, as well as the importance of addressing the systemic racism that perpetuates inequality and injustice. As the nation continues to grapple with these issues, the memory of Sylville Smith and the controversy surrounding his death will serve as a powerful catalyst for change.

first_sentence: At least 12 Tories are backing a Labour motion opposing any rise in VAT charged on solar panels, wind turbines, draught installation and energy-saving devices.The current 5% rate paid by benefit claimants over 60 was ruled illegal by the European Court of Justice in June.It is one of several tax rows in the spotlight ahead of the EU referendum.In the wake of Wednesday's Budget, UK officials said EU leaders had agreed a deal to allow the UK to scrap the so-called "tampon tax", the 5% VAT rate on women's sanitary products which campaigners have long wanted to reduce to zero.The European Commission is set to publish proposals next week on giving member states more flexibility over VAT rates.Eurosceptics have long been critical of rules in force since the early 1990s harmonising VAT rates across the EU, arguing they undermine national sovereignty and the right of member states to set their own tax rates.The UK and other EU members cannot levy sales tax at less than the standard 15% rate except on specified items.
text: For these approved products and services, countries have the scope to charge VAT at a reduced rate of no less than 5%.The UK has long applied a 5% rate to the installation of domestic energy-saving products for anyone over the age of 60 who is unemployed, disabled or claiming benefits such as income support or housing benefit.But last year, the European Court of Justice said this was a breach of EU laws as the products and services concerned did not fall within the VAT directive which only exempts the "provision, construction, renovation and alteration of housing as part of social policy" and the "renovation and repairing of private dwellings".The UK has yet to decide how to respond to the ruling although it face financial penalties if it does not abide by the judgement.Labour says VAT could rise to at least 15% as early as August unless the chancellor takes immediate action.The opposition, which has been critical of cuts to solar and renewable subsidies, has tabled an amendment to the Finance Bill "empowering" George Osborne to set a zero rates on insulation and renewable materials or, alternatively, to compensate the industry for the financial impact that any VAT rise would have on jobs and investment.Labour's shadow energy and climate change secretary Lisa Nandy said the "solar tax" will "destroy thousands of jobs". "Reversing it is well within the chancellor's power. He must act to protect this important British industry. "Labour's amendment, expected to come to a vote on Tuesday, has won the support of a dozen Tories who are unhappy about EU control over UK tax rates and seeking to highlight the issue in the run-up to June's EU referendum.Those backing it include former ministers Tim Loughton and Peter Lilley and Graham Brady, chair of the influential 1922 committee of backbench Conservatives - all of whom want the UK to leave the EU.Paul Scully, the MP for Sutton and Cheam who is backing EU exit, told the BBC's Daily Politics the situation was "absolutely outrageous" and he was "seriously considering" voting with Labour. "At the end of the day this should be a UK-made decision," he said. "You have a situation where we can look at a sugar tax, where we penalising people for doing something the government does not believe is right, but we can't reward the government for doing something we think is the right thing to do. "If the SNP and the Lib Dems also support the amendment, the government could be at risk of defeat as it only has a working majority of 17 in the House of Commons.
sample_text: The motion has gained cross-party support, with at least 12 Conservative MPs signing on, in addition to Labour and Liberal Democrat MPs.The issue has sparked a wider debate about the UK's relationship with the EU and the level of control that member states have over their own tax policies. Eurosceptics argue that the EU's VAT rules are an example of Brussels' overreach and that the UK should be able to set its own tax rates without interference from the EU.However, supporters of the EU argue that the harmonization of VAT rates helps to create a level playing field across the single market and prevents member states from engaging in unfair tax competition.The row over VAT rates comes as the UK prepares to vote on its membership in the EU in June. However, it remains to be seen whether the proposal will be enough to satisfy the UK's demands and whether it will have any impact on the outcome of the EU referendum.In the meantime, the debate over VAT rates is set to continue, with the Labour motion on Monday likely to be just the first salvo in a wider battle over the UK's relationship with the EU and its tax policies.

"This is a classic example of the EU's interference in our domestic affairs," said Conservative MP and Eurosceptic, John Redwood. "We should be able to set our own tax rates and not be dictated to by Brussels."However, supporters of the EU argue that the harmonization of VAT rates helps to create a level playing field across the single market and prevents member states from engaging in unfair tax competition. first_sentence: Although founded by freed American and Caribbean slaves, Liberia is mostly inhabited by indigenous Africans, with the slaves' descendants comprising 5% of the population.Around 250,000 people were killed in Liberia's civil war and many thousands more fled the fighting.Big programmes are under way to address the shortage of electricity and running water.
text: Corruption is rife and unemployment and illiteracy are endemic.Population 4.2 millionArea 99,067 sq km (38,250 sq miles)Languages English, 29 African languages belonging to the Mande, Kwa or Mel linguistic groupsMajor religions Christianity, Islam, indigenous beliefsLife expectancy 56 years (men), 59 years (women)Currency Liberian dollarPresident: Ellen Johnson SirleafEllen Johnson Sirleaf became Africa's first female president in 2005, two years after the end of a brutal 14-year conflict.She was re-elected in November 2011 in a poll marred by a low turn-out and a boycott by her main rival, Winston Tubman.Critics accuse her of having little to show for her first term, but supporters say she deserves praise for ensuring stability in the country.She was awarded the Nobel peace prize in 2011 for what the prize committee said were her efforts to secure peace, promote economic and social development and strengthen the position of women.Born in 1938, she is a widowed mother-of-four.Years of civil war left Liberia's media with the task of rebuilding. Many outlets still rely on financial support from politicians or international donors.Large fines imposed in libel cases have encouraged self-censorship despite the enacting of West Africa's first freedom of information law in 2010, reports US-based Freedom House.Some key events in Liberia's history:1847 - Constitution modelled on that of the US is drawn up, and Liberia becomes independent.1917 - Liberia declares war on Germany, giving the Allies a base in West Africa.1926 - Rubber production becomes backbone of Liberia's economy after Firestone Tyre and Rubber Company opens rubber plantation on land granted by government.1936 - Forced-labour practices abolished.1943 - William Tubman elected president.1958 - Racial discrimination outlawed.1980 - Master Sergeant Samuel Doe carries out military coup ousting and publicly executing President William Tolbert and 13 of his aides.1985 - Doe wins presidential election one year after his regime allowed return of political parties following pressure from the United States and other creditors.1989-2003 - Civil war. Up to 250,000 are killed, while thousands more are mutilated and raped, often by armies of drugged child soldiers led by ruthless warlords.2005 - Ellen Johnson Sirleaf becomes the first woman to be elected as an African head of state.2013-2016 - Outbreak of the deadly Ebola virus sweeps through Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone, killing 11,300 people, mainly in Liberia.

first_sentence: Back then, without the endless stream of blogs and social media, major stories that defined our technological future made their glorious debuts here.
text: Like the VCR, for instance - first shown at CES way back in 1970. Who could have foreseen the impact that piece of technology would have on the world?And 11 years later, the CD was shown here before anywhere else.These days, you rarely see entirely new things at CES. And so the show's purpose has changed somewhat - shifting into an event that is as much about spotting momentum rather than new products.But perhaps somewhere in the vast halls of the Las Vegas Convention Centre we've seen this year's VCR - a technology that will have impact well beyond what we can predict.Attendees - some 170,000 of them - are now heading home. And there seems to be a general consensus that CES 2016 signalled a transition year, but not a revolutionary one. The big ideas - like virtual reality, reinventing the car, or home robotics - were promising but still half-baked, a bun in the metaphorical (smart) oven. "We're in an in-between phase, where categories like drones, virtual reality, and wearables are growing and advancing, but still have a long way to go," wrote Rachel Metz from MIT Tech Review.The New York Times' Farhad Manjoo described CES 2016 as an "awkward adolescence" for emerging technologies.And that's absolutely right. VR has yet to go mainstream. Drones are out there, but set to be locked in regulatory hassle for the next year at least. And wearables? Well, let's just say too many companies are still thinking about function before fashion.CES 2016 was like it is every year: Big, overwhelming, full of terrible ideas, wasted money and overhyped nonsense.Gone are the days where you find the "next big thing" at CES. But if the technology business is alive and well, CES is still very much its pulse.Until next time, Vegas...Follow Dave Lee on Twitter @DaveLeeBBCRead and watch all our coverage from CES.
sample_text: It was an era of anticipation, where readers would eagerly await the morning paper or evening news broadcast to stay abreast of the latest developments shaping the world.In this bygone era, the introduction of the personal computer, the Internet, and the World Wide Web were met with a mix of fascination and trepidation. The potential of these innovations to revolutionize the way we lived, worked, and communicated was palpable, yet the uncertainty surrounding their impact on society was equally profound.I recall the excitement surrounding the launch of the IBM PC in 1981, which marked a significant turning point in the democratization of computing. The notion that individuals could now own a machine capable of performing tasks previously reserved for mainframe computers was a game-changer, and the media played a crucial role in explaining the significance of this development to a curious public.Similarly, the advent of the Internet in the late 1980s and early 1990s was met with a flurry of articles, editorials, and feature pieces that sought to demystify this newfangled network of networks. The potential for global connectivity, instant access to information, and the dawn of a new era of digital communication were all hot topics of discussion, as the media struggled to keep pace with the rapid evolution of this technology.And then, of course, there was the World Wide Web, which burst onto the scene in the early 1990s and forever changed the way we interact with information. The Web's intuitive interface, coupled with the proliferation of browsers like Netscape and Internet Explorer, made it possible for the masses to access and share information on an unprecedented scale.Throughout these pivotal moments, the media played a vital role in shaping public perception and understanding of these emerging technologies. Journalists, commentators, and pundits worked tirelessly to explain the complexities of these innovations, often using analogies and metaphors to make them more accessible to a broad audience.In many ways, the media's coverage of these technological milestones helped to fuel the imagination of the public, inspiring a new generation of innovators, entrepreneurs, and thinkers to explore the possibilities of the digital realm. As we look back on these formative years, it is clear that the media's role in shaping our understanding of technology was instrumental in laying the groundwork for the modern digital landscape we inhabit today.

first_sentence: Hoy says there is nothing worse as an athlete to have a special sporting moment ruined by suspicion.
text: "My message is it's possible to win clean," he told BBC Scotland. "Not every performance that you see that is outstanding should be met with a raised eyebrow. "The World Anti-Doping Agency (Wada)'s independently commissioned report found evidence of a Russian four-year, state-run "doping programme" across the "vast majority" of Olympic sports.Hoy, who is in Rio, says everyone wants a clean Olympics and athletes are in favour of the stringent testing process if it helps ensure their sport, and their success, is fair.He said: "Re-testing samples from the Beijing and London Olympics, the message to the athletes is 'Yes you might pass the test today but if you are cheating we are going to catch you at some point. It'll catch up with you, so what is the point in cheating?'. "You are going to have that fleeting moment of glory and then it's all going to be taken away from you, so don't do it. "There will always be somebody out there who will try and cheat, that's human nature. "Hoy also believes there are a number of Scots capable of winning medals, with Dunblane brothers Andy and Jamie Murray set to lead the way.They will partner each other in the tennis doubles, while newly crowned Wimbledon champion Andy will attempt to successfully defend his Olympic gold medal from London 2012. "Andy has had a cracking year so far," Hoy said. "You wouldn't bet against him winning gold here. But it's just so exciting, there's just so many names who are capable of winning medals here. "In the cycling team, Callum Skinner. I remember when he was a kid at Meadowbank and he's progressed through, worked incredibly hard and fought for his place. There was real competition to replace myself in the sprint team and some of the times have been mind boggling. "Katie Archibald, she's already been world champion, world record holder, European champion, but this is her first Olympics. And they are the favourites for the women's team pursuit along with Laura Trott and Elena Barker."
sample_text: Speaking exclusively to our publication, Hoy, a renowned Olympic cyclist, expressed his disappointment and frustration on behalf of Jack, saying, "There's nothing worse as an athlete to have a special sporting moment ruined by suspicion. You work your entire life for that one moment, and to have it tainted by doubts about your integrity is devastating."Hoy, who has won multiple Olympic gold medals and has been a vocal advocate for clean sport, emphasized the importance of maintaining the integrity of athletic competitions. "As athletes, we have a responsibility to ourselves, our teammates, and our fans to compete fairly and honestly. When someone is accused of cheating, it undermines the entire system and erodes trust in the sport."Jack, who broke the Australian record in the 100m freestyle event, has denied any wrongdoing and is cooperating fully with the Australian Sports Anti-Doping Authority (ASADA) investigation. However, the cloud of suspicion surrounding her achievement has already sparked heated debate among fans and fellow athletes.Hoy urged the sporting community to reserve judgment until the investigation is complete, saying, "We need to let the process play out and allow the authorities to do their job. It's not fair to assume guilt or innocence until all the facts are known."As the investigation continues, the sporting world remains divided on the issue. While some have rallied around Jack, others have called for stricter penalties for athletes found guilty of doping.One thing is certain, however: the integrity of sport is at stake, and the outcome of this investigation will have far-reaching implications for athletes, fans, and the sport as a whole.
sample_text2: The controversy surrounding Jack's record-breaking performance has sparked a wider conversation about the prevalence of doping in sports and the measures in place to prevent it. Many have questioned whether the current testing protocols are sufficient to catch cheaters, and whether the penalties for doping are severe enough to serve as a deterrent.Hoy, who has been a vocal advocate for clean sport throughout his career, believes that more needs to be done to protect the integrity of athletic competitions. "We need to invest more in anti-doping research and development, and we need to make sure that the penalties for doping are severe enough to make it not worth the risk," he said.Others have pointed to the need for greater transparency and accountability within the sporting community. "Athletes, coaches, and officials all have a role to play in maintaining the integrity of sport," said Dr. Kathryn Johnston, a sports ethicist at the University of Sydney. "We need to create a culture where athletes feel empowered to speak out against doping, and where those who are caught cheating are held accountable."As the investigation into Jack's case continues, the sporting world waits with bated breath for the outcome. Will she be cleared of any wrongdoing, or will she be found guilty of doping? Whatever the result, one thing is certain: the integrity of sport is at stake, and the consequences of this investigation will be felt far beyond the pool deck.In related news, the Australian Olympic Committee has announced that it will be conducting a review of its anti-doping policies and procedures in the wake of the Jack controversy. The review, which is expected to take several months, will examine the current testing protocols, the education and support provided to athletes, and the penalties for doping.The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has also weighed in on the issue, releasing a statement calling for greater cooperation and coordination between national anti-doping agencies and international sporting federations. "The fight against doping is a collective responsibility, and we must work together to protect the integrity of sport," said IOC President Thomas Bach.As the debate rages on, one thing is clear: the integrity of sport is at a crossroads. Will the sporting community come together to protect the values of fair play and clean competition, or will the temptation of victory at any cost continue to undermine the very fabric of athletic competition? Only time will tell.

first_sentence: Perfecto Yasay said he rejected an offer to hold negotiations "outside of and [in] disregard of" the ruling.Last week, the Permanent Court of Arbitration ruled that China's claims to rights in the South China Sea had no legal basis.The case at the tribunal was brought by the Philippines.China claims almost all of the South China Sea, and is locked in disputes with several other nations.
text: It rejected the verdict of the tribunal.There has been no comment from China in response to Mr Yasay's assertions but separately during a meeting on maritime security with the US, China remained defiant on the issue, state news agency Xinhua reported.A Chinese military official said that they would "never stop construction halfway" on the Nansha islands, China's name for the Spratly islands, Xinhua said.The tribunal ruling detailed where Beijing had violated Manila's rights under international law, including its construction work on Mischief Reef. "[China's foreign minister] had asked us to open ourselves for bilateral negotiations but outside, or [in] disregard of, the arbitral ruling," Perfecto Yasay told the ABS-CBN news channel. "This is something I told him was not consistent with our constitution and our national interest. ""They said that if you insist on the ruling and discussing it along those lines, then we might be headed for a confrontation," Mr Yasay said in the interview.Mr Yasay had met Chinese Foreign Minister Wang Yi on the sidelines of an Asia-Europe summit in Mongolia last weekend.Negotiating the right of Filipino fishermen to return to the disputed Scarborough Shoal would be the first priority of the Philippines, said Mr Yasay. He added that the implementation of all other parts of the ruling would be handled one-by-one.How are the lives of Filipino fishermen affected by the South China Sea dispute? "We will never stop our construction on the Nansha islands halfway," Wu Shengli, commander of the People's Liberation Army Navy told his US counterpart Admiral John Richardson on Tuesday, according to Xinhua. "The Nansha islands are China's inherent territory and our necessary construction on the islands is reasonable, justified and lawful," Mr Wu said.China had previously dismissed the tribunal ruling as a "piece of waste paper".The US, Japan and Australia are among many countries who have urged Beijing to respect the tribunal ruling.
sample_text: In a statement, Yasay said that he had rejected an offer to hold negotiations "outside of and [in] disregard of" the ruling, emphasizing that the Philippines would not engage in talks that would undermine the tribunal's decision.The ruling, handed down last week, was a major blow to China's claims to the disputed waters, which are believed to be rich in oil and gas reserves. The Philippines had brought the case to the tribunal in 2013, arguing that China's claims were in violation of international law.China has consistently rejected the ruling, calling it "null and void" and vowing to ignore it. Beijing claims almost all of the South China Sea, and is locked in disputes with several other nations, including Vietnam, Malaysia, and Brunei.The Philippines' stance has been welcomed by other countries in the region, who have long been wary of China's growing military presence in the South China Sea. The United States, in particular, has been vocal in its support for the Philippines, calling on China to respect the ruling and refrain from further militarization of the disputed waters.The standoff has raised concerns about the potential for conflict in the region, with some analysts warning that China's actions could lead to a military confrontation. The Philippines, meanwhile, has said that it is open to dialogue with China, but only if it is based on the principles of international law and respect for the tribunal's ruling.As tensions continue to simmer, the international community is watching closely to see how the situation will unfold. One thing is clear: the Philippines' commitment to upholding the rule of law has sent a strong message to China and the rest of the world.

first_sentence: Black GIs based in Bristol during World War Two were housed in segregated units but many experienced a new-found freedom in the city while off duty.They were able to mix with white women and socialise, which would have led to lynch mob violence in some US states.Ms Greer said her father, Ben, and other young GIs "had seen another world" and had taken a thirst for similar freedoms back home with them.It had given them a "kind of humanity and brief equality".She said the city had become a "seedbed" for the civil rights movement in the US and is now calling for a better acknowledgement of this in school curriculums in the UK and the US.The tolerance generally shown in the UK inspired many of the African Americans to fight oppression on their return to the US.Ms Greer, filming for a BBC West documentary which explores the issue, said the contrast had a significant impact.
text: "For the first time in their lives, they could be just young soldiers, out on the town, doing their own thing," she said. "And they could do the one thing they would have been killed for back home - hanging out with white women. "Neil Wynn, Emeritus Professor of 20th Century American History at the University of Gloucestershire, said: "It was a surprise for many African Americans to be treated as equals. "That for many of them was an amazing experience and one which was going to remain with them for the rest of their lives. "Ms Greer said what happened in Bristol should be highlighted alongside other more publicised aspects of the city's past. "The slave trade played a huge role in Bristol's history but I think that the experience of the GIs in the war was also important and the story should be told. "Both sides of Bristol should be taught," she said. "That's education - that's how knowledge and intelligence grows. "Her Chicago-born late father, Ben Greer, was based in England as a GI before taking part in the D-Day landings.He described his time in the UK to her as the "first decent experience of white people I'd ever had".The American authorities met local resistance to their attempts to introduce segregation beyond their military units, camps and social clubs.The Colston Arms in Bristol, for example, refused to accept that black and white soldiers should not be served together.Ms Greer said: "There should be a blue plaque outside the pub - it was remarkable what happened there. "The African American GIs livened up the city's wartime nightlife introducing exciting new dances such as the jitterbug and jazz music.But their popularity with the local girls led to tension and clashes with the white American GIs in Bristol  - culminating in a riot in the Park Street area in 1944.Details of the confrontation between hundreds of soldiers and military police were downplayed in the press under WW2 censorship.At the end of the war, many white GI brides emigrated to America but black soldiers returning to the US had to leave their sweethearts and children behind as interracial relationships and marriage were illegal in many states.VE Day: The First Days of Peace: Race Relations will be broadcast on BBC One in the West on Monday 11 May at 19:30 BST and on the BBC iPlayer.
sample_text: 'They had seen that they didn't have to live in a segregated society, that they could walk down the street without being lynched, that they could go into a pub and have a drink with white people,' she explained.Ms. Greer's father, Ben, was one of the many African American GIs who were stationed in Bristol during World War Two. He, like many others, was struck by the relative freedom and tolerance they experienced in the city. 'My father would tell me stories about how he would go to the cinema, and he would sit wherever he wanted, and nobody would bother him,' Ms. Greer recalled.The experience had a profound impact on the young men, many of whom went on to become prominent figures in the civil rights movement. 'They came back to the US with a newfound sense of confidence and a determination to fight for their rights,' Ms. Greer said.Ms. Greer is now calling for a greater recognition of the role that Bristol played in the civil rights movement. 'This is an important part of history that has been overlooked,' she said. 'We need to acknowledge the debt that we owe to these brave men who fought for our freedom, and who then went on to fight for their own.'The documentary, which is set to air on BBC West, explores the experiences of African American GIs in Bristol during World War Two. It features interviews with veterans and their families, as well as archival footage and photographs.Ms. Greer hopes that the documentary will help to raise awareness of this important chapter in history, and inspire a new generation to learn about the civil rights movement. 'This is a story that needs to be told,' she said. 'It's a story about courage, and perseverance, and the power of the human spirit.'"Title: "Bristol's Hidden History: The African American GIs Who Fought for Freedom"Subtitle: "New documentary explores the experiences of African American soldiers stationed in Bristol during World War Two and their role in the civil rights movement"
sample_text2: The documentary, "Bristol's Hidden History: The African American GIs Who Fought for Freedom," is set to premiere on BBC West next month, and Ms. Greer hopes it will spark a renewed interest in the city's rich cultural heritage. "Bristol has a unique place in the history of the civil rights movement, and it's time we recognized that," she said.The film features interviews with several African American veterans who were stationed in Bristol during World War Two, including 95-year-old James Edwards, who served in the 784th Tank Battalion. "I remember being amazed by the freedom we had in Bristol," Edwards said in the documentary. "We could go anywhere, eat anywhere, and nobody bothered us. It was like a different world."Edwards, who went on to become a prominent civil rights activist in the 1960s, credits his experience in Bristol with inspiring him to fight for racial equality back in the United States. "Seeing how people lived in Bristol, seeing how they treated each other with respect and dignity, it made me realize that we didn't have to accept the way things were in America," he said.The documentary also explores the impact that the African American GIs had on the local community in Bristol. Many of the soldiers formed close bonds with the people they met in the city, and some even went on to marry local women and start families.One such story is that of Emily Wilson, a Bristol native who met and fell in love with an African American GI named Samuel Brown. The couple married in 1945 and had two children together, but their relationship was not without its challenges. "It wasn't easy, of course," Wilson said in the documentary. "There were people who didn't approve of our relationship, but we didn't let that stop us. We knew that our love was stronger than any obstacle."Ms. Greer hopes that the documentary will help to shed light on the often-overlooked experiences of African American GIs in Bristol during World War Two. "These men were heroes in every sense of the word," she said. "They fought for our freedom, and then they went on to fight for their own. It's time we recognized their bravery and sacrifice."The documentary "Bristol's Hidden History: The African American GIs Who Fought for Freedom" will air on BBC West on March 15th.

first_sentence: The programme's future on ITV1 had been the subject of intense speculation for some time.ITV confirmed it had decided not to commission any further series of Taggart for the ITV network.Programme producers STV said they were exploring a range of options with other broadcasters to keep Taggart going.The company said it was committed to the brand and recognised the continuing popularity of this long-running series.It is believed the company will look at possible co-financing deals with other UK-based channels or foreign broadcasters.An ITV spokesman said: "Since it was first broadcast in 1983, Taggart has been one of ITV's most enduring dramas but, reflecting the demands of our audience and as part of the ongoing creative renewal of the ITV1 schedule, our priority is to invest in new and original drama for the channel.
text: "He added: "ITV1 broadcast five out of the top 10 new dramas on any channel last year, including the most popular new drama in over five years, Downton Abbey. "A broad range of new drama series premiering on the channel over 2011 includes Marchlands, Vera, Injustice, Scott & Bailey, The Jury and DCI Banks. "Two years ago, Taggart came close to being axed but STV and ITV worked out a co-production deal.This meant that STV paid a significant proportion of the production cost itself but also gained the right to screen the series before it was shown across the network.Previously STV had simply been commissioned by ITV to make the series and it was shown across the whole of the UK simultaneously.The most recent series was shown in the STV region last autumn while viewers in the rest of the UK saw the acclaimed costume drama Downton Abbey. Taggart's ratings within the STV region remained strong.But when the series was shown on the network a few months later, it was a different story. Taggart's ratings across the UK fell to 3.8 million for the most recent series - considered poor for a mainstream drama.In recent years, ITV has axed a number of long-running dramas - notably Heartbeat and The Bill - to put more effort into bringing new shows to the screen.Although Taggart had lost its popularity on ITV1, it remains popular in Scotland and is important to STV commercially and the television industry in Scotland.For instance, STV generates money from Taggart through sales to foreign broadcasters - over the years it has been screened in many countries around the world.Distributor DRG said Taggart was a "hugely popular" series internationally, airing across three different TV channels in Australia alone.A DRG spokesperson added: "It's our shared ambition to return Taggart to UK screens and we can confirm we're currently working closely with STV as we explore options to achieve this. "ITV did recently commission another drama from STV - a 90-minute one-off called Fast Freddie, The Widow and Me, which is expected to be shown over Christmas.STV and ITV recently ended a long-running legal dispute amicably. The dispute was triggered by STV's decision to drop a number of ITV network programmes but touched on many other matters.ITV sources are stressing the decision to discontinue Taggart was a purely creative decision, completely unconnected with the dispute.
sample_text: The decision to axe Taggart comes as ITV1 continues to revamp its programming schedule, with a focus on attracting a younger audience and increasing its ratings. The channel has recently introduced new dramas such as "Broadchurch" and "The Guilty", which have received critical acclaim and strong viewing figures.Taggart, which has been on the air for over 28 years, has been a staple of ITV1's programming schedule, with over 100 episodes produced to date. The show, which follows the investigations of the fictional Strathclyde Police department, has a loyal fan base and has won numerous awards during its run.STV, the production company behind Taggart, has expressed its commitment to keeping the show alive, despite ITV1's decision not to commission further series. The company is exploring options with other broadcasters, including possible co-financing deals with UK-based channels or foreign broadcasters."We are proud of the legacy of Taggart and are committed to finding a way to keep the show going," said an STV spokesperson. "We believe that the brand still has a lot to offer and we are exploring all options to ensure its continued success."Fans of the show have taken to social media to express their disappointment at the news, with many calling for the show to be saved. A petition has also been set up to try and persuade ITV1 to reconsider its decision.As the future of Taggart remains uncertain, one thing is clear - the show's dedicated fan base will not go quietly into the night.
sample_text2: The news of Taggart's axing has sent shockwaves through the television industry, with many industry insiders expressing surprise at ITV1's decision to cancel the long-running drama. The show's popularity has endured for nearly three decades, and its loyal fan base has been a significant factor in its success."Taggart has been a stalwart of ITV1's programming schedule for years, and its cancellation is a huge loss for the channel," said TV critic, Sarah Johnson. "The show's unique blend of gritty realism and clever storytelling has made it a favorite among audiences, and its absence will be deeply felt."The show's cast, including John Michie, who plays DI Robbie Ross, and Siobhan Redmond, who plays DCI Michelle Dunn, have also expressed their disappointment at the news. Michie took to Twitter to thank fans for their support, saying "I'm devastated by the news, but I'm so grateful to have had the opportunity to play Robbie Ross for so many years. The fans have been incredible, and I hope we can find a way to keep the show going."Redmond also expressed her sadness, saying "I'm heartbroken that Taggart won't be returning to ITV1, but I'm determined to fight for its future. The show has been a huge part of my life, and I know how much it means to the fans."As the news of Taggart's cancellation continues to spread, fans are rallying behind the show, using social media to express their outrage and disappointment. The hashtag #SaveTaggart is trending on Twitter, with fans sharing their favorite memories of the show and calling for ITV1 to reconsider its decision.Meanwhile, STV is working tirelessly to find a new home for the show. The production company is in talks with several UK-based broadcasters, including BBC Scotland and Channel 4, as well as foreign broadcasters, to explore co-financing deals."We're exploring all options to keep Taggart on the air," said an STV spokesperson. "We believe in the show's potential and are committed to finding a way to make it work. We're grateful for the outpouring of support from fans, and we're doing everything we can to make sure their voices are heard."As the future of Taggart remains uncertain, one thing is clear - the show's dedicated fan base will not give up without a fight. With its rich history, compelling storylines, and beloved characters, Taggart has earned its place as a British television institution, and its fans will stop at nothing to ensure its survival.

first_sentence: Ryan Morse, from Brynithel, Blaenau Gwent, died on 8 December 2012 from Addison's disease.Prof Ieuan Hughes said this could have been prevented if a basic examination was done and he was sent to hospital.Dr Joanne Rudling, 46, of Cardiff, and Dr Lindsey Thomas, 42, of Tredegar, deny manslaughter.Prof Hughes, a consultant paediatrician, told Cardiff Crown Court he would have expected Ryan to survive, given emergency treatment, up until a few hours before his death.And another medical expert, Dr Leonard Peter said the care both doctors gave Ryan fell far below expected standards.Earlier, the court heard Ryan's mother twice phoned Abernant Surgery in Abertillery the day before he died.On 7 December at 08:55 GMT, she spoke to Dr Thomas about Ryan's sickness and diarrhoea and said he was too weak to make it to the surgery.Mrs Morse phoned the surgery again at 17:45 GMT and spoke to Dr Rudling after she noticed parts of his skin had turned "completely black" but was told it was hormonal changes due to puberty.Prof Hughes said: "In my view, if Ryan had been admitted to hospital on the morning of 7 December and received satisfactory resuscitation, I would have expected him to survive.
text: "He said he believed Ryan's life could also have been saved if he had been sent to hospital when Dr Rudling spoke to him and even up until 23:00.He died shortly afterwards and Carol Morse woke at 04:15 GMT on 8 December to find him cold and lifeless on the sofa.Ryan first fell ill in July 2012 and weighed just 4st 11lb (30kg) at the time of his death.Dr Peter told the court Dr Rudling should have weighed Ryan when she saw him on 7 November, a month before he died and on 21 November at a follow-up appointment, as Ryan's mother had mentioned his weight loss.He said: "That complaint would have led any reasonably competent GP to weigh Ryan to see if he was below what was expected of a child of his age and height. "He said Dr Thomas had also missed several "red flag" symptoms when she spoke to Mrs Morse on the phone on 7 December and should have visited Ryan in person or arranged for him to be taken to A&E.His symptoms included Ryan suffering from diarrhoea, being delirious and being unable to stand or walk.He said: "Delirium in a 12 year old is not something I have ever experienced in 41 years as a GP except in a child with sepsis or meningitis- it's an extraordinarily unusual symptom. "Taken together these symptoms should have given a strong warning for an overwhelming infection such as septicaemia or meningitis or metabolic problems like diabetes or indeed Addison's, although I would not have expected her to diagnose Addison's. "He said advising Ryan's mother to see how he was in a couple of hours was not appropriate as if he had had an infection, he could have fallen dangerously ill within that time.The court heard an intravenous drip to rehydrate Ryan and boost his salt levels plus medication to raise his blood pressure could have saved him.If his adrenal gland had been irreversibly damaged, he would have then needed oral medication for life, Prof Hughes added.The trial continues.
sample_text: The court heard that Ryan's mother, Mrs. Morse, had become increasingly concerned about her son's condition and had called the surgery twice, but was reassured by the doctors that his symptoms were not serious.Dr. Leonard Peter, a medical expert, testified that the care provided by Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas fell "far below" the expected standards. He stated that Ryan's symptoms, including vomiting, diarrhea, and skin discoloration, were clear indicators of a life-threatening condition that required immediate medical attention.The prosecution alleges that Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas failed to take adequate action to diagnose and treat Ryan's condition, leading to his tragic death.Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas deny manslaughter and claim that they did not neglect their duties as doctors. Their defense team argues that Ryan's condition was not as severe as claimed and that they had followed proper medical procedures.The trial is ongoing, with further medical experts and witnesses expected to testify. The jury will have to decide whether the doctors' actions, or lack thereof, contributed to Ryan's death.The case has sparked widespread concern about the quality of medical care in the UK and the importance of doctors taking patient concerns seriously. Ryan's family has expressed their hope that the trial will bring about changes to ensure that such a tragedy never happens again.The court will reconvene tomorrow to hear further evidence in the case.
sample_text2: **DAY 3 OF TRIAL: EXPERT WITNESSES TAKE THE STAND**The trial of Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas continued today, with a series of expert witnesses taking the stand to testify about the standard of care provided to Ryan Morse.Dr. Sophia Patel, a pediatrician with over 20 years of experience, told the court that Ryan's symptoms were "textbook" indicators of a life-threatening condition. "Any competent doctor would have recognized the severity of Ryan's condition and taken immediate action," she stated.Dr. Patel was followed by Dr. James Wilson, a specialist in emergency medicine, who testified that the delay in diagnosing and treating Ryan's condition was "inexcusable." "In a case like this, every minute counts. The failure to act promptly and decisively led to Ryan's tragic death," he said.The defense team, however, continued to argue that Ryan's condition was not as severe as claimed and that their clients had followed proper medical procedures. They pointed to Ryan's initial diagnosis of a viral infection, which they claimed was a reasonable conclusion based on the symptoms presented.Under cross-examination, Dr. Patel and Dr. Wilson were pressed by the defense team to acknowledge that there were some ambiguities in Ryan's symptoms and that a diagnosis of a viral infection was not entirely unreasonable. However, both experts maintained that the doctors should have erred on the side of caution and taken further action to rule out more serious conditions.The prosecution also called Ryan's mother, Mrs. Morse, to the stand, who tearfully recounted her son's final days and the conversations she had with Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas. "I was told not to worry, that Ryan just had a virus and would be fine. But I knew something was wrong. I knew my son," she said.The trial is expected to continue for several more days, with further expert witnesses and medical evidence to be presented. The jury will have to weigh the competing claims and decide whether Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas are guilty of manslaughter.**FAMILY'S PLEA FOR CHANGE**Outside the courtroom, Ryan's family and supporters gathered to call for changes to the healthcare system to prevent similar tragedies from occurring. "We don't want any other family to go through what we've been through," said Ryan's father, Mr. Morse. "We need to make sure that doctors take patient concerns seriously and that they are held accountable when they fail to provide adequate care."The case has sparked widespread outrage and concern about the quality of medical care in the UK. Health experts and patient advocacy groups are calling for greater transparency and accountability in the healthcare system.As the trial continues, the nation waits with bated breath for the verdict. Will Dr. Rudling and Dr. Thomas be found guilty of manslaughter, or will they be acquitted? One thing is certain: the outcome of this trial will have far-reaching implications for the healthcare system and the families who rely on it.
