first_sentence: Tsang led Hong Kong from 2005 to 2012 and is the most senior official in the territory ever to stand trial for corruption.He was found guilty last week of misconduct in public office, in a case related to a luxury flat in China.In sentencing, Judge Andrew Chan said: "Never in my judicial career have I seen a man fall from so high.
text: "A number of senior former officials in Hong Kong had written letters to the court in defence of Tsang's character.The judge said he took Tsang's reputation and long public service into account in sentencing, taking 10 months off what would have been a 30-month sentence. The maximum penalty could have been seven years.Tsang was cleared last week of a second count of misconduct, while the jury failed to reach a verdict on a third charge of accepting an advantage. He is expected to be retried on that charge in September.After sentencing, he was taken from court in handcuffs to the hospital where he has been staying since experiencing chest pain on Monday.When the presiding judge asked Mr Tsang to stand for sentencing, the former chief executive took a sip of water and closed his eyes. He kept his eyes closed during most of the sentencing speech and appeared to calm himself with a rhythmic breathing exercise.Five years of investigations and weeks of trial had culminated in this humiliating moment.It was an ignominious end for a man who used to be the pride of Hong Kong - someone who had overcome a humble start in life to hold three of the city's top jobs.Mr Tsang's legacy and reputation are in tatters and the judge acknowledged it, saying he had never before seen a man fall so far, so fast.The case has worried a territory that prides itself on its relatively clean reputation.The trial related to events which took place near the end of his term, between 2010 and 2012.Prosecutors accused Mr Tsang of inappropriate and undeclared conflicts of interest, including renting a luxury flat in mainland China from the shareholder of a broadcast company whose licence applications he approved. They also alleged the flat was redecorated free of charge and that he later nominated the interior designer for an honour.The jury found him guilty of misconduct over his failure to disclose the lease of the flat, but dismissed the charge related to the designer and did not reach a verdict on whether he accepted a bribe in the form of the refurbishment.A career civil servant, Tsang rose through the ranks to become Hong Kong's second chief executive, following Tung Chee-hwa.His deputy, former Chief Secretary Rafael Hui, was jailed for accepting bribes from a property tycoon in 2014.
sample_text: The defendant's actions were a gross breach of trust, and his fall from grace is a tragedy of his own making."Tsang, 72, was sentenced to 20 months in prison, with the judge citing the severity of the offense and the need to maintain public confidence in the government.The case against Tsang centered around his failure to disclose his dealings with a property developer who was also a major shareholder in a Hong Kong television network. Tsang was accused of accepting a luxury apartment in Guangzhou, China, at a significantly discounted price, as well as other favors, in exchange for his support of the developer's business interests.During the trial, prosecutors presented evidence that Tsang had lied about his dealings with the developer and had concealed his ownership of the apartment from the public. The court heard that Tsang had also accepted other gifts and favors, including a luxury car and a trip to China, without disclosing them.Tsang's defense team had argued that the former chief executive was not guilty of misconduct, citing his long history of public service and his commitment to the people of Hong Kong. However, the judge rejected these arguments, saying that Tsang's actions were a clear breach of the public trust.The sentence is seen as a major blow to Tsang's reputation and a significant victory for anti-corruption efforts in Hong Kong. The territory has long been known for its clean government and strong institutions, and the conviction of a former chief executive is a rare and significant event.The case has also sparked widespread debate about corruption and accountability in Hong Kong, with many calling for greater transparency and stronger measures to prevent abuse of power.Tsang's legal team has indicated that they will appeal the sentence, but for now, the former chief executive will begin serving his prison term.
sample_text2: The verdict has sent shockwaves throughout Hong Kong, with many residents expressing outrage and disappointment at the fall of a once-respected leader. "This is a dark day for Hong Kong," said Emily Wong, a local resident. "We trusted Tsang to lead our city with integrity, and it's devastating to learn that he betrayed that trust."The case has also sparked concerns about the influence of wealthy business interests on Hong Kong's government. "This verdict shows that even the most powerful people in Hong Kong are not above the law," said lawmaker Claudia Mo. "But it also highlights the need for greater transparency and accountability in our government. We need to ensure that our leaders are serving the people, not just their own interests."Tsang's conviction is also seen as a major victory for the Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC), which has been investigating the case for years. "This verdict is a testament to the ICAC's tireless efforts to root out corruption in Hong Kong," said ICAC Commissioner Simon Peh. "We will continue to work to ensure that those who abuse their power are held accountable."As Tsang begins his prison term, many are left wondering how such a respected leader could fall so far. "Tsang was once a hero to many in Hong Kong," said political analyst Joseph Cheng. "But his desire for power and wealth ultimately consumed him. This case is a cautionary tale about the dangers of corruption and the importance of accountability in government."The case has also sparked calls for greater reform in Hong Kong's government. "This verdict shows that our system is broken," said pro-democracy lawmaker Eddie Chu. "We need to reform our government to prevent this kind of corruption from happening again. We need to ensure that our leaders are accountable to the people, not just to their own interests."As the city comes to terms with the fall of a once-respected leader, many are left wondering what the future holds for Hong Kong. Will this verdict mark a turning point in the fight against corruption, or will it be just another chapter in a long history of abuse of power? Only time will tell.

first_sentence: The Belfast man became the first Northern Ireland boxer to win world titles at two weight divisions when he defeated Leo Santa Cruz in the US.Supporters gathered on the lawns at the front of Belfast City Hall on Friday evening to celebrate the win.The Jackal said he was "glad to get home" after his win over the Mexican in New York last month.
text: "I haven't done a lot since I've come back home, I've tried to keep my head down," the 29-year-old added. "This is the first time I've tried to get out among the people - to see the support they have for me is absolutely fantastic. "He said he hoped to fight again in December, with a potential rematch against Santa Cruz on the cards. "I want to have Christmas off to spend time with Christine and the kids," he said. "I'm ready to fight big names - I want all fights to be big fights. "I want to fight in Belfast more often, more than I have been recently. "But now I'm the champion again, we can bring the big boys to Belfast. "First Minister Arlene Foster, who was at City Hall, said Frampton is a "wonderful young man". "We're all so proud of Carl Frampton, he embodies everything that is good about Northern Ireland, he inspires young people as well," she added.Lord Mayor of Belfast Brian Kingston said the event was a chance for Frampton's fans to congratulate him. "He is a tremendous ambassador for us," he said. "Not just in what he has achieved, but how he handles himself, his whole character and he's very proud of where he comes from. "Frampton won his first world title - the IBF super-bantamweight crown - in 2014 when he beat Spain's Kiko Martinez.He became the unified world champion at that weight when he defeated WBA champion Scott Quigg in February this year.He then gave up his belts and moved up a weight to fight the previously undefeated Santa Cruz.
sample_text: "It's amazing to see so many people come out to support me," said Frampton, beaming with pride as he held aloft his WBO interim featherweight title belt. "I'm glad to get home and celebrate with the people who have been behind me every step of the way."The 30-year-old boxer, known for his formidable punching power and slick ring skills, was mobbed by fans as he made his way through the crowd, signing autographs and posing for photos.Frampton's victory over Santa Cruz on January 28 marked a significant milestone in his career, cementing his status as one of the world's top boxers. The win added the WBO interim featherweight title to his collection, which already included the IBF super bantamweight title he won in 2014.Belfast Lord Mayor, Councillor Brian Kingston, was among the dignitaries who attended the celebration, and he praised Frampton's achievement as a source of inspiration for the people of Northern Ireland."Carl Frampton is a true champion, not just in the boxing ring, but as a role model for young people across our city and beyond," said Councillor Kingston. "His dedication, hard work, and perseverance are an inspiration to us all, and we are proud to call him one of our own."As the celebration continued into the evening, Frampton took to the microphone to thank his fans and express his gratitude for their unwavering support."I couldn't have done it without you all," he said, his voice filled with emotion. "This is a dream come true, and I'm honored to be able to share it with the people of Belfast."The event was also attended by Frampton's wife, Christine, and their two children, who were beaming with pride as they watched their father bask in the adoration of the crowd.As the night drew to a close, Frampton vowed to continue pushing himself to new heights, and to bring more glory to Northern Ireland in the years to come."I'm not done yet," he said, his eyes gleaming with determination. "I've got more titles to win, and more history to make. And I'll do it all with the people of Belfast right behind me."

first_sentence: His endorsement came after meeting Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders who has been battling Mrs Clinton for the nomination.Speaking in a video tweeted out by Mrs Clinton, Mr Obama said she may be the most qualified person "ever" for the role of president.The two are set to start campaigning together soon.
text: "I want those of you who've been with me from the beginning of this incredible journey to be the first to know that 'I'm with Her.' I am fired up and cannot wait to get out there and campaign for Hillary," Mr Obama said in the video. "Secretary Clinton and Senator Sanders may have been rivals during this primary, but they're both patriots who love this country and they share a vision for the America that we all believe in. "The two ran against one another for the Democratic nomination in 2008 and Mr Obama later made Mrs Clinton secretary of state.Speaking to Reuters following the endorsement, Mrs Clinton said Mr Obama's endorsement "means the world". "It is absolutely a joy and an honour that President Obama and I, over the years, have gone from fierce competitors to true friends," she said.Presumptive Republican nominee Donald Trump tweeted that Mr Obama's endorsement means he wants "four more years of Obama" and "nobody else does".Barack Obama is now in the game. In a slickly produced video endorsement, the president has thrown his support behind Hillary Clinton's bid to keep the White House in Democratic hands.Given the high production value of the video, the announcement had obviously been in the works for some time. In fact, astute observers have noted that Mr Obama is sporting the tie he wore on Tuesday.Bernie Sanders has said he will continue to campaign in Washington DC, leading up to the capital city's primary next week - but expect most Democrats to close ranks quickly. The Vermont senator even struck a more conciliatory tone after a meeting at the White House, saying he looks forward to "working together" with the former secretary of state to defeat Donald Trump.Mr Obama and Mrs Clinton will make their first joint appearance together in Wisconsin next week. Before that she's visiting Ohio and Pennsylvania.The Democrats clearly view the general election battleground as the industrial Rust Belt states. And for the first time since 1998 there is a popular, scandal-free second-term incumbent president working hard on the campaign trail to preserve his legacy.What an Obama endorsement will mean for Hillary
sample_text: In the video, President Obama praised Mrs. Clinton's experience and dedication to public service, saying "I don't think there's ever been someone so qualified to hold this office." He also highlighted her commitment to issues such as healthcare, education, and economic opportunity.The endorsement is seen as a significant boost to Mrs. Clinton's campaign, which has been facing a tough challenge from Senator Sanders. The Vermont senator has been gaining momentum in recent weeks, winning several state primaries and caucuses.However, President Obama's endorsement is likely to help Mrs. Clinton consolidate her lead among Democratic voters and party leaders. The President's popularity among Democrats remains high, and his backing is expected to carry significant weight with undecided voters.In a statement, Mrs. Clinton thanked President Obama for his endorsement, saying "I'm thrilled to have President Obama's support. His leadership and vision have inspired a generation of Americans, and I'm honored to have him by my side as we work to build a better future for our country."The joint rally next week is expected to mark the beginning of a more intense campaign push by Mrs. Clinton and President Obama, as they seek to energize Democratic voters and take on the Republican nominee in the general election.Meanwhile, Senator Sanders' campaign has responded to the endorsement, saying that it will not deter them from continuing to push for a political revolution in the United States. "We're not going to let endorsements from establishment politicians stand in the way of our movement," said a Sanders campaign spokesperson. "We're going to keep fighting for the values and principles that matter most to the American people."
sample_text2: The endorsement has also sparked a lively debate among political analysts, with some arguing that it could be a game-changer for Mrs. Clinton's campaign, while others believe it may not have a significant impact on the outcome of the primary race."President Obama's endorsement is a major coup for Hillary Clinton," said Dr. Jane Smith, a political science professor at Harvard University. "His popularity among Democrats is still very high, and his backing will likely help to consolidate her lead among party loyalists and undecided voters."However, others argue that the endorsement may not be enough to sway voters who are looking for a more radical change in Washington. "Bernie Sanders' supporters are motivated by a desire for fundamental reform, and an endorsement from President Obama may not be enough to persuade them to switch sides," said Tom Johnson, a political analyst at CNN.The endorsement has also raised questions about the role of the President in the Democratic primary process. Some have criticized President Obama for intervening in the race, arguing that it undermines the democratic process and gives an unfair advantage to Mrs. Clinton."President Obama should have stayed out of this race," said Senator Sanders' campaign manager, Jeff Weaver. "By endorsing Hillary Clinton, he's essentially putting his thumb on the scale and trying to influence the outcome of the primary."Despite the controversy, Mrs. Clinton's campaign is likely to capitalize on the endorsement, using it to build momentum and energize her supporters. The joint rally next week is expected to be a major event, with thousands of supporters expected to attend.In the meantime, Senator Sanders' campaign is vowing to continue its grassroots efforts, relying on small donations and volunteer support to fuel its campaign. "We're not going to let the establishment politicians and their big-money donors dictate the outcome of this election," said Senator Sanders in a statement. "We're going to keep fighting for the people, and we're going to win."As the primary race enters its final stretch, one thing is clear: the battle for the Democratic nomination is far from over. With President Obama's endorsement, Mrs. Clinton has gained a significant advantage, but Senator Sanders' campaign is refusing to give up. The next few weeks will be crucial in determining the outcome of this highly contested race.

first_sentence: After today's announcement that 800 jobs are being created in Solihull, global brand director John Edwards said: "We're only going to build in China for the Chinese market.
text: "Our job is to keep our three factories in the UK buzzing. "The Gaydon-based firm has released record global sales figures for 2012, showing sales in China rose by 70%.The firm sold 71,940 vehicles in China last year, meaning it has now overtaken the UK to become JLR's biggest market.In November the Indian-owned company announced a deal to complete a car plant near Shanghai by 2015, allowing it to manufacture vehicles in China for the first time.Last month it also emerged that JLR is considering building cars in Saudi Arabia.Jaguar Land Rover recorded sales in 177 countries for 2012 and currently exports 85% of production from its factories in Birmingham, Merseyside and Coventry.Mr Edwards added: "We're looking to build our workforce in Solihull, but it's not just about Solihull. Gaydon, Whitley and Castle Bromwich are all good places to be at the moment. "He said the manufacturer continues to have "significant growth ambitions" and is looking to expand markets in Brazil, Russia and Indonesia. "China's very important, it's the biggest car market in the world and it's our fastest growing market," Mr Edwards continued. "We grew by more than 70% in China last year. "But it still only accounts for 20% of our volume. "One of real success factors is that we're a global business. "We export 85% of our production from the UK and we go the world over. "Rachael Eade, from the Manufacturing Advisory Service (MAS), said people living in China Russia and India "really want to buy premier goods".Ms Eade said: "They will still be making cars in Britain for the foreseeable future. "Part of the reason is the overseas buyers like to be able to drive cars that are designed and made in the UK. "The news of the job creation at JLR would have a big impact on the local economy in the West Midlands, according to Ms Eade.She said: "Every job created at Jaguar Land Rover, or any other vehicle manufacturer, equates to two or three in the supply chain. "Smaller local companies are being encouraged to invest in new factories, new technologies and new machinery. "MAS wants to help companies to get ready to up their speed and their ability to produce and get the goods to Jaguar Land Rover ready to build cars."
sample_text: We're thrilled to be bringing these new jobs to the region and investing in the local community."The announcement has been hailed as a major boost to the West Midlands economy, with local leaders praising the company's commitment to the area. "This is fantastic news for Solihull and the wider region," said Councillor Ian Courts, leader of Solihull Council. "We've worked hard to create a business-friendly environment and it's great to see a global brand like this recognizing the benefits of investing here."The new facility, which is expected to be operational by the end of next year, will be the company's first manufacturing base in Europe. It will produce a range of products, including automotive parts and industrial equipment, for distribution across the continent.The 800 new jobs will include a mix of manufacturing, engineering, and administrative roles, with the company promising to work with local schools and colleges to provide training and development opportunities for young people in the area.Today's announcement is the latest in a series of investments in the region, which has seen a surge in economic growth in recent years. The West Midlands is increasingly being seen as a hub for advanced manufacturing and engineering, with several major companies setting up operations in the area."This is a great example of the West Midlands' ability to attract major international investment," said Andy Street, Mayor of the West Midlands. "We're proud to be a region that's open for business and we look forward to working with this company to make the most of this exciting opportunity."
sample_text2: The company's decision to locate in Solihull is also seen as a vote of confidence in the region's transport infrastructure, with the nearby Birmingham Airport and major motorway networks providing easy access to European markets."This investment is a testament to the West Midlands' strategic location and connectivity," said Neil Rami, Chief Executive of the West Midlands Growth Company. "We're delighted to have worked with the company to secure this investment and look forward to supporting their growth plans in the region."The news has also been welcomed by local business leaders, who see the investment as a catalyst for further economic growth in the area."This is a fantastic opportunity for the region and a great endorsement of the West Midlands as a place to do business," said Paul Faulkner, Chief Executive of the Greater Birmingham Chambers of Commerce. "We're confident that this investment will have a positive impact on the local economy and create new opportunities for businesses of all sizes."The company's commitment to working with local schools and colleges to provide training and development opportunities has also been praised by education leaders in the region."This is a great example of how businesses and education providers can work together to develop the skills and talent needed to drive economic growth," said Dr. Christine Braddock, Principal of Solihull College. "We're looking forward to working with the company to provide training and development opportunities for our students and help them access these new job opportunities."Overall, today's announcement is seen as a major coup for the West Midlands, cementing its reputation as a hub for advanced manufacturing and engineering. With its strong transport infrastructure, business-friendly environment, and highly skilled workforce, the region is well-placed to attract further investment and drive economic growth in the years to come.

first_sentence: Former Chelsea boss Grant, 59, has been discussing his financial package with the Ghana Football Association (GFA).There had been concerns his Israeli nationality could pose access problems to some North African countries.GFA president Kwesi Nyantekyie told BBC Sport "that is an issue" but says the two parties will deal with it.
text: "The holder of an Israeli passport will not only be denied entry into North African countries, he will be denied into some Arab countries," he said. "He has brought an alternative way of dealing with it. There is a satisfactory arrangement to arrest his threat. Very soon, in a matter of months, we should clear that. "Nyantekyie confirmed Grant has met with the GFA in Accra and said it is "almost certain" the two parties will reach a deal. "By the time we finish with our game against Togo, we should have an agreement in place," he said.Grant will be given a two-year contract, and Nyantekyie says the GFA is confident he has the profile to succeed in the role. "He is a motivator. He has the capacity and skill to manage egos and top players and these are some of the challenges that the Black Stars team is going through. "He has the strength, he has a strong mentality. He feels in Africa most of the players lack the passion or the mentality even though they have the skill. We hope he will be able to instil these qualities so that we will win trophies. "Grant took Chelsea to the final of the 2008 European Champions League, in which they were beaten by Manchester United, and also had a four-year spell in charge of Israel's national side.The Black Stars have been without a permanent coach since Kwesi Appiah left after the opening two 2015 Africa Cup of Nations qualifiers, with Maxwell Konadu leading the team on a temporary basis.Ghana midfielder Andre Dede Ayew said: "If Avram Grant comes to Ghana, we will support him. He is a good coach, he has coached big clubs and hopefully he will help Ghana. "What is most important is that we win trophies - and anybody that is going to bring trophies, I will be with the person whether he is big, small or whatever. "If he is coming to Ghana, I know he will feel the Ghanaian pressure, he will know that Ghana is a country which needs to win because we have not won a trophy in a long while. "Ghana missed an opportunity to qualify for the 2015 Africa Cup of Nations after losing 1-0 to Uganda in Group E in Kampala on Saturday.The group will be decided after the final round of matches on Wednesday.

However, GFA president Kwesi Nyantekyie has acknowledged that Grant's Israeli nationality could pose a problem."That is an issue," Nyantekyie told BBC Sport. "But we will deal with it. However, the issue of his Israeli nationality is likely to be a challenge that the GFA will need to navigate carefully.It remains to be seen whether Grant will be able to overcome the potential obstacles and take the reins of the Ghana national team. But one thing is certain - his appointment would be a major talking point in the world of football.

However, his Israeli nationality has raised concerns about his ability to travel to certain countries, particularly in Africa and the Middle East, where Israel is not recognized.GFA president Kwesi Nyantekyie has acknowledged the issue, but remains optimistic that a solution can be found. "We can't afford to have our team boycotted or protested against because of our coach's nationality."Despite the controversy, Grant's supporters argue that his experience and reputation in the football world make him an ideal candidate for the job."Grant has a proven track record as a coach," said one football analyst. first_sentence: More than 800 million gel capsules, or liquitabs, are sold every year in the UK.Their popularity has been accompanied by a surge in poisonings of children under five, who are attracted by their brightly coloured, sweet-like appearance.BBC Scotland has highlighted the dangers of the capsules several times.Under the new EU regulations, from 1 June all laundry capsules must be packaged in non-transparent boxes, with warnings and a child-resistant closure.
text: They must also be insoluble for 6 seconds and be impregnated with a bitter flavour so that a child will spit out the tab.It is expected it will take six months before capsules manufactured under the new regulations replace those currently on sale.The head of sustainability and safety at the European consumer organisation BEUC, Sylvia Maurer, said: "It is reassuring that the European Commission swiftly took action to mitigate the risk of laundry detergents after poisoning incidents of young children were reported. "Having binding rules which go beyond voluntary industry action are indispensable to keep consumers safe in the internal market. "One bitter flavouring which is likely to be used by some manufacturers is Bitrex, which is manufactured in Edinburgh by Macfarlane Smith. "We see aversive agents like Bitrex as a last line of defence," said business manager Gina Mercier. "It isn't a substitute for safe storage and child-resistant packaging, but as most liquitab incidents take place when they are in use, Bitrex is a final reassurance for parents. "Bitrex is the bitterest substance in the world, and its inclusion makes it almost impossible for even the most determined child to swallow a potentially dangerous detergent. "Reconstructive surgeryThe European Commission decided to act after research by the Organisation for European Co-operation and Development (OECD) found poisonings were widespread across Europe.There were 1,486 incidents involving laundry capsules in the UK between May 2009 and July 2012, equating to more than one a day. In France there were 7,500 reports between 2005 and 2013, and Ireland experienced 200 incidents in 2012 and 2013.Most involved children under five and some required reconstructive surgery.The products were launched in 2001, but it took 12 years for opaque packaging, warning labels and child-resistant catches to be rolled out. Before the EU ruling, only Tesco had added a bitter flavour to its own-brand laundry capsules.The director general of the UK Cleaning Products Industry Association denied that the industry had been slow to act. "The industry has moved quickly," he said. "The legislation has adopted what we were already doing. The final key is in the home. It's down to the parents to use the products responsibly and keep them out of reach - and that goes for other household products too, such as bleach. "He pointed out that his organisation has been supporting the Royal Society for the Prevention of Accidents, and other children's charities, to help parents improve safety in the home.
sample_text: According to the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, there were over 2,000 reported cases of children under five being poisoned by laundry detergent capsules in the UK between 2014 and 2018.The new regulations, which come into effect on June 1, aim to reduce the attractiveness of the capsules to young children. Manufacturers will be required to package the capsules in opaque boxes, making it harder for children to see the colorful contents. Additionally, the boxes will feature clear warnings about the dangers of ingesting the capsules, and will be equipped with child-resistant closures to prevent accidental opening.The UK's Chief Medical Officer, Professor Chris Whitty, welcomed the new regulations, saying "These measures will help to protect young children from the dangers of laundry detergent capsules. We urge parents and caregivers to remain vigilant and to keep these products out of reach of children at all times."The changes are part of a wider effort to improve safety standards for household products. The EU has also introduced new regulations for other hazardous substances, including button batteries and cleaning products.While the new regulations are a step in the right direction, campaigners say more needs to be done to prevent accidental ingestions. "We need to see a fundamental change in the way these products are designed and marketed," said Sarah Jones, a mother whose child was poisoned by a laundry detergent capsule in 2017. "We need to make sure that these products are safe for our children, and that manufacturers are held accountable for their actions."As the new regulations come into effect, parents and caregivers are being urged to take extra precautions to keep laundry detergent capsules out of reach of children. The NHS has also launched a public awareness campaign to educate parents about the dangers of accidental ingestions and the importance of seeking medical attention immediately if a child is suspected of ingesting a laundry detergent capsule.
sample_text2: The campaign, titled "Safe at Home," aims to raise awareness about the potential dangers of household products and provide parents with practical tips on how to keep their children safe. The campaign will include social media advertisements, posters, and leaflets, as well as partnerships with parenting groups and online forums.Dr. Amanda Thomas, a pediatrician and spokesperson for the Royal College of Paediatrics and Child Health, emphasized the importance of parental vigilance. "Laundry detergent capsules may look like candy or toys to young children, but they can be extremely dangerous if ingested. Parents and caregivers need to be aware of the risks and take steps to prevent accidents from happening."The new regulations and public awareness campaign come as part of a broader effort to reduce the number of accidental ingestions of household products. According to the National Poisons Information Service, there were over 10,000 reported cases of children under 18 being poisoned by household substances in 2019 alone.While the focus is currently on laundry detergent capsules, campaigners are calling for greater action to be taken to improve safety standards across the board. "We need to see a culture shift in the way manufacturers design and market their products," said Sarah Jones, the mother whose child was poisoned by a laundry detergent capsule. "We need to prioritize the safety of our children and hold companies accountable for their actions."The UK government has pledged to continue working with manufacturers and safety experts to improve safety standards and reduce the number of accidental ingestions. As the new regulations come into effect, parents and caregivers are being urged to remain vigilant and take extra precautions to keep household products out of reach of children.In related news, a number of manufacturers have announced plans to introduce new safety features to their products. Procter & Gamble, the manufacturer of Tide laundry detergent, has announced that it will be introducing a new child-resistant packaging design for its capsules. Unilever, the manufacturer of Persil laundry detergent, has also pledged to introduce new safety features to its products.As the debate around household product safety continues, one thing is clear: the safety of our children must be our top priority. By working together, we can create a safer environment for our children and reduce the risk of accidental ingestions.

first_sentence: The Payments Systems Regulator (PSR) was responding to a "super complaint" from consumer group Which?.This complaint highlighted the problem of "push" fraud whereby victims are conned into paying the wrong person.However, the PSR stopped short of recommending that banks should be forced to compensate customers.In response, Which?
text: said that banks had been let off the hook, and they would have little incentive to protect account-holders.It had wanted banks to refund consumers in cases where customers accidentally transferred money to a fraudster, similar to the protections provided on credit card transactions.At the moment banks pay up in about a third of such cases. But mostly they do not admit liability, leaving consumers out of pocket.Such transfers work instantly, and cannot be recalled.In one example highlighted by Which?, Christopher Mills, from York, was tricked into paying a Â£10,000 house deposit to a fraudster who posed as his estate agent.The bank refused to cover the loss. "Tens of thousands of people have, combined, lost hundreds of millions of pounds to these scams," said Hannah Nixon, the PSR's managing director. "We need a concerted and co-ordinated industry-wide approach to better protect consumers, and we need it to start today. "The regulator said banks needed to work together to help detect this type of fraud, adding they could do more to identify potentially fraudulent payments.It is recommending that:However Which? accused the regulator of letting banks off the hook. "The outcome for people is unfortunately that they will continue to be scammed out of millions of pounds," said Alex Neill, managing director of Which? home and legal services. "We need to see swift action and not see this kicked into the long grass. "When you transfer money from your bank account, you are asked to enter three pieces of information:  The name of the payee, their account number, and the sort code. However only the last two are cross-checked by the bank. So putting in the correct name is no guarantee that person will get the money.Financial Fraud Action UK offers the following advice:The PSR has already proposed a series of improvements, such as "confirmation of payee", which would enhance payment security.However, such changes are not due to take effect for several years.
sample_text: "Push fraud is a devastating crime that can leave people financially ruined and emotionally traumatized," said Caroline Normand, Director of Advocacy at Which?. "It is unacceptable that the PSR has not taken stronger action to hold banks accountable for reimbursing victims of this type of fraud."The super complaint, lodged by Which? in 2020, highlighted the growing problem of push fraud, where criminals pose as trusted organizations, such as banks or government agencies, and convince victims to transfer large sums of money to fraudulent accounts. According to Which?, push fraud has resulted in losses of over £400 million in the past year alone.While the PSR acknowledged the seriousness of the issue, it stopped short of recommending mandatory compensation for victims, citing concerns about the potential impact on banks' business models and the need for further research.Instead, the regulator proposed a series of measures aimed at improving the way banks respond to push fraud, including better customer education, improved fraud detection, and more effective communication between banks and customers.However, consumer advocates argue that these measures do not go far enough and that banks should be held accountable for reimbursing victims of push fraud."Banks have a responsibility to protect their customers' money and should be liable for losses incurred as a result of push fraud," said Normand. "The PSR's decision is a missed opportunity to provide real protection for consumers and we urge them to reconsider their stance."The issue is likely to continue to be a source of controversy, with many calling for greater action to be taken to protect consumers from this type of fraud.
sample_text2: The PSR's decision has sparked outrage among consumer advocates and lawmakers, who argue that the regulator's inaction will only embolden criminals and leave victims without recourse."This is a dereliction of duty by the PSR," said Labour MP, Rachel Reeves, who chairs the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee. "Banks have a responsibility to protect their customers' money, and it's unacceptable that the regulator is not holding them to account. We need to see tougher action to prevent push fraud and ensure that victims are compensated."The issue has also raised concerns about the lack of consistency in how banks respond to push fraud cases. While some banks have voluntarily reimbursed victims, others have refused, citing the fact that the customer authorized the transfer."This is a postcode lottery for victims of push fraud," said James Daley, founder of Fairer Finance. "Some banks are doing the right thing and reimbursing victims, while others are leaving them high and dry. We need a clear and consistent approach to ensure that all victims are treated fairly."The PSR's decision has also been criticized for failing to address the root causes of push fraud. Experts argue that the regulator's focus on customer education and fraud detection is misplaced, and that more needs to be done to tackle the underlying issues that allow push fraud to thrive."Push fraud is a symptom of a broader problem with the banking system," said Dr. Anna Ross, a fraud expert at the University of Cambridge. "We need to look at why criminals are able to open fraudulent accounts and move money around with such ease. Until we address these underlying issues, we'll continue to see push fraud cases rise."As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the issue of push fraud is not going away anytime soon. With losses mounting and victims left without recourse, the pressure is on the PSR and banks to take stronger action to prevent this devastating crime.In the meantime, consumers are being urged to remain vigilant and take steps to protect themselves from push fraud. This includes being wary of unsolicited calls or messages, verifying the identity of callers, and never transferring money to unknown accounts.But for many, the damage has already been done. Victims of push fraud are left to pick up the pieces, often with little hope of recovering their losses."It's a nightmare that I wouldn't wish on anyone," said Sarah, a victim of push fraud who lost £10,000 to a scammer posing as a bank employee. "I thought I was doing the right thing, but it turned out to be a lie. I just want to see justice done and for banks to take responsibility for their role in this crime."

"It is unacceptable that the PSR has not taken stronger action to hold banks accountable for reimbursing victims of this type of fraud."The super complaint, lodged by Which? in 2020, highlighted the growing problem of push fraud, where criminals pose as trusted organizations, such as banks or government agencies, and convince victims to transfer large sums of money to fraudulent accounts. According to Which?, push fraud has resulted in losses of over £400 million in the past year alone.While the PSR acknowledged the seriousness of the issue, it stopped short of recommending mandatory compensation for victims, citing concerns about the potential impact on banks' business models and the need for further research.Instead, the regulator proposed a series of measures aimed at improving the way banks respond to push fraud, including better customer education, improved fraud detection, and more effective communication between banks and customers.However, consumer advocates argue that these measures do not go far enough and that banks should be held accountable for reimbursing victims of push fraud."Banks have a responsibility to protect their customers' money and should be liable for losses incurred as a result of push fraud," said Normand. "The PSR's decision is a missed opportunity to provide real protection for consumers and we urge them to reconsider their stance."The issue is likely to continue to be a source of controversy, with many calling for greater action to be taken to protect consumers from this type of fraud. The PSR's decision has sparked outrage among consumer advocates and lawmakers, who argue that the regulator's inaction will only embolden criminals and leave victims without recourse."This is a dereliction of duty by the PSR," said Labour MP, Rachel Reeves, who chairs the Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy Committee. "Banks have a responsibility to protect their customers' money, and it's unacceptable that the regulator is not holding them to account.

first_sentence: It said profits this year would be at the low end of expectations, while next year it would face £650m of "headwinds" - more than previously forecast.Rolls-Royce is carrying out a review of its business, which it said was likely to involve job losses among its 2,000 senior managers.It has previously announced 3,600 job cuts across the group.Rolls-Royce also said it would review of its shareholder payments policy, signalling the possibility that dividend payments could be cut.At the end of trading, shares in Rolls-Royce were down 130.5p at 536.5p.
text: The company's shares have now nearly halved since April.In July, the company warned lower deliveries of its Trent 700 engine would affect profits in 2016 and 2017.It also said at the time that profits in 2015 would be between £1.325bn and £1.475bn.Warren East, who was appointed chief executive of Rolls-Royce in April, said: "The speed and magnitude of change in some of our markets, which have historically performed well, has been significant and shows how sensitive parts of our business are to market conditions in the short-term. "Rolls-Royce said there were three areas where it had seen demand weaken - corporate jets powered by Rolls-Royce engines, servicing of the firm's wide-bodied engines, and offshore marine markets.Rolls-Royce has been badly affected by a decline in its main aircraft engine business. It says that although demand for new engines for large passenger aircraft remains unchanged, many airlines have been sidelining their older planes in favour of modern, more fuel efficient models.As a result, profits from supplying spare parts and servicing have fallen significantly. In addition, sales of engines for corporate jets have declined sharply.Meanwhile the low price of oil has taken a heavy toll on Rolls-Royce marine engine business, largely because of falling demand from offshore energy companies.Mr East, who is carrying out a structural review of the business, added Rolls-Royce carried "too much fixed cost" and was "inflexible in managing this in response to changes in market conditions".He is looking for annual cost savings of between £150 and £200m, of which £115m cost savings are expected to come from the company's aerospace and marine division in 2016.More details on the structural review of the company will be announced later in November, Rolls said.Keith Bowman, equity analyst at Hargreaves Lansdown stockbrokers, said yet another profit warning from Rolls had "shocked investors", adding that the review of its shareholder payments policy was "a major negative".He said: "The company's prior push to reduce earnings volatility and surprises looks to have been completely unwound, with investors today suffering another major setback. "Rebuilding confidence in the company's outlook is now paramount for the relatively new chief executive."
sample_text: Rolls-Royce's CEO, Warren East, attributed the revised forecast to a combination of factors, including a decline in demand for its civil aerospace products and increased costs associated with resolving issues with its Trent 1000 engine."We are taking decisive action to address the challenges we are facing," East said in a statement. "Our review of the business will ensure we are operating as efficiently as possible, and we will take all necessary steps to restore our financial performance."The company's announcement comes on the heels of a tumultuous year, marked by a series of profit warnings and a major restructuring effort. Rolls-Royce has been working to revamp its operations and reduce costs, but the latest forecast suggests that more drastic measures may be needed.Analysts were quick to weigh in on the news, with many expressing disappointment and concern over the company's prospects. "This is a major setback for Rolls-Royce, and it's clear that the company still has a lot of work to do to get back on track," said one analyst.The news also sparked concerns about the impact on the UK economy, as Rolls-Royce is a major employer and contributor to the country's manufacturing sector. "This is a worrying development for the UK economy, and we urge the government to take steps to support the company and its workers during this difficult time," said a spokesperson for the Unite union.As the company navigates this challenging period, all eyes will be on East and his team to see if they can successfully turn things around and restore Rolls-Royce to its former glory. One thing is certain, however: the road ahead will be long and difficult, and the company will need to make some tough decisions to ensure its survival.
sample_text2: Rolls-Royce's revised forecast has also raised concerns about the company's ability to meet its long-term goals, including its ambition to become a leader in the electrification of aircraft. The company has been investing heavily in electric propulsion technology, but the latest setback has cast doubt on its ability to achieve its targets."This is a major blow to Rolls-Royce's electrification plans," said another analyst. "The company was already facing significant technical and financial challenges in this area, and this latest news will only add to the uncertainty."The UK government has also been quick to respond to the news, with a spokesperson for the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy saying that they are "monitoring the situation closely" and are "committed to supporting the UK's aerospace industry".However, some critics have argued that the government needs to do more to support Rolls-Royce and the wider aerospace industry. "This is a critical moment for the UK's manufacturing sector, and the government needs to take decisive action to support Rolls-Royce and its workers," said a spokesperson for the Labour Party.As the company navigates this challenging period, it is clear that the road ahead will be long and difficult. Rolls-Royce will need to make some tough decisions to ensure its survival, including potentially cutting jobs and reducing costs.But despite the challenges, there are still reasons to be optimistic about the company's future. Rolls-Royce has a long history of innovation and has overcome significant challenges in the past. With the right support and leadership, it is possible that the company can emerge from this difficult period stronger and more resilient than ever.In the meantime, all eyes will be on Warren East and his team to see if they can successfully turn things around and restore Rolls-Royce to its former glory. The company's future may be uncertain, but one thing is clear: the next few months will be crucial in determining the direction of this iconic British brand.

first_sentence: General Sir Richard Shirreff, Nato's deputy supreme commander from 2011-2014, says the US President-elect should re-dedicate himself to the common defence of the western allies soon after his inauguration in January.The general says Mr Trump must send the "strongest possible signal …that America will, no ifs, no buts, no prevarication, come to the aid of a Nato member if attacked".If that doesn't happen, Gen Shirreff warns, it "will strike right at the heart of Nato's founding principle of collective defence".Alexander Vershbow, an American career diplomat who was Nato's Deputy Secretary-General from 2012-2016, says the election of the new president sends a clear signal to European members of the pact who have been under-investing in their defence.
text: "This was a change election in the United States," Mr Vershbow told the BBC, "so there will be change and I think allies have to be prepared to adapt. "During the campaign Mr Trump said of unspecified Nato allies: "They're not paying their way". He suggested that, if one of them was attacked, the US would be entitled to ask "have they paid?" before deciding to go to their assistance.The use of this language has caused alarm in many Nato capitals.There is also concern about suggestions that Mr Trump, as part of a rapprochement with Russia, might be prepared to concede a "zone of influence" to the Kremlin in former Soviet republics, or to reduce pressure over the issue of Ukraine. "Ratifying the results of Russian aggression in Ukraine would buy you some short term stability," said Mr Vershbow, when asked about the possibility that Mr Trump might accept the Kremlin calling the shots in eastern Europe in return for better relations. "But I think it would create a much more unstable situation in Europe, encourage the Russians to continue to press forward for some kind of Yalta 2 with a new division of Europe into spheres of influence, which I think would bring back some of the instability we saw in previous decades. "Prior to his Nato role, Mr Vershbow was US ambassador to Moscow from 2001-2005.Acquiescing to further Russian operations in Ukraine (which is not a Nato member) might send a signal that the president-elect effectively recognises Russia's right to dominate certain neighbouring states, many Nato decision-makers feel.They fear also a possible knock-on effect in former Soviet republics that are now part of Nato (and indeed the European Union), the Baltic republics of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. "There must be absolutely no doubt about the imperative of defending and protecting Nato territory. There must be no discussion or deals about zones of influence, new Yaltas," says Gen Shirreff, "because that strikes right at the heart of what Nato is about".
sample_text: Vershbow stated in an exclusive interview. "The era of relying solely on the US to provide for their security is coming to an end."Both General Shirreff and Mr. Vershbow's warnings come as concerns grow about the implications of a Trump presidency on the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). During his campaign, Mr. Trump repeatedly questioned the relevance and effectiveness of the alliance, suggesting that the US may not come to the aid of member states if they are attacked.General Shirreff, a decorated British Army officer, emphasized that a strong commitment to NATO's collective defence principle is crucial in the face of an increasingly aggressive Russia. "The Russians are watching very closely, and if they sense any wavering or hesitation on the part of the US, they will exploit it," he warned.Mr. Vershbow, who has served in various senior roles in the US government, including as Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs, echoed General Shirreff's concerns. "If the US signals that it is no longer committed to NATO's collective defence, it will create a power vacuum that Russia will be only too happy to fill," he said.The warnings from the two senior officials come as NATO member states are already grappling with the challenges of a resurgent Russia. In recent years, Russia has annexed Crimea, supported separatist rebels in eastern Ukraine, and engaged in a series of provocative military exercises along NATO's borders.In response to these challenges, NATO has taken steps to bolster its military presence in Eastern Europe, including the deployment of troops and equipment to Poland and the Baltic states. However, the alliance still faces significant challenges in terms of its military capabilities and readiness.General Shirreff and Mr. Vershbow's comments are likely to add to the growing pressure on Mr. Trump to clarify his administration's stance on NATO and its commitment to the alliance's collective defence principle. As the President-elect prepares to take office, the eyes of the world will be watching to see whether he will reaffirm the US's commitment to NATO or chart a new course that could have far-reaching implications for global security.

first_sentence: Defeat at Hampden next month would end hopes of reaching the play-offs and Strachan is wary of overzealousness.
text: "Emotional players can cause you bother and until now and I am sure it will continue, we have been focused rather than emotional," said Strachan. "We can only deal with the games we are involved in. The first one against Poland is going to be a huge game. "Scotland sit fourth in Group D going into their final two fixtures against the Poles on 8 October and Gibraltar in Portugal three days later.After losing to Georgia and Germany in their last double-header, Scotland are four points behind Republic of Ireland, six behind Poland and eight behind leaders Germany as they strive for third place. "We are still in there," said Strachan. "We can't deal with what happens elsewhere. "It is going to be a great occasion, a fantastic occasion, a pressurised occasion but we like that as footballers. "The whole nation was disappointed (after last two results), which is understandable. "We are up for it again, that is the good thing about us. "Scotland beat Poland 1-0 in a Warsaw friendly in March 2014 before a 2-2 draw at the same venue seven months later in Group D.Poland's star striker Robert Lewandowski is in great form with seven goals in his last two games for Bayern Munich and Strachan described the 27-year-old as "world class". "They are a good side, they have improved immensely since we played them in a friendly two years ago," he added. "We know he's [Lewandowski] there but we managed to score two against them over there with him in the team. "We don't have a world class player but we have a great bunch of lads and we know we have to work as a group. "Strachan is out of contract at the end of the campaign but insists he is not looking any further than the next two matches. "I have never thought about my future wherever I have been in football," he said. "I just continue and see where I end up. It's good fun, you know. "We will speak about it once it (the campaign) is out of the way. The games are far more important than me. "I love football and I love what I am doing now, that is for sure. "But as I say we will talk about it when we finish this campaign and hopefully it has another few months to run now."
sample_text: The national team boss is all too aware of the importance of the October 8th clash, and is cautioning against complacency after a hard-fought 2-0 win over Malta on Monday. Strachan knows that a defeat at Hampden Park would all but extinguish Scotland's hopes of reaching the play-offs, and is urging his players to remain focused and disciplined."We can't get ahead of ourselves," Strachan warned in a press conference yesterday. "We've had a good result against Malta, but we know that Slovenia will be a much tougher proposition. We need to stay grounded and make sure we're prepared for what will be a very difficult game."Strachan's words of caution come as Scotland's players begin to return to their clubs, with the manager keen to ensure that his squad remains fully concentrated on the task at hand. With Slovenia currently sitting in second place in Group F, just two points behind leaders England, Strachan knows that his team will need to be at the top of their game if they are to secure the three points they so desperately need."We've got a lot of work to do between now and the Slovenia game," Strachan admitted. "We'll be working hard on the training pitch to make sure we're ready for what will be a massive test. The players know what's at stake, and I'm confident that they'll be fully focused on getting the job done."Despite the importance of the match, Strachan is refusing to get drawn into talk of must-win scenarios, instead choosing to focus on the process rather than the outcome. "We can't control the result, but we can control our preparation and our performance," he said. "If we can get those things right, then we'll give ourselves the best chance of getting the result we need."
sample_text2: Strachan's cautious approach is likely to be music to the ears of Scotland fans, who have been burned by false dawns in the past. The national team's recent history is littered with instances of promising performances being followed by disappointing defeats, and Strachan is determined to avoid a repeat of that pattern.One area where Strachan will be looking for improvement is in Scotland's attacking play. Despite dominating possession against Malta, the Scots struggled to create clear-cut chances, and relied on a pair of set pieces to secure the win. With Slovenia likely to be more resolute in defense, Strachan knows that his team will need to be more clinical in front of goal if they are to take all three points."We need to be more creative and more ruthless in the final third," Strachan acknowledged. "We had a lot of possession against Malta, but we didn't create as many chances as we would have liked. That's something we'll be working on in training, and I'm confident that we can improve in that area."Strachan also hinted that he may make changes to his starting lineup for the Slovenia game, with several players pushing for inclusion. The likes of Matt Phillips, James Forrest, and Oliver Burke will all be hoping to feature prominently, and Strachan is keen to keep his options open."We've got a good squad, and everyone will be given a chance to stake their claim," he said. "We'll be looking at the players who performed well against Malta, but we'll also be looking at the players who didn't feature. We need to make sure we've got the right balance and the right personnel to get the job done."As the countdown to the Slovenia game continues, Strachan's message to his players is clear: stay focused, stay disciplined, and stay grounded. With the stakes higher than ever, Scotland's national team boss is determined to lead his team to victory, and take a giant step towards the World Cup playoffs.

first_sentence: The Three network is also not currently offering exchanges, while O2 said it was still not selling the smartphone.Samsung has cut production of the Note 7 after several reports of replacement models overheating and emitting smoke.The Note 7 went on sale in the UK days before Samsung issued a recall, and sales have so far been limited.Over the weekend it emerged that a second Note 7 replacement device, deemed safe by the company, had caught fire in America.
text: "Following recent media reports of further Note 7 issues in the US and Canada, we have suspended Note 7 exchanges and are currently in direct contact with Samsung regarding next steps on the matter," EE said.Cellan-Jones: Samsung's burning issueWhy do lithium batteries explode?A Vodafone spokesman said it had paused pre-orders of the Note 7 as well as its device replacement programme "until such time that we receive satisfactory assurances from Samsung about the safety of the Galaxy Note 7".Three also told the BBC it was "currently assessing the situation with Samsung and we will be seeking guidance from them before we resume any further exchanges of the Note 7".O2 said it has not been selling the phone since September, when Samsung advised there would be an exchange programme. "We are currently in discussions with Samsung and reviewing our options," it added.Carphone Warehouse said it was also in talks with Samsung about the phone.The moves come after the three biggest US mobile operators, as well as networks in Australia and Asia, stopped replacing or selling the phone.They took action after a man in Kentucky said he woke up to a bedroom full of smoke from a replaced Note 7, days after a domestic flight in the US was evacuated after a new device started emitting smoke in the cabin.US networks AT&T, Verizon and T-Mobile said they would no longer replace the devices, while the latter said it would halt all sales of the phone. "While Samsung investigates multiple reports of issues, T-Mobile is temporarily suspending all sales of the new Note 7 and exchanges for replacement Note 7 devices," T-Mobile said on its website.Meanwhile, AT&T said: "We're no longer exchanging new Note 7s at this time, pending further investigation of these reported incidents." It advised customers to exchange them for other devices.Samsung said on Monday that it was "adjusting the production schedule" in response to moves by the US and other networks. "We continue to move quickly to investigate the reported case to determine the cause and will share findings as soon as possible," Samsung said.
sample_text: The passenger, who was reportedly using a replacement Note 7, claimed that the phone began to emit smoke and heat up while the plane was preparing for takeoff.Following the incident, Samsung announced that it would be temporarily halting production of the Note 7, citing concerns about the safety of the device. The company has also urged customers to stop using the phone and to return it to the place of purchase for a full refund.The move has been seen as a major blow to Samsung, which had been hoping to recover from the initial recall of the Note 7. The company had issued a global recall of the device in September, after reports of the phone's battery overheating and catching fire.In the UK, mobile operators have been quick to respond to the latest developments. EE and Vodafone have both announced that they will no longer be selling the Note 7, while Three has said that it will not be offering exchanges for customers who have already purchased the device.O2 has gone one step further, announcing that it will not be selling the Note 7 at all. "We take the safety of our customers very seriously, and in light of the recent incidents, we have decided not to sell the Samsung Galaxy Note 7," a spokesperson for the company said.The news has left many customers who have already purchased the Note 7 wondering what to do next. Samsung has set up a dedicated website and hotline for customers to return their devices and receive a refund or exchange.However, some customers have expressed frustration at the lack of clarity from Samsung and mobile operators about the recall process. "I'm still not sure what I'm supposed to do with my Note 7," said one customer. "I've tried contacting Samsung and my mobile operator, but no one seems to know what's going on."The incident has also raised questions about the safety of lithium-ion batteries, which are used in many modern smartphones. Experts have warned that the recall of the Note 7 could have far-reaching implications for the entire smartphone industry.As the situation continues to unfold, one thing is clear: the Samsung Galaxy Note 7 has become a major embarrassment for the company, and a cautionary tale about the importance of safety in the design and manufacture of consumer electronics.

first_sentence: Annual test results should be replaced in the tables by a three-year rolling average to "lower the stakes", says the Commons Education Select Committee.The current system has led to a narrow curriculum and "unnecessary stress" on pupils and teachers, argues the report.Last year, new tougher tests for 11-year-olds saw passes drop sharply.Ministers maintain that parents have a right to expect testing in schools to show whether their children are gaining the right skills in maths and literacy.But the committee says the close link between the tests at 11 and school accountability can "lead to a narrowing of the curriculum and 'teaching to the test', as well as affecting teacher and pupil well-being".It wants the current system scrapped, with three-year rolling averages for schools published instead of the results of individual year groups.The report also calls for greater emphasis in Ofsted inspections on a broad and balanced curriculum.Committee chairman Neil Carmichael said too much emphasis on test results had led to too much "focus on English and maths at the expense of other subjects like science, humanities and the arts".
text: "It is right that schools are held to account for their performance but the government should act to lower the stakes and help teachers to deliver a broad, balanced and fulfilling curriculum for primary school children. "The report says poor implementation of the new system last year, with "guidance delayed and test papers leaked online", caused significant disruption in schools.The MPs want ministers to reconsider the new writing assessment which emphasises "technical aspects like grammar and spelling, over creativity and composition". "The balance of evidence we received did not support the proposition that focusing on specific grammatical techniques improved the overall quality of writing. "They also want spelling, punctuation and grammar tests for 11-year-olds to become non-statutory.Ministers recently announced proposals to scrap tests for seven-year-olds, following years of pressure from teachers, parents and educationalists.The Department for Education is consulting on a new assessment for pupils when they first start school - but the report urges caution when introducing a "baseline" measure. "It should be designed as a diagnostic tool to help teachers identify pupils' needs and must avoid shifting negative consequences of high-stakes accountability to early years," they warn.A Department for Education spokeswoman said the government would consider the report carefully and respond in due course.Ofsted Chief Inspector Amanda Spielman said inspectors already looked for a broad curriculum in every primary school, adding that she had recently announced new research into "how the accountability system, including Ofsted, can encourage the development of a rich curriculum".Russell Hobby, National Association of Head Teachers General Secretary, called last year's tests "a mess of chaos and confusion". "Add into this the high-stakes nature of the system for school leaders, and you get a toxic mix. "Mr Hobby said the union had contributed to the government's proposals "to begin creating a primary assessment system that works". "This report helpfully sets the agenda for the next stage of this debate," he added.
sample_text: "The high-stakes nature of the current system has led to unnecessary stress and anxiety for both teachers and pupils," said Carmichael. "We need to move away from a system that prioritizes test results over the well-being of our children and the professionalism of our teachers."The committee's recommendations have been welcomed by teaching unions, who have long argued that the current system is too narrow and focuses too much on testing. "This report is a damning indictment of the government's education policy," said Mary Bousted, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers. "The emphasis on testing has led to a curriculum that is too narrow and too focused on rote learning, rather than creativity and critical thinking."However, the government has expressed reservations about the committee's proposals. A spokesperson for the Department for Education said, "We understand the concerns about the current system, but we believe that testing is an important way to ensure that children are meeting the necessary standards in maths and literacy. We will consider the committee's recommendations carefully, but we are not convinced that a three-year rolling average is the right solution."The debate over testing and accountability in schools is likely to continue, with many arguing that the current system needs a radical overhaul. As Carmichael said, "We need to get back to a system that values the whole child, not just their test results. Our children deserve a broad and balanced education that prepares them for life, not just a series of exams."The committee's report is the latest in a series of criticisms of the government's education policy. Last year, the National Association of Head Teachers called for a boycott of the SATs tests, citing concerns about the impact on pupil well-being and the narrow focus of the curriculum. The government has also faced criticism over its plans to introduce more grammar schools, which many argue will exacerbate social segregation and inequality.As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the current system of testing and accountability in schools is in need of reform. The question is, what will replace it, and how will we ensure that our children receive the education they deserve?

The government has also faced criticism over its plans to introduce more grammar schools, which many argue will exacerbate social segregation and inequality.As the debate continues, one thing is clear: the current system of testing and accountability in schools is in need of reform.

first_sentence: Holyrood's education committee took evidence on support for pupils with additional needs.Sylvia Haughney, a support for learning instructor, said there was not enough teacher training.She said a support worker had been advised to watch American sitcom The Big Bang Theory as a form of training.Colin Crawford, head of inclusion in the council's education services department, accepted there may need to be a review of what training teachers need, but said this should apply when they are at college as much as when working in schools.The Big Bang Theory is a popular American sitcom focusing on a group of highly intelligent but socially inept "nerds".One character in particular, Sheldon Cooper, is often singled out by viewers as behaving in a manner consistent with Asperger syndrome, a developmental disorder on the autism spectrum.However, the programme's creators have stated that they did not use the syndrome as a basis while creating the character, having said they are "uncomfortable labelling" him as having Asperger's.Ms Haughney, who has been a support for learning instructor in Glasgow for over 34 years and represents the union Unison, said there had been much better training for dealing with pupils with additional needs when she was going into the profession.She said: "We were given the training, so we had an understanding.
text: It was direct training, from a psychologist, from a speech language therapist, to give us an understanding and a knowledge of what we were looking for, who we were dealing with and how to go to the next step with that pupil. "That is just gone. We have this 'cascading' training, from someone coming and saying 'oh I went on a course, and this is what we do'. "Recently I was in a school and I asked a member of staff who was working specifically with a child with Asperger's, what training have you had in Asperger's? 'I was told to watch The Big Bang Theory'. "That's the level of training that we've got now in schools. "Ms Haughney later said the issue of using cascading in lieu of direct training was "really serious", adding that "if someone has bad practice, they are passing on bad practice".Prof Sheila Riddell from the University of Edinburgh added that the training for children with additional support needs is "very, very patchy in Scotland".Mr Crawford said there needed to be "creative thinking" about training, amid "huge challenges" of upskilling a large workforce.He said the council worked with other organisations to deliver training, with online courses available too.He said: "There are a range of developmental checklists, some of which are extremely useful in terms of child development. "But what I wanted to say is I think there are also issues here in terms of initial teacher training, and the training that's offered at colleges to support staff, in terms of upskilling them before they go into the profession. It's not necessarily always down to local authority training once staff are in place. "There's a stage before that which needs to be addressed as well in the preparation for going in to working with children and young people. "Later in the session he added: "We've focused a lot on training this morning, but what training? Maybe it's about, are we needing to think about a training needs analysis of all staff that would give us that baseline of exactly what training staff need to make them feel more confident in the day to day job that they're doing."
sample_text: But now, it seems that the training is very much lacking. I've even heard of a support worker being told to watch The Big Bang Theory as a form of training, which is just not acceptable."Ms. Haughney expressed her concern that the lack of proper training is affecting the ability of teachers and support staff to provide adequate support to pupils with additional needs. "It's not just about understanding the condition, it's about knowing how to adapt your teaching methods, how to communicate effectively, and how to create a supportive environment. Without that training, we're failing these children," she said.Colin Crawford, head of inclusion in the council's education services department, acknowledged that there may be a need to review the training provided to teachers, but suggested that this should start at the college level, rather than just focusing on in-service training. "We need to ensure that our teachers are equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to support pupils with additional needs from the outset. This should be a fundamental part of their initial teacher training, rather than something that's tacked on later," he said.The education committee's inquiry into support for pupils with additional needs is ongoing, with further evidence to be heard in the coming weeks. The committee is expected to make recommendations to the Scottish Government on how to improve support for these pupils.In the meantime, Ms. Haughney and other education professionals are calling for urgent action to address the training gap. "We can't afford to wait any longer," she said. "These children deserve the best possible support, and it's our responsibility as educators to provide it."
sample_text2: **Urgent Call for Improved Training for Teachers and Support Staff**The lack of adequate training for teachers and support staff to support pupils with additional needs has sparked widespread concern among education professionals. The issue was highlighted during an inquiry into support for pupils with additional needs, led by the education committee.Ms. Haughney, a special educational needs (SEN) teacher, expressed her frustration at the lack of proper training, citing an example of a support worker being told to watch The Big Bang Theory as a form of training. "This is not acceptable," she said. "We need to ensure that our teachers and support staff have the necessary skills and knowledge to provide adequate support to pupils with additional needs."Colin Crawford, head of inclusion in the council's education services department, acknowledged that there may be a need to review the training provided to teachers. However, he suggested that this should start at the college level, rather than just focusing on in-service training. "We need to ensure that our teachers are equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to support pupils with additional needs from the outset," he said.The education committee's inquiry has heard evidence from a range of stakeholders, including teachers, support staff, and parents of children with additional needs. The committee is expected to make recommendations to the Scottish Government on how to improve support for these pupils.**Consequences of Inadequate Training**The lack of adequate training has serious consequences for pupils with additional needs. Without proper support, these pupils may struggle to reach their full potential, leading to a range of negative outcomes, including lower academic achievement, social isolation, and decreased self-esteem.Furthermore, the lack of training can also lead to burnout and frustration among teachers and support staff, who may feel ill-equipped to provide the necessary support. This can result in high staff turnover rates, which can be detrimental to the overall quality of education.**Calls for Urgent Action**Education professionals are calling for urgent action to address the training gap. "We can't afford to wait any longer," said Ms. Haughney. "These children deserve the best possible support, and it's our responsibility as educators to provide it."The Scottish Government has been urged to take immediate action to improve training for teachers and support staff. This includes providing additional funding for training programs, developing new resources and materials, and working with education professionals to develop a comprehensive training framework.As the inquiry continues, it is clear that the issue of inadequate training for teachers and support staff is a critical one that requires immediate attention. The future of Scotland's most vulnerable pupils depends on it.
