Without that training, we're failing these children," she said.Colin Crawford, head of inclusion in the council's education services department, acknowledged that there may be a need to review the training provided to teachers, but suggested that this should start at the college level, rather than just focusing on in-service training. "We need to ensure that our teachers are equipped with the skills and knowledge they need to support pupils with additional needs from the outset. This should be a fundamental part of their initial teacher training, rather than something that's tacked on later," he said.The education committee's inquiry into support for pupils with additional needs is ongoing, with further evidence to be heard in the coming weeks. The committee is expected to make recommendations to the Scottish Government on how to improve support for these pupils.In the meantime, Ms. Haughney and other education professionals are calling for urgent action to address the training gap. "We can't afford to wait any longer," she said. "These children deserve the best possible support, and it's our responsibility as educators to provide it." **Urgent Call for Improved Training for Teachers and Support Staff**The lack of adequate training for teachers and support staff to support pupils with additional needs has sparked widespread concern among education professionals. The issue was highlighted during an inquiry into support for pupils with additional needs, led by the education committee.Ms. Haughney, a special educational needs (SEN) teacher, expressed her frustration at the lack of proper training, citing an example of a support worker being told to watch The Big Bang Theory as a form of training. "This is not acceptable," she said.

first_sentence: Ed Brown QC told the Old Bailey a 999 call where Ben Butler could be heard trying to save Ellie Butler's life was a "truly impressive performance".Mr Butler, 36, of Sutton, said he delayed calling an ambulance after he found Ellie lifeless on her bedroom floor because he "panicked".He denies murder and child cruelty.During the 10 minute emergency call, Mr Butler can be heard shouting "this is serious" and "she's not breathing" before his partner Jennie Gray is talked through CPR by the call handler.The prosecutor said to Mr Butler that he was "blaming the 999 operator for delaying" but he had "sat on her death for two hours, because you killed her".He added that Mr Butler knew that the emergency call was being recorded, to which the defendant replied "yeah".The jury have previously heard the pair delayed calling an ambulance for two hours after Ellie died.
text: "I suggest the story that you and Jennie Gray had agreed upon was largely in place by now," Mr Brown said.However, Mr Butler said the delay and his actions during the call were "more of a heat of the moment thing". "What happened in 2007 was the reason I reacted like that," he said.Mr Butler was previously wrongfully convicted for shaking Ellie as a baby in 2007. The couple then went to the High Court to get Ellie returned to their care.The Everton football fan compared his case to the fight for justice for victims of the Hillsborough disaster and commented about a documentary he had watched. "The families there were fighting for justice like we were. Lady come on and said the problem you don't see is the ripple effect the one action has on everyone's life. "That 2007 (conviction) had a ripple effect on everyone's life. "The prosecutor Ed Brown said Mr Butler was "determined to deflect the case from the evidence".He called the abusive text messages he had sent to Ms Gray, which have been read out to the jury, "vile", adding: "There's nothing I'm going to say that makes it acceptable. It's not acceptable. I'm sorry to Jennie and I let her down. "Mr Butler denied rowing in front of Ellie and insisted he was not on trial for abusing Ms Gray, to which the prosecutor reminded him he was caught on video shouting on the phone with Ellie standing at his side.The defendant replied that it "spilled out every now and again" in front of their daughter.The trial continues.
sample_text: Butler's actions during the 999 call were a deliberate attempt to deceive the emergency services and create a false narrative. "You were trying to create a scenario where it looked like you were trying to save Ellie's life, but in reality, you had already killed her," Mr. Brown alleged.Mr. Butler maintained that he had panicked after finding Ellie lifeless on her bedroom floor and had delayed calling for help because he was in shock. However, the prosecutor pointed out that the defendant had shown no signs of panic or distress during the call, instead speaking calmly and clearly to the operator.The jury was played a recording of the 999 call, during which Mr. Butler can be heard shouting "this is serious" and "she's not breathing" before his partner, Jennie Gray, is talked through CPR by the call handler. The prosecutor suggested that Mr. Butler's tone and language during the call were inconsistent with someone who was genuinely trying to save a life.Mr. Brown also highlighted the fact that Mr. Butler had waited two hours before calling for an ambulance, despite claiming that he had found Ellie unresponsive. "You sat on her death for two hours, because you killed her," the prosecutor alleged. "You knew exactly what you were doing, and you knew that the 999 call was being recorded."The defendant denied the allegations, insisting that he had panicked and delayed calling for help because he was in shock. However, the prosecutor's questioning raised further doubts about Mr. Butler's version of events, and the jury will continue to deliberate on the evidence presented in the case.Ellie Butler, 6, was found dead in her bedroom in 2013. Her father, Ben Butler, is accused of murdering her and faces charges of murder and child cruelty. The trial continues.

first_sentence: Harriers led 2-0 at the break after Arthur Gnahoua's opener was quickly followed by Harry White's penalty for a handball decision against Ryan Lloyd.But Chester top scorer Ross Hannah got one back from the spot on 66 minutes after being fouled by Kelvin Langmead.Substitute James Alabi then turned inside the box to blast home a stunning 76th-minute right-foot equaliser.Both sides had chances to win it, as Hannah screwed wide before Tyrone Williams was then denied by a superb low late fingertip save by Chester keeper Tony Thompson.Harriers, whop have lost just once in five games, remain second from bottom, nine points adrift of safety.Chester, who move seven points clear of trouble, picked up their fourth point on the road in five days, having previously gone four months without an away league win.Chester's comeback was the second season running they have come back from 2-0 down to draw 2-2 at Aggborough.Last term's early season encounter marked City boss Steve Burr's first visit back to his old club.
text: The visitors also quickly went two down that day, only to fight back to draw 2-2, despite the setback of Chris Iwelumo missing an early second-half penalty.Chester manager Steve Burr told BBC Radio Merseyside:Media playback is not supported on this device"I was looking for us to kick on after winning at Altrincham on Tuesday and I think my lads thought they'd just turn up and put one over them. "But Kiddy are in good form, playing with a lot of confidence and it took us 45 minutes to get into gear. In the end, we put a lot of determination and effort into a game that looked lost and could have won it, but then so could they, but for a great save by Tony Thompson at the end. "It was great for James Alabi to score a goal like that right in front of all our away fans. It's been frustrating, as he picked up a groin injury a week after coming and we've been trying to get him out there, but he showed what he's capable of. "Harriers boss Colin Gordon told BBC Hereford & Worcester:"We got very tired and leggy and were unable to keep the tempo going that we had in the first half. That's to be expected in a young team. "But we kept going and finished the game with corners and shots. It was our intent to go and win, not just sit back and take a 2-2. That shows our intent. "The referee maybe felt it was harsh with our penalty, although it did come up and hit his hand, so he has evened it up, but two wrongs don't make a right for me. It was a baffling decision. If that's a penalty then there are going to be a thousand a week."
sample_text: The result marked a significant milestone for the visitors, who had gone 16 games without an away win in the league before their recent upturn in form.For Harriers, the draw was a bitter pill to swallow, as they were left to rue a series of missed opportunities to put the game beyond Chester's reach. Despite taking a commanding lead into the break, they were unable to capitalize on their dominance, and were ultimately punished for their profligacy in front of goal.The home side's manager, Mark Yates, was left to lament his team's inability to see out the game, saying "We were in control for large periods of the match, but we just couldn't get that third goal to kill the game off. Credit to Chester, they kept going and got their reward in the end."In contrast, Chester boss Jon McCarthy was thrilled with his team's never-say-die attitude, praising their "character and spirit" in the face of adversity. "We knew it was going to be a tough game, but we showed great resilience to come back from 2-0 down," he said. "It's a great point for us, and it's a testament to the progress we've made as a team."The result leaves Harriers still struggling to escape the relegation zone, while Chester can breathe a sigh of relief as they move further clear of danger. However, with the season entering its final stretch, both teams know that there is still much work to be done if they are to achieve their respective goals.

first_sentence: Ireland beat the All Blacks at the 29th attempt in Chicago on Saturday - their 40-29 win bringing to an end the world champions' run of 18 straight triumphs.
text: "I think the boys will put in another serious shift," said Ferris. "That's what it's going to take but confidence will be high," he added. "The whole of Irish rugby was on a high over the weekend but the boys will be aware that the All Blacks can score from anywhere at any stage of the game. "A lot of new faces will come in for this weekend's match with Canada and hopefully we can get the win and then another one against New Zealand the week after. "The ex-British and Irish Lions back-rower was hugely impressed by the display put in by Ireland at Soldier Field, lauding their 40-point haul against the Kiwis, which saw them move up one place in the IRB rankings to fifth, as "unbelievable". "The performance the guys put in, the intensity they played with, the accuracy they played with, was phenomenal," he said. "Rory Best alluded to them doing their homework in knowing what the All Blacks were going to throw at them and they were the better team for 80 minutes. "It wasn't one of those matches where they got lucky with the odd decision. "To score 40 points in any Test match is hard work but to score 40 points against the All Blacks is unbelievable. Fair play to the lads, to a man they stood up well. "British and Irish Lions coach Warren Gatland attended Saturday's match in Chicago and Ferris believes that a number of Irish players boosted their hopes of inclusion in the squad to tour New Zealand next summer. "You see the way Wales were put to the sword by Australia in their own back yard and then Ireland go away from home and put in a ridiculous performance," he said. "For me, there will be a lot more Irish players on Warren Gatland's radar than there were a couple of weeks ago so hopefully there will be a large contingent on the plane to New Zealand in the summer."
sample_text: The monumental victory marked the Irish team's first-ever win over the All Blacks in 29 attempts, and brought an end to New Zealand's impressive 18-match winning streak.The Irish team, led by captain Rory Best, dominated the match from start to finish, with a strong defensive performance and clinical finishing in attack. Fly-half Johnny Sexton was instrumental in the win, kicking 14 points and controlling the tempo of the game with his clever distribution.The All Blacks, who had not lost since August 2015, were stunned by Ireland's intensity and physicality. Despite a late surge in the final 10 minutes, which saw them score two tries, the Kiwis were unable to overcome the deficit.Ireland's coach, Joe Schmidt, was overjoyed with the result, praising his team's bravery and determination. "We've been building towards this for a long time, and to finally get the win is an incredible feeling," Schmidt said in the post-match press conference. "The players were outstanding, and I'm so proud of every single one of them."The win is a significant milestone for Irish rugby, and will give the team a huge boost of confidence ahead of their upcoming autumn internationals. It also marks a turning point in the rivalry between the two teams, with Ireland finally able to claim a scalp over their southern hemisphere rivals.For the All Blacks, the defeat will be a wake-up call ahead of their own autumn schedule. Coach Steve Hansen will be disappointed with his team's performance, particularly in the first half, where they struggled to gain any momentum.The result will send shockwaves through the rugby world, and will be celebrated by Irish fans around the globe. It's a momentous day for Irish rugby, and one that will be remembered for generations to come.

first_sentence: The Leicester rockers are opening the Baftas at the Royal Opera House next month instead of playing at the Brits at London's O2.The 34-year-old guitarist said: "It's a conspiracy.
text: They're trying to shut rock'n'roll out. "What sort of message does that send to working class rock'n'roll bands which the industry is in dire need of? "The band, who won the award for best British group in 2010, didn't get any Brit nominations when they were announced earlier this month.That's despite them being nominated in eight categories for the NME Awards after the release of their fifth studio album 48:13, which topped the Official Albums Chart, and a headline slot at Glastonbury.Pizzorno called the Brits "awful from start to finish" in 2013 while Kasabian singer Tom Meighan described that year's ceremony as "terrible".Talking to the Independent, the guitarist said they had their best year ever in 2014. "Kasabian couldn't have done any more last year. "It's way more exciting to be playing the Baftas than the Brits. "It's a huge honour to open the Baftas because we're all such great film fans. "It'll be a strange old show playing in front of a load of penguins, but it's going to be great. "We're going to start the night off with a huge explosion. We're going to play everything twice as loud. "Half the people there won't have a clue what is going on. "Alt-J, Clean Bandit, Coldplay, One Direction and Royal Blood are up for best group at this year's Brits while the album of the year prize will be fought out between Alt-J, Ed Sheeran, George Ezra, Royal Blood and Sam Smith.The live act category was dropped after 2013's ceremony.We've asked the organisers of the Brits for a response to Sergio Pizzorno's comments.Follow @BBCNewsbeat on Twitter, BBCNewsbeat on Instagram and Radio1Newsbeat on YouTube
sample_text: We were all set to shred the stage at the Brits, and then suddenly we get a call from the Bafta people asking us to open their show instead. I mean, don't get me wrong, it's an honor to be performing at the Royal Opera House, but it's just not the same vibe as rocking out at the O2."The guitarist, who wished to remain anonymous, hinted that there may be some behind-the-scenes politics at play. "Let's just say that we've had some creative differences with the Brits organizers in the past. I think they're still salty about that time we trashed our dressing room back in 2018."When asked about the band's setlist for the Baftas, the guitarist revealed that they're planning to debut some new material. "We're going to bring the house down with a special acoustic performance of our latest single. It's going to be a real departure from our usual high-energy show, but we're excited to showcase our more introspective side."The Baftas ceremony is set to take place on February 19th, and will be broadcast live on BBC One. The Leicester rockers will be joined by a star-studded lineup of presenters and performers, including Hollywood A-listers and British acting royalty.In related news, the Brit Awards have announced that they will be featuring a special performance by pop sensation, Ariana Grande, at their ceremony on February 22nd. Coincidence? The Leicester rockers think not.

first_sentence: Kingsley Burrell died on 31 March 2011, four days after he was detained after a disturbance at a shop in Birmingham.His family has previously claimed he was restrained using excessive force.In July, the Crown Prosecution Service said there was insufficient evidence to prosecute anyone over his death.The 29-year-old died at the Birmingham's Queen Elizabeth Hospital from a cardiac arrest.An inquest at Birmingham Coroners Court heard he was taken to a mental health unit after calling emergency services to the Haymer shop in Winson Green on 27 March 2011, claiming he had been threatened by two armed men while with his four-year-old son.His sister Kadisha Brown-Burrell said she had visited the mental health unit at the QE Hospital later in the day and been concerned by his condition.
text: "When he walked over he walked over stiff. He couldn't move his head, couldn't move his body, couldn't move his shoulders," she said. "Kingsley had three lumps, one on his forehead. I said to [his partner] Chantelle 'take a photo of that'. "She told the inquest when she visited the following day her brother had urinated and had been left on the floor in handcuffs for five or six hours. "He said that while he was in the QE during assessment he was on the floor, and all he wanted was a glass of water," she said.Ms Brown-Burrell said her brother, a father-of-three, had described being involved in a struggle with police officers in the back of an ambulance. "Kingsley said 'They've drugged me up in the head, they have injected me into my brain'. "Police officers told the family he had gone "berserk" in the ambulance and attacked his own son, and had to be restrained.Ms Brown-Burrell described her brother as "calm, collected and outgoing", but said he had been worried by a paternity issue with an ex-girlfriend, who claimed her son was not his.The jury was told he had been worried two men in the shop in Winson Green had come to threaten him over that issue and he had dialled 999 to say that armed gang members had "put a machine gun" to his head.CCTV footage played to the court, however, revealed no sign of armed men but showed Mr Burrell looking agitated near the counter.Andy Gillespie, a firefighter who was one of the first on the scene, described Mr Burrell as "very distressed" and said "it was almost that he felt relieved that he hadn't been shot".The inquest also heard that Mr Burrell had been carrying a CS canister on the day he was detained, as well as claims that he was a gang member and drug dealer. His partner Chantelle Graham said he was not a heavy drug user.Many of his family wore red T-shirts to the inquest with his photo and the slogan "Justice for Kingsley Burrell".The inquest is expected to last six weeks.
sample_text: Ms. Brown-Burrell also stated that she had asked staff at the unit to check on her brother regularly, but was told that they were short-staffed.The inquest heard that Kingsley Burrell was later restrained by police officers and mental health staff after he became aggressive and tried to leave the unit. He was placed in a seclusion room, where he was found unresponsive shortly after.A post-mortem examination revealed that Mr. Burrell had suffered a cardiac arrest, but the exact cause of his death remains unclear. The inquest is ongoing, with further evidence to be heard in the coming days.The case has sparked widespread concern and outrage, with many questioning the use of restraint techniques and the treatment of mental health patients by authorities. Mr. Burrell's family has called for greater transparency and accountability, and for those responsible for his death to be held accountable.The inquest is expected to continue for several more weeks, with evidence to be heard from police officers, mental health staff, and other witnesses. The family of Kingsley Burrell is being supported by the charity INQUEST, which provides support and guidance to families affected by deaths in custody.The case has also sparked a wider debate about the treatment of mental health patients and the use of restraint techniques. Campaigners are calling for greater investment in mental health services and for a review of the use of restraint techniques, which they argue can be dangerous and even deadly.As the inquest continues, the family of Kingsley Burrell and the wider community will be watching closely, seeking answers and justice for a young man who died in tragic and disturbing circumstances.

first_sentence: Swan, 16, was beaten 6-3 3-6 6-3 by Ysaline Bonaventure in the opening rubber of the best-of-three tie.Watson, 23, led 4-2 in the final set but eventually lost 6-4 3-6 6-4 to Alison van Uytvanck as Belgium took an unassailable 2-0 lead in the Group 1 promotion play-off in Eilat, Israel.
text: "The Belgian team were a bit stronger than us," captain Judy Murray said. "All in all, there are lots of things to be pleased about but we are very disappointed we didn't get out of this zone - we have been stuck in here for years and I am fed up of it. "Murray's squad beat South Africa and Georgia this week to reach the Group 1 play-off.Both British players were ranked lower than their opponents, with Swan the world number 524 and Bonaventure at 160, while Watson is 42 places below Van Uytvanck at 85 in the rankings.With the result of the tie already decided after the two singles matches, they did not play the doubles.GB were without world number 28 and Australian Open semi-finalist Johanna Konta, who withdrew with illness, and Naomi Broady, whose family has a long-running dispute with the Lawn Tennis Association.Former British number one Laura Robson was not considered as she is in the early stages of her latest comeback from wrist injuries.Murray added: "Next year we want a full team out, get out of the zone into the World Group to have some home and away ties, and really showcase British women's tennis to the fans in Britain. "The defeat by Belgium means GB miss out on a World Group II play-off in April, and the possibility of a first home tie for Britain's women since 1993.International Tennis Federation president David Haggerty says his organisation is reviewing the format of the Fed Cup. "The competition has benefited from the home-and-away knock-out format that has been so successful in the Davis Cup, and the ITF is looking at new formats that would allow a 16-team World Group, something that is favoured by many of our constituents," he said.
sample_text: Katie Swan, 16, was beaten 6-3 3-6 6-3 by Ysaline Bonaventure in the opening rubber, despite showing flashes of brilliance in a closely contested match. The young Briton struggled to find consistency, ultimately succumbing to the Belgian's experience and guile.Heather Watson, 23, fared little better in the second singles match, leading 4-2 in the final set but eventually losing 6-4 3-6 6-4 to Alison van Uytvanck. The British number one was left to rue a series of unforced errors and missed opportunities, as her opponent capitalized on her mistakes to take the win.The defeats leave Great Britain facing an uphill battle to reach the World Group II play-offs, with Belgium now holding a commanding 2-0 lead in the best-of-three tie. The British team will need to regroup and refocus if they are to have any chance of overturning the deficit and keeping their promotion hopes alive.Captain Anne Keothavong will be looking for a strong response from her team in tomorrow's doubles match, where Johanna Konta and Jocelyn Rae will take on Belgium's An-Sophie Mestach and Alison van Uytvanck. A win in the doubles would give Great Britain a glimmer of hope, but they will need to produce a much-improved performance if they are to have any chance of turning the tie around.

first_sentence: Fury shocked the boxing world by beating Wladimir Klitschko on Saturday to secure the WBA, IBF and WBO belts.But Fury has not forgiven Haye for pulling out of two scheduled fights against him in 2013 and causing him "mental and physical torture".
text: "David Haye will never get a fight against Tyson Fury after what he did to me," said the Manchester boxer. "I remember him saying that he'd never give me a payday. Well, the shoe is on the other foot now. "If he gets a mandatory shot with any of the governing bodies, I'll vacate the title. Let him go and fight Fred Flintstone or Joe Bloggs and make no money. "I don't care if he says I can make £10m by fighting him, it's not about money for me. "I knew how much boxers got messed about at the highest level. But there were times [when Haye pulled out of the fights] that I didn't want to box any more. "He is a pretender, a fraud and he is getting no opportunities from us. "Media playback is not supported on this deviceHaye, who lost to Klitschko in 2011, recently announced a comeback. He has not fought since beating Dereck Chisora in 2012 and underwent major shoulder surgery in 2013.The 35-year-old, a former two-weight world champion, will fight Australia's Mark de Mori in London on 16 January.Haye told BBC Sport on Sunday: "Tyson Fury is the number one in the division now. Mark de Mori is ranked number 10, I need to work my way up to two, to number one contender, to get to Tyson Fury. "If people want to come and support me on this journey to Tyson Fury then feel free, because it's going to be a fun ride. "A fight between Fury and Haye appeared to make perfect sense and could fill Wembley Stadium. And as is always the case in boxing, it could still happen, despite Fury's outburst.Fury's first defence is likely to be a rematch against Klitschko. Immediately after their fight the Ukrainian said he would trigger a rematch clause, although there is a chance he will decide that at 39, his best days are behind him.Aside from Haye, another prospective opponent for Fury is American Deontay Wilder, the WBC title-holder. Victory over Wilder would make Fury the first undisputed world heavyweight champion since Lennox Lewis in 2000.And while Olympic champion Anthony Joshua will not be ready to fight for a world title for a couple of years yet, a clash with Fury is already a mouth-watering prospect.
sample_text: David Haye.Fury's stunning unanimous decision win in Düsseldorf, Germany, secured the WBA, IBF, and WBO belts, cementing his status as the best heavyweight boxer in the world. However, the 27-year-old's post-fight comments made it clear that he has not forgotten the bitter past with Haye, who pulled out of two scheduled fights against Fury in 2013."Haye is a coward, a con artist, and a fake," Fury said in a scathing attack on the former WBA champion. "He's a guy who thinks he's above the sport, but he's nothing but a joke. He's a guy who pulled out of two fights against me, causing me mental and physical torture. I'll never forgive him for that."Fury's animosity towards Haye stems from the cancelled fights, which were scheduled to take place in September and November 2013. Haye cited a cut above his eye as the reason for the initial postponement, but Fury was left frustrated and disillusioned when the fight was eventually scrapped altogether.The bad blood between the two fighters has been simmering ever since, with Fury frequently taking to social media to taunt and criticize Haye. Now, with Fury holding all the aces as the new heavyweight champion, he is eager to settle the score once and for all."I'd love to get in the ring with Haye and show him what a real fighter looks like," Fury said. "I'd knock him out cold, just like I did to Klitschko. He's a has-been, a relic of the past, and I'm the future of heavyweight boxing."While a fight between Fury and Haye is far from certain, one thing is clear: the bad blood between these two fighters is very real, and it's only a matter of time before they finally settle their differences in the ring.
sample_text2: The war of words between Fury and Haye has been ongoing for years, with both fighters trading verbal jabs and insults on social media and in interviews. However, with Fury now holding the WBA, IBF, and WBO titles, the stakes have never been higher.Haye, who has been out of the ring since 2013, has been quietly plotting his comeback, and a fight against Fury would be the perfect opportunity to silence his critics and prove that he still has what it takes to be a world-class fighter.But Fury is not intimidated by Haye's reputation or his past achievements. In fact, he believes that Haye's best days are behind him, and that he is now nothing more than a shadow of his former self."Haye was a good fighter in his prime, but that was years ago," Fury said. "He's been out of the ring for too long, and he's not got the same hunger or desire that he used to have. I'm the one who's been dominating the heavyweight division, and I'm the one who's going to continue to do so."Fury's promoter, Mick Hennessy, has also weighed in on the situation, saying that a fight between Fury and Haye would be a huge event, but only if Haye is willing to put in the work and prove himself worthy of a shot at the title."Tyson Fury is the best heavyweight in the world, and he's not going to give Haye a shot at the title just because he's got a big mouth," Hennessy said. "Haye needs to prove himself, and if he can do that, then we'll consider making the fight happen. But until then, he's just a relic of the past, trying to cling onto his former glory."As the rivalry between Fury and Haye continues to simmer, one thing is certain: the boxing world is eagerly awaiting a showdown between these two bitter enemies. Will Haye be able to put aside his pride and prove himself worthy of a shot at the title, or will Fury continue to dominate the heavyweight division and leave Haye in his wake? Only time will tell.

first_sentence: Pensions scheme members reported "hardship, distress and inconvenience" caused by the late payment of pensions, the NAO said.MyCSP said its performance was now back to a "steady state".The PCS union said the mutualisation had been "a textbook case in how not to reform public services".MyCSP, a joint venture between government and private sector firm Equiniti, took over civil service pensions administration from Capita in September 2014.In a report on Thursday Amyas Morse, head of the National Audit Office said the mutual "did not cope with the workload and a large backlog of work built up".
text: "Some people were paid late and members struggled to contact MyCSP," he added.Due to a lack of staff, a backlog of work grew, peaking at 22,000 urgent cases in January 2015, and many thousands of calls went unanswered.Between September 2014 and March 2015, MyCSP failed to answer 99,408 calls, the NAO said.The mutual was unable to prioritise urgent cases once a backlog had built up because of the way its system ran, NAO added.In January 2015 the Cabinet Office told the mutual to develop a plan to tackle the backlog.By September 2015 MyCSP had managed to re-establish previous performance levels and was not hit with any financial penalties, the NAO added.MyCSP said: "We recognise the findings of the National Audit Office report published today. "It has been well documented that a number of factors led to the reduction in service levels, including a communication to 1.1 million members which resulted in significantly increased call volumes and a corresponding impact on 'business as usual' workload. "It added that it had recruited new staff, increased call centre opening times, and started in-house training. "Call handling levels have been back to normal for the past six months, with a corresponding reduction in member complaints, significantly down from their peak at the time of the service challenges," it said. "Service to members remains our utmost priority and we will continue to work with... the Cabinet Office and employers to deliver towards that aim," MyCSP added.The PCS union said the NAO report had "exposed the failings of the government's only mutual venture in a damning verdict on the administration of civil service pensions".The new pension administration IT system, Compendia, was not fully ready when MyCSP took on the extra work, PCS said.Compendia was developed by Equiniti, which took over a controlling stake in the mutual in 2014, PCS added.PCS general secretary Mark Serwotka said: "The mutualisation of MyCSP has from the start been a textbook case in how not to reform public services."
sample_text: As a result, a significant backlog of work built up, leading to delays in pension payments and causing "hardship, distress, and inconvenience" to scheme members.The report highlighted that MyCSP's performance issues were exacerbated by inadequate planning, insufficient resources, and poor communication with stakeholders. The mutual's inability to cope with the workload led to a surge in complaints from pensioners, with many experiencing delays in receiving their pension payments.In response to the report, MyCSP claimed that its performance was now back to a "steady state," suggesting that the issues had been addressed. However, the Public and Commercial Services (PCS) union, which represents civil servants, was highly critical of the mutualisation of pensions administration.The PCS union described the MyCSP experience as "a textbook case in how not to reform public services." The union argued that the government's decision to outsource pensions administration to a private sector-led mutual had been a mistake, and that the problems encountered by MyCSP were a direct result of this flawed approach.The NAO report's findings are likely to fuel concerns about the government's plans to mutualise other public services. The report's author, Amyas Morse, warned that the MyCSP experience highlighted the importance of careful planning and robust risk management when introducing significant changes to public services.The government has faced criticism in the past for its handling of public sector outsourcing contracts, with several high-profile failures, including the collapse of Carillion, a major outsourcing firm. The MyCSP debacle is likely to add to the growing scrutiny of the government's outsourcing policies and the role of private sector companies in delivering public services.In the meantime, pensioners who were affected by the delays in pension payments will be hoping that MyCSP's claims of improved performance are genuine, and that they will no longer experience the "hardship, distress, and inconvenience" caused by the mutual's earlier struggles.

first_sentence: Each one has taken it closer to what decades of international talks have tried to prevent - a nuclear weapon in the hands of one of the world's most unpredictable states.9 October 2006 - a weapon for 'peace'Years of posturing - and attempts at negotiation by foreign powers - culminated in October 2006 with an announcement by Pyongyang that it had carried out its first nuclear explosion.Like all tests that would follow, it took place underground, in tunnels dug into a remote mountainous site called Punggye-ri, in the north-east.The device is assumed to have used plutonium, sourced from the North's nuclear facility at Yongbyon.International observers estimated the blast had an energy discharge of about a kiloton, less than a tenth of the size of the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945.Many believed this indicated a nuclear "fizzle" rather than a fully effective blast.But the North said it had joined the nuclear club and that its bomb would contribute to peace and stability on the Korean peninsula.The second test was bigger, with an estimated yield of 2-8 kilotons.North Korea said it had achieved a "higher level in terms of its explosive power and technology".While the international consensus was that a nuclear test had happened, no radiation was detected.
text: The ability to contain a nuclear test would in itself be a big advance for the North.It also followed hard on the heels of a test of a missile with a long enough range to reach the US.Both were seen as an attempt by ailing leader Kim Jong-il to prove the North's nuclear capacity before he died.In the early hours of 12 February 2013, unusual seismic activity was again detected around Punggye-ri.The North said it had tested "a miniaturised and lighter nuclear device with greater explosive force than previously".The as-yet unproven reference to "miniaturised" stoked fears that Pyongyang was closer to producing a device small enough to fit on a long-range missile.Speculation was rife that the test involved a uranium device, though this has never been confirmed beyond doubt.A successful uranium test would mark a significant leap forward in North Korea's nuclear programme. The North's plutonium stocks are finite, but if it could enrich uranium it could build up a nuclear stockpile.Plutonium enrichment also has to happen in large, easy-to-spot facilities, whereas uranium enrichment can more easily be carried out in secrecy.The first indication was again report of an "artificial quake" in North Korea, registering about magnitude 5.1, close to Punggye-ri.North Korea later announced it had conducted its first successful test of a hydrogen bomb.H-bombs, also known as thermonuclear warheads, are massively more powerful than atomic bombs, using fusion - the merging of atoms - rather than fission to unleash enormous amounts of energy.Though again it has never been confirmed, that claim alarmed the international community.Observations from afar suggested the blast detected was not large enough to have been a full thermonuclear device, but may have involved some nuclear fusion.Again, North Korea said the device had been miniaturised.A few months later, Kim Jong-un announced that North Korea scientists had been able to do what had long been feared, and make a nuclear warhead small enough to fit on a warhead.It came after days of threats to carry out "indiscriminate" attacks on the US and South Korea. But analysts said it was impossible to confirm.
sample_text: The blast was estimated to be between 2-8 kilotons, significantly larger than the first test. Pyongyang claimed that it had achieved a "higher level in terms of its explosive power and technology".The test was met with widespread condemnation from the international community, with the United Nations Security Council imposing new sanctions on the country. The test also sparked concerns about the potential for radioactive fallout, although no radiation was detected.12 February 2013 - A Third TestNorth Korea's third nuclear test, conducted on February 12, 2013, was its most powerful yet. The blast was estimated to be around 10 kilotons, and was widely seen as a significant step forward in the country's nuclear program.The test was conducted in defiance of international warnings, and was met with strong condemnation from the United States, South Korea, and other countries. The UN Security Council imposed further sanctions on North Korea, and the country was also expelled from the International Atomic Energy Agency.6 January 2016 - A Hydrogen Bomb?North Korea's fourth nuclear test, conducted on January 6, 2016, was claimed by Pyongyang to be a hydrogen bomb. The blast was estimated to be around 7-10 kilotons, and was seen as a significant escalation in the country's nuclear program.However, many experts questioned whether the test was actually a hydrogen bomb, citing the relatively small yield and the lack of evidence of a thermonuclear reaction. Nevertheless, the test sparked widespread concern about the potential for North Korea to develop a more powerful and sophisticated nuclear weapon.9 September 2016 - A Fifth TestNorth Korea's fifth nuclear test, conducted on September 9, 2016, was its most powerful yet. The blast was estimated to be around 10-30 kilotons, and was seen as a significant step forward in the country's nuclear program.The test was conducted just days after North Korea launched three ballistic missiles into the Sea of Japan, sparking concerns about the country's rapidly advancing nuclear and missile capabilities.3 September 2017 - A Sixth TestNorth Korea's sixth and most recent nuclear test, conducted on September 3, 2017, was its largest and most powerful yet. The blast was estimated to be around 120-160 kilotons, and was seen as a significant escalation in the country's nuclear program.The test was met with widespread condemnation from the international community, and sparked concerns about the potential for North Korea to develop a nuclear weapon capable of reaching the United States.Throughout its nuclear testing program, North Korea has consistently claimed that its goal is to develop a nuclear deterrent to protect itself from external threats. However, the international community remains deeply concerned about the potential risks and consequences of the country's nuclear program.

first_sentence: Parry, 35, threw two Commonwealth Games A standards with efforts of 65.25m and 65.32m to put her in contention for a place at the Gold Coast next April.The Rhondda athlete is looking to add the silver won in Delhi in 2010.
text: "I am looking to get a medal next year and won't go if I didn't think I was capable," said Parry.Parry was the only Welsh athlete to achieve a Commonwealth Games A standard at the Welsh Championships. It was her 12th successive Welsh title and 13th overall.Parry  joined Melissa Courtney (1500m), Sally Peake (pole vault), Dewi Grffiths (10,000m), Ieuan Thomas (3,000m steeplechase), Josh Griffiths (marathon), Andrew Davies (marathon) David Omoregie (110m hurdles), Bethan Davies (20km walk), Jon Hopkins (3,000m steeplechase in achieving an A standard for the Gold Coast in 2018.Brett Morse (discus), Ben Gregory (decathlon), Jennifer Nesbitt (10,000m), Heather Lewis (20km walk), Adele Nicoll (shot putt), Tom Marshall (1500m) have recorded B standards. "I am absolutely delighted," Parry added. "I had a bit of difficult winter and this is only my second competition back so I am pleased. "I was walking my dog in November and I slipped down a bank and snapped my ankle and have had pins and plates put in there. "I would hope two A standards would get me selected but you have to wait for the letter or phone call. "It would be my fourth Commonwealth Games. "I started in Australia in Melbourne in 2006 and maybe this would be full circle. "Find out how to get into athletics with our special guide.Sprinter Mica Moore, who is hoping to compete at both the Commonwealth Games and Winter Olympics in the bobsleigh next year, won the 100m in a time of 11.69 seconds.Sam Gordon ran a new personal best to win the men's event in 10.32secs.Other winners included Bethan Davies (3km walk), Brett Morse (discus), Adele Nicoll (shot putt), Dewi Griffiths (5,000m) and Thomas Williams (200m).Paralympic champion Aled Sion Davies, who was this week named in the Great Britain squad for the World Championships in London 2017, competed in the discus and shot putt.Leading Welsh athletes David Omoregie, Sally Peake, Hannah Brier, Rhys Williams and Seren Bundy-Davies were not competing.The 100th Welsh Championship was marked by a parade of more than 100 former winners, including 1964 Olympic long jump gold medallist Lynn Davies, ex-world marathon record holder Steve Jones and Merthyr Tydfil's Venissa Head who won a record 25 Welsh titles in discus and shot.
sample_text: Parry's impressive throws at the Loughborough European Athletics Permit Meeting have propelled her to the top of the UK rankings and have set her up nicely for a strong challenge at the Commonwealth Games.The Welsh athlete, who has been training under the guidance of coach Andrew Neal, has been working tirelessly to perfect her technique and build up her strength and endurance. Her hard work appears to be paying off, with her recent performances suggesting that she is in the form of her life.Parry's achievement is all the more impressive given the strong competition she faces in the hammer throw event. The UK has a rich tradition of producing talented hammer throwers, and Parry will need to be at the top of her game if she is to secure a place on the podium at the Gold Coast.Despite the challenges ahead, Parry remains focused and determined to achieve her goal. "I'm thrilled with my recent performances and I'm feeling confident about my chances at the Commonwealth Games," she said in a statement. "I've been working hard and I'm in the best shape of my life. I'm looking forward to the opportunity to compete against the best athletes from around the world and to bring home another medal for Wales."With her sights firmly set on the Gold Coast, Parry will be looking to build on her recent success and continue to push herself to new heights. With her talent, dedication, and determination, she is sure to be a force to be reckoned with in the hammer throw event.

With her talent, dedication, and determination, she is sure to be a force to be reckoned with in the hammer throw event. Parry's rise to the top of the UK rankings is a testament to her unwavering commitment to her craft. The 25-year-old athlete has been training relentlessly, honing her skills and building her strength and endurance. Her hard work has paid off, with her recent performances suggesting that she is in the form of her life.The Loughborough European Athletics Permit Meeting was a crucial stepping stone for Parry, providing her with the perfect opportunity to test her mettle against some of the best athletes in the world. And she did not disappoint, producing a series of impressive throws that left the competition in her wake.Parry's coach, Andrew Neal, has been instrumental in her success, providing her with expert guidance and support every step of the way.

first_sentence: Xixi Bi, 24, was attacked by Jordan Matthews in August 2016 suffering a broken jaw, ribs and widespread bruising.
text: She died in hospital after a cardiac arrest.Matthews had admitted manslaughter but denied murder.But a jury at Cardiff Crown Court found him guilty.Following the verdict Miss Bi's family branded Matthews as a "selfish, mindless and gutless" man who "ripped the heart out of our family".Matthews had told police he was a black belt in karate but did not think the incident was bad enough to cause the injuries Miss Bi suffered.But the court heard he regularly beat her and called her "worthless".Matthews said he had hit Miss Bi, believing she had cheated on him and cried when he was later told she had died.He told Cardiff Crown Court he had planned to marry Miss Bi.Matthews accepted he was smoking "quite a lot" of cannabis at the time, and the court heard he felt "insecure" when his girlfriend went to visit her family in China.He said he became "paranoid" about Miss Bi being unfaithful to him, and believed at the time she had received a message from someone called "Ben" on the Tinder dating app.Both prosecution and the defence agreed that Miss Bi did not have the Tinder app, nor any contact called "Ben".Analysis from pathologist Dr Ryk James said: "The assault upon her was severe and involved dozens of impacts. "She had died as a result of the multiple blunt force injuries. "Born in China, Miss Bi was educated in the UK from the age of 15 and was a post-graduate student at Cardiff Metropolitan University at the time of her death.In a statement following the verdict Miss Bi's family described her as an "intelligent and energetic person who had a very bright future and her whole life in front of her". "All this was taken away from her, and us, by the selfish, mindless and gutless actions of Jordan Mathews, who brutally killed her for no other reason than jealousy," they said. "He has wallowed in self-pity and refused to accept the truth. "Her family said they hoped the sentence would prevent Matthews from ever having the opportunity to hurt anyone else and give him time to reflect on his actions.Cardiff Metropolitan University said they were offering support to students and staff affected by her death.A spokesman said: "The University offers its deepest sympathies to the family and friends of Xixi at this very difficult time."
sample_text: The attack, which occurred on a quiet evening in August 2016, has been described by prosecutors as a "savage and unprovoked" assault.According to eyewitnesses, Matthews, 27, approached Bi without warning and launched a vicious attack, punching and kicking her repeatedly. The assault was so severe that it left Bi with a broken jaw, multiple broken ribs, and widespread bruising across her face and body.Bi, a university student at the time, was rushed to the hospital where she underwent emergency surgery to repair her broken jaw. She spent several days in the hospital recovering from her injuries and was left with a long and difficult road to recovery.The attack has had a lasting impact on Bi's life, leaving her with ongoing anxiety and depression. She has also been forced to undergo extensive counseling to deal with the trauma of the assault.Matthews, who has a previous history of violence, was arrested and charged with assault causing grievous bodily harm. He is currently facing trial and could face up to 10 years in prison if convicted.The case has sparked outrage in the community, with many calling for tougher sentences for violent offenders. Bi's family and friends have also set up a support fund to help her with her ongoing medical expenses and recovery.As the trial approaches, Bi's loved ones are rallying around her, urging the community to stand up against violence and support victims of assault. "No one deserves to go through what Xixi has gone through," said her sister, Mei Bi. "We need to make sure that justice is served and that Jordan Matthews is held accountable for his actions."
sample_text2: The community has rallied around Bi, with many taking to social media to express their outrage and support for the young woman. A hashtag campaign, #JusticeForXixi, has gone viral, with thousands of people sharing messages of solidarity and calling for tougher sentences for violent offenders.Local businesses have also stepped up to show their support, with several donating to Bi's support fund and offering discounts to customers who wear #JusticeForXixi t-shirts.Meanwhile, Matthews' defense team has argued that their client was under the influence of drugs and alcohol at the time of the attack, and that he is willing to plead guilty to a lesser charge.However, prosecutors are pushing for the maximum sentence, citing Matthews' previous history of violence and the severity of Bi's injuries."This was a brutal and unprovoked attack on a innocent young woman," said prosecutor, Sarah Lee. "The defendant's actions have had a devastating impact on Xixi's life, and he must be held accountable for his actions."As the trial approaches, Bi's loved ones are bracing themselves for what promises to be a difficult and emotional ordeal. But they are determined to see justice served and to ensure that Matthews is held accountable for his actions."Xixi is a strong and brave young woman, but she should never have had to go through what she did," said Mei Bi. "We will be in court every day, supporting her and fighting for justice."The trial is set to begin on March 15, and is expected to last several weeks. The community is urged to continue showing their support for Bi and her family, and to demand justice for victims of assault.In the meantime, Bi's family and friends are urging anyone who may have witnessed the attack or has information about Matthews' whereabouts on the night of the assault to come forward."Every piece of evidence counts, and we need the community's help to ensure that justice is served," said Mei Bi.As the community continues to rally around Bi, one thing is clear: no one deserves to go through what she has gone through, and it's time for justice to be served.

first_sentence: The Child Exploitation and Online Protection Centre, now part of the National Crime Agency, took more than a year to pass the details on to police.Canadian police sent files to CEOP on about 2,000 men, including Myles Bradbury, convicted in September of abusing boys at a hospital until 2013.NCA head Keith Bristow told MPs he was sorry if children had been put at risk.Information on the men was sent by Toronto Police in July 2012, as part of an international investigation, Operation Spade, into suspected paedophiles.But it was not passed on to police forces until more than 12 months later in November 2013.The BBC has obtained figures from several police forces suggesting they have arrested only about a third of the names they were given.And so far just 6% have been charged, including teachers and nursery workers.West Yorkshire Police, which received the names of 60 people a year ago, had made no arrests a week ago but in the last few days has arrested 24 menA spokesman for the force said the arrests were very recent and no-one had yet been charged.Mr Bristow told the home affairs select committee: "Sitting on data for the period of time between July 2012 and November 2013, that could have led to children being protected or safeguarded, seems to me whether it's systemic or it's down to individuals - and there are certainly some systemic issues that we need to work through - that's not in the spirit of what we stand for.
text: "I'm sorry if that's led to harm to children or exposing them to risk because that's not what we stand for. "Mr Bristow told the committee: "We are sat on a daily basis on top of significant risk because of the sheer volume of images and the different methods of offending by people who have a sexual interest in children. "And we have a problem - not just NCA, not just law enforcement, not just government - we as a society have a problem with the number of people in the UK who access these horrible images or paying for children to be abused online. "Police watchdog the IPCC has written to every chief constable to see if information from the Canadian investigation has been mishandled.Det Insp Jim Foy, of another of the forces, West Midlands Police, said: "In November 2013, we received 58 packages from the National Crime Agency (NCA) in connection with Operation Spade. "After an initial assessment of the information provided, 30 were found to be no longer for our attention as either the suspects were already under investigation, were deceased or had moved away from the West Midlands Force area. "Of the remaining 28 referrals, four people have already been charged with offences. Two are awaiting charging advice from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) and 16 have been arrested and are currently on police bail. "No further action was required in six of the packages: we found no evidence of any offences in five of the referrals and one of the cases involved a man with serious mental health issues."
sample_text: We need to learn from this and make sure it doesn't happen again."The delay in passing on the information has been criticized by child protection experts, who say it may have allowed some of the suspected paedophiles to continue abusing children."This is a shocking failure of the system," said John Carr, a member of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety. "It's unacceptable that it took over a year for this information to be passed on to the police. Who knows how many children may have been harmed as a result?"The National Crime Agency (NCA) has launched an internal investigation into the delay, and MPs have called for a full inquiry into the matter.The files sent by Toronto Police were part of Operation Spade, a global investigation into a child abuse ring that was dismantled in 2013. The operation resulted in the arrest of over 300 people worldwide, including Myles Bradbury, a British doctor who was convicted of abusing boys at a hospital in Cambridge.The BBC has learned that several police forces in the UK received the files from the NCA in November 2013, but many have yet to make arrests or bring charges against the suspected paedophiles.In addition to West Yorkshire Police, other forces that have received the files include the Metropolitan Police, Greater Manchester Police, and West Midlands Police.The Home Affairs Select Committee has called for the NCA to provide a full explanation for the delay and to outline the steps it is taking to prevent similar failures in the future."This is a serious breach of trust and a failure of the system," said Keith Vaz, the committee's chairman. "We need to get to the bottom of what happened and make sure it doesn't happen again."The NCA has apologized for the delay and has promised to cooperate fully with the investigation. The agency has also pledged to review its procedures to ensure that information is shared quickly and effectively with police forces in the future.In the meantime, child protection experts are calling for greater transparency and accountability in the handling of child abuse cases."This is a wake-up call for all of us," said Mr. Carr. "We need to make sure that our systems are working properly and that we're doing everything we can to protect children from abuse."
final_sample_text: We need to learn from this and make sure it doesn't happen again."The delay in passing on the information has been criticized by child protection experts, who say it may have allowed some of the suspected paedophiles to continue abusing children."This is a shocking failure of the system," said John Carr, a member of the UK Council for Child Internet Safety. "It's unacceptable that it took over a year for this information to be passed on to the police. Who knows how many children may have been harmed as a result?"The National Crime Agency (NCA) has launched an internal investigation into the delay, and MPs have called for a full inquiry into the matter.The files sent by Toronto Police were part of Operation Spade, a global investigation into a child abuse ring that was dismantled in 2013. The operation resulted in the arrest of over 300 people worldwide, including Myles Bradbury, a British doctor who was convicted of abusing boys at a hospital in Cambridge.The BBC has learned that several police forces in the UK received the files from the NCA in November 2013, but many have yet to make arrests or bring charges against the suspected paedophiles.In addition to West Yorkshire Police, other forces that have received the files include the Metropolitan Police, Greater Manchester Police, and West Midlands Police.The Home Affairs Select Committee has called for the NCA to provide a full explanation for the delay and to outline the steps it is taking to prevent similar failures in the future."This is a serious breach of trust and a failure of the system," said Keith Vaz, the committee's chairman.

first_sentence: There were 70 reports during the lambing season earlier this year compared with 45 over the same time last year.Police Scotland said the crime, which involved dogs chasing farm animals, had previously been under-reported.It said 60% of this year's incidents were detected and the dogs' owners reported to the procurator fiscal.Most of the offences reported were in Aberdeenshire, Highlands and Islands and Lanarkshire.Sheep were the most common animal affected.
text: Other animals involved included horses and cattle.In 79% of incidents, livestock were killed or injured, and on average this involved two or three sheep per incident.Most incidents - 70% - involved only one dog and in 73% of cases the offending dog was local to that area, with more than half of all incidents involving a dog roaming free and where no owner was present.Insp Jane Donaldson, Police Scotland's rural crime co-ordinator, said the rise in reports followed a campaign encouraging farmers and crofters to contact police about livestock worrying incidents.She said: "Livestock worrying has previously been under-reported. "Farmers were often reluctant to report incidents to police, particularly where there was a 'near miss' and no physical damage was done to their livestock. "A significant part of the spring campaign was to get this message out to farmers and encourage them to report all incidents and I think that this is reflected in the increase in reported crimes. "More accurate reporting has improved our understanding of the problem, increasing intelligence about the how, where and why these incidents are occurring. "Anne Gray, policy officer with Scottish Land and Estates, said: "We are very pleased with how successful this year's campaign has been and we will continue to support the initiative going forward. "It is vital that livestock worrying incidents are reduced. "No-one wants to see this type of completely unnecessary suffering and the higher the profile of these incidents the more, we hope, it will prompt the small minority of irresponsible dog owners to change their ways and ensure they know where their dog is at all times."
sample_text: According to Police Scotland, there were 70 reports of dogs chasing farm animals, a marked increase from the 45 incidents reported during the same period last year.The rise in reported incidents is attributed, in part, to a greater awareness among farmers and the public about the importance of reporting these crimes. Police Scotland believes that livestock attacks have historically been under-reported, and the increased numbers may reflect a growing willingness to come forward and report these incidents.In a positive development, 60% of this year's incidents resulted in the detection of the dogs involved and their owners being reported to the procurator fiscal. This suggests that efforts to tackle the problem are yielding results, and those responsible are being held accountable.The majority of the offences reported were in Aberdeenshire, Highlands and Islands, and Lanarkshire, with sheep being the most common animal affected. The attacks not only cause significant distress to the animals but also result in financial losses for farmers, who may be forced to euthanize injured animals or suffer from reduced productivity.Police Scotland is urging dog owners to take responsibility for their pets and to ensure they are kept under control, particularly in rural areas where livestock is present. Farmers are also being advised to take precautions to protect their animals, including using fencing and other deterrents to prevent dog attacks.The Scottish Government has also weighed in on the issue, with Rural Affairs Minister, Mairi Gougeon, stating, "Livestock attacks are a serious concern for farmers and can have devastating consequences for their businesses. We are working closely with Police Scotland and other stakeholders to raise awareness about the importance of responsible dog ownership and to support farmers in protecting their animals."As the lambing season comes to a close, farmers and animal welfare groups are urging dog owners to remain vigilant and to take steps to prevent further attacks. With increased awareness and cooperation, it is hoped that the number of livestock attacks can be reduced, and the rural community can work together to protect Scotland's agricultural heritage.

first_sentence: The move ends years of speculation about the ownership of the company.Bernie Ecclestone will remain as chief executive but Chase Carey, vice-chairman of 21st Century Fox, will become the new chairman.Liberty Media has stakes in several sports and entertainment businesses, including the Atlanta Braves Major League Baseball club.Owned by the billionaire John Malone, Liberty will initially purchase a minority stake in the world's leading motor-racing championship.
text: A full takeover is planned if regulators approve the deal.The total transaction values the firm at $8bn but includes $4.1bn worth of F1's debt.Liberty Media is buying the stake from the private equity firm CVC Capital.CVC has held a stake for the past decade but sold some of its holding in 2012.It has been criticised for taking considerable profits from the sport, which has suffered from falling TV ratings in recent years.This is one of the biggest deals in sports history and one of the most important moments in the history of F1.Under overlord Bernie Ecclestone's long command - and the last decade of ownership by private equity group CVC - the motorsport series has enjoyed remarkable growth in terms of global popularity, profits and new races.Liberty Media will hope to build on these strengths, helping the sport gain new fans, especially in the Americas, and to capitalise on new opportunities around marketing, promotion, digital rights and social media.However, assuming European regulators approve the takeover, there are issues that the new US owners will need to address - the decline in appeal among younger audiences in an ultra-competitive sporting landscape, the rising costs to teams, fans and circuits, and the predictability of races.Many inside the sport will be relieved to see the back of CVC, which has done very well out of its investment, and excited by the future. But this is also the beginning of the end of Mr Ecclestone's remarkable reign. Inevitably there will be uncertainty.Ecclestone to stay for 'three more years'Beginning of the end for Ecclestone?Ecclestone: The man, the myths and the motors"We are excited to become part of Formula 1," said Greg Maffei, chief executive of Liberty Media. "We think our long-term perspective and expertise with media and sports assets will allow us to be good stewards of Formula 1 and benefit fans, teams and our shareholders. "Mr Ecclestone said: "I would like to welcome Liberty Media and Chase Carey to Formula 1 and I look forward to working with them. "Earlier, he said in an interview with Reuters that he had been asked to stay on for three years and would miss the Singapore Grand Prix on 18 September as he needed be in London for the negotiations.The 85-year-old British businessman has run the sport for 40 years.
sample_text: The deal, reportedly worth $4.4 billion, marks a significant shift in the ownership structure of Formula One, which has been controlled by Ecclestone and his family for over 40 years.Ecclestone, 85, has been the driving force behind Formula One's growth into a global phenomenon, but his leadership has also been marked by controversy and criticism. The change in ownership is expected to bring a new era of transparency and accountability to the sport.Carey, a veteran media executive, will bring a wealth of experience to his new role as chairman. His background in negotiating lucrative television deals and managing complex sports franchises is seen as a major asset for Formula One as it looks to expand its reach and revenue streams.Liberty Media's involvement in Formula One is also expected to lead to increased investment in the sport, particularly in areas such as digital media and fan engagement. The company's experience in owning and operating other sports franchises, such as the Atlanta Braves, is seen as a major plus in this regard.The deal is subject to regulatory approval, but is expected to be completed in the coming months. Once finalized, it will mark a new chapter in the history of Formula One, and could have significant implications for the sport's future direction and growth.In a statement, Ecclestone said: "I am excited to work with Chase Carey and the Liberty Media team to take Formula One to the next level. This is a great opportunity for the sport, and I am confident that together, we can achieve great things."Carey added: "We are thrilled to have the opportunity to invest in Formula One, and we look forward to working with Bernie and the entire Formula One team to build on the sport's success."
sample_text2: The sale of Formula One to Liberty Media is seen as a major coup for the sport, which has been seeking to expand its global reach and appeal to a younger demographic. The deal is expected to bring a new level of investment and expertise to the sport, which has been criticized in recent years for its lack of innovation and stagnation.One of the key areas of focus for Liberty Media is expected to be the development of Formula One's digital presence. The sport has been slow to adapt to the changing media landscape, and its online offerings have been criticized for being outdated and lacking in engagement. Liberty Media's experience in this area, through its ownership of other sports franchises such as the Atlanta Braves, is seen as a major asset in helping Formula One to catch up with other sports in terms of digital innovation.Another area of focus is expected to be fan engagement. Formula One has been criticized in recent years for its lack of accessibility and its failure to connect with fans. Liberty Media is expected to bring a new level of enthusiasm and energy to the sport, and to work to create a more immersive and engaging experience for fans.The deal is also expected to have significant implications for the teams and drivers competing in Formula One. The sport has been plagued by controversy and infighting in recent years, and the change in ownership is seen as an opportunity to bring a new level of stability and cooperation to the sport.In a statement, the Formula One Teams Association (FOTA) welcomed the deal, saying: "We are excited to work with Liberty Media and Chase Carey to build a brighter future for Formula One. We believe that this new ownership structure will bring a new level of investment and expertise to the sport, and we look forward to working together to achieve great things."The deal is subject to regulatory approval, but is expected to be completed in the coming months. Once finalized, it will mark a new chapter in the history of Formula One, and could have significant implications for the sport's future direction and growth.In related news, it is understood that Bernie Ecclestone will remain involved with Formula One in a consultative role, although the exact nature of his involvement is still to be determined. Ecclestone's leadership of the sport has been marked by controversy and criticism, but he is also widely credited with transforming Formula One into the global phenomenon it is today.As the sport looks to the future, one thing is clear: the sale of Formula One to Liberty Media marks a significant turning point in the history of the sport, and could have far-reaching implications for its future direction and growth.

first_sentence: Weir showed his strength in the final 600 metres to win the T54 5,000m - the first of five events he has entered at this week's event in Grosseto.There were also golds for fellow wheelchair racers Mo Jomnez and Richard Chiassaro, sprinters Maria Lyle and Richard Whitehead and throwers Dan Greaves and Aled Davies.Weir, 37, competing over the T54 5,000m distance for the first time this year, said: "I knew coming here I was in good shape and it's all looking good for Rio.
text: "Jomnez - who is part of the Weir-Archer Academy, which the four-time London gold medallist runs with coach Jenny Archer - set a new personal best of 26.64 seconds to claim the T53 200m title, while there was also a new championship record and first major title for Chiassaro in the T54 200m event. "It feels great," said Jomnez, who won 200m bronze at last year's World Championships in Doha. "It was a fast race - the field is getting really strong. "After winning the T35 100m in 14.45secs, short of her own European record of 13.92, Scottish teenager Lyle accepted she will need to do more in Rio when she faces her Australian rival Isis Holt, the world champion and world record holder, who has a best of 13.57. "I'm definitely happy that I've got my title again but I'm a little disappointed with how I ran it," said the 16-year-old. "I've got plenty of time before Rio to sort that out. It will be good to sort the mistakes out from my 100m to the 200m. "Whitehead showed the work on his starts have been paying up with a perfectly-timed run in the T42 100m.The London 200m champion made his customary late charge to win by 0.03 seconds from Russian Anton Prokhorov in a new championship record of 12.21 seconds. "That probably wasn't my best 100m race but it is about performing in the finals," he said. "I knew a 12.2 would probably win it today. "Myself and my coach Keith Antoine had done some work on the warm-up track before but I felt in cracking shape. "Greaves retained his F46 discus title with a best throw of 58.15 metres, while Davies was just two centimetres short of his F42 shot put world record of 16.13m, beating the rest of the field by over two and a half metres.Britain also claimed silvers on Sunday through Carly Tait (T34 400m), Isaac Towers (T34 400m) and Sophie Hahn (T38 200m), while there were bronzes for Ben Rowlings (T34 400m), Steve Osborne (T51 100m) and Kadeena Cox (T38 200m).Meanwhile, German 'Blade Jumper' Markus Rehm, who wants to compete in both the Rio Olympics and Paralympics, easily won the T44 long jump event, leaping 7.98 metres, but it was well short of his best of 8.40m.
sample_text: "I've been working hard on my endurance and it paid off today. I'm feeling strong and confident, and I'm excited to see how the rest of the week goes."Weir, a six-time Paralympic gold medalist, is considered one of the favorites to win multiple gold medals in Rio. His dominant performance in the T54 5,000m event at the Grosseto Grand Prix, a key tune-up event for the Paralympics, only solidified his status as a top contender.Fellow British athletes also had a successful day, with Mo Jomnez and Richard Chiassaro winning gold medals in the T53 100m and T54 400m events, respectively. Maria Lyle and Richard Whitehead took top honors in the T35 100m and T42 200m events, while Dan Greaves and Aled Davies won gold in the F44 discus and F42 shot put events.The strong showing by the British team bodes well for their chances at the Paralympic Games, which take place from September 7-18. "We're all feeling really confident and motivated after today's performances," said Weir. "We're all pushing each other to be our best, and it's going to be an exciting few weeks ahead."The Grosseto Grand Prix continues through the weekend, with Weir set to compete in the T54 800m, 1,500m, and 4x400m relay events.
sample_text2: Weir's Dominant Performance at Grosseto Grand Prix Boosts British Team's Confidence Ahead of Rio ParalympicsGrosseto, Italy - David Weir, a six-time Paralympic gold medalist, led the British team to a stellar performance at the Grosseto Grand Prix, a key tune-up event for the Rio Paralympics. Weir's dominant win in the T54 5,000m event has solidified his status as a top contender for multiple gold medals in Rio.Weir, who has been working tirelessly on his endurance, was thrilled with his performance. "I've been putting in the hard work, and it paid off today. I'm feeling strong and confident, and I'm excited to see how the rest of the week goes," he said.The British team had a successful day, with several athletes winning gold medals in their respective events. Mo Jomnez took top honors in the T53 100m event, while Richard Chiassaro won gold in the T54 400m event. first_sentence: The Chinese firm, which handles more transactions than Amazon and eBay combined, reported a net income of 71bn yuan ($11bn; Â£7.6bn) for the year to 31 March, up 193% on the previous year.Sales rose by a third to 101bn yuan, with sales on mobile devices up 182%.
text: "Alibaba Group finished the fiscal year on a very strong note," said chief executive Daniel Zhang. "Whatever they are doing must be working, and most importantly it's a sign that the Chinese consumer may not be weakening quite yet," said Gil Luria of Wedbush Securities.Despite the strong rise in sales, the company has struggled to reach the growth levels it recorded before it became a public company two years ago.It faces strong competition from local rival websites like Baidu, Tencent and JD.com.Shares have also lost more than a third of their value since the company held its record initial public offering in 2014.The company's original business was Alibaba.com, set up by the company's colourful founder, Jack Ma, in 1999. It helps to connect exporters in China (and other countries) with companies in over 190 countries around the world.The business now includes entertainment services, including China's version of YouTube, Youku Tudou, as well as payment systems and cloud computing and logistics services.Increasingly, Mr Ma is looking to counter the company's reliance on Chinese consumers, with the firm now looking to get up to half of its sales from abroad.Among recent deals to expand was the purchase of South East Asia e-commerce start-up Lazada and Hong Kong's well-respected English language, the South China Morning Post.Another area of potential growth investors are excited about is its payment platform Alipay.Alipay is operated by affiliate Zhejiang Ant Small & Micro Financial Services Group, also known as Ant Financial.Mr Ma controls Ant, which is China's biggest online financial services firm, and is said to be worth around $60bn following its latest fundraising round.
sample_text: The company's net income of 71 billion yuan ($11 billion; £7.6 billion) for the year ending March 31 marks a staggering 193% increase from the previous year, solidifying its position as one of the world's most successful and influential companies.The significant growth in sales, which rose by a third to 101 billion yuan, can be attributed to the company's successful expansion into mobile commerce. Sales on mobile devices surged by an astonishing 182%, demonstrating Alibaba's ability to adapt to the rapidly changing online shopping landscape.Alibaba's dominance in the e-commerce space is undeniable, with the company handling more transactions than Amazon and eBay combined. Its popular online marketplaces, including Taobao and Tmall, have become an essential part of daily life for millions of Chinese consumers.The company's success can also be attributed to its strategic investments in cloud computing, digital payments, and logistics. Alibaba's cloud computing arm, AliCloud, has become a major player in the industry, while its digital payment platform, Alipay, has revolutionized the way people pay for goods and services online.Alibaba's impressive financial results have sent its stock soaring, with investors eager to capitalize on the company's continued growth and expansion. The company's market value has surpassed that of many of its Western counterparts, cementing its position as a global e-commerce leader.As Alibaba continues to expand its reach into new markets and industries, its impact on the global economy is likely to be significant. The company's success serves as a testament to the growing influence of Chinese businesses on the world stage, and its financial results are being closely watched by investors and analysts around the world.
